As for His saying the Exalted: <<فَلا تُزَكُّوا أَنْفُسَكُمْ هُوَ أَعْلَمُ بِمَنِ اتَّقَى>> (So do not purify yourselves; He is most knowing of who is pious), this means that Allah does not accept the *Zakat* of a soul that attributes itself to itself. For He said: <<فَلا تُزَكُّوا أَنْفُسَكُمْ>> (So do not purify *yourselves*), attributing them to you. That is, if you believe that your souls belong to you, not to Me, and the *Zakat* is My right, and you are trustees over it, then when you are called upon regarding it, you claim that you gave Me what was yours, and that I asked you for what was not Mine. The reality is contrary to that. Whoever is in this position of giving should not purify his soul (*yuzakkī nafsah*), for I only requested what is Mine, not yours, until you meet Me and the veil is lifted in the Hereafter. At that time, you will know whether your souls, upon which I obligated *Zakat*, were Mine or yours, though your knowledge then will not benefit you. For this reason, He said: <<فَلا تُزَكُّوا أَنْفُسَكُمْ>> (So do not purify *yourselves*), attributing the souls to you, though they belong to Him.

### The Soul of Jesus: From One Aspect It is His, and From Another It is Allah's

Do you not see how Jesus (peace be upon him) attributed his soul (*nafs*) to himself from one aspect that belongs to him, and attributed it to Allah from the aspect that belongs to Allah? He said: <<تَعْلَمُ مَا فِي نَفْسِي وَلا أَعْلَمُ مَا فِي نَفْسِكَ>> (You know what is within my soul, but I do not know what is within Your Soul). He attributed it to Allah—meaning, My soul is Your Soul and Your property, for You purchased it, and it is not in my ownership. So, You are most knowing of what You placed within it. And he attributed the soul to himself, for in terms of its essence (*‘ayn*), it belongs to him, but in terms of its Existence (*wujūd*), it belongs to Allah, not to him. So he said: <<تَعْلَمُ مَا فِي نَفْسِي>> (You know what is within my soul) from the perspective of its essence, and <<وَلا أَعْلَمُ مَا فِي نَفْسِكَ>> (but I do not know what is within Your Soul) from the perspective of its Existence, which is from the perspective of what belongs to You.

### The Soul is One in Essence, but Multiple in Attributions and Relations

Although the soul (*nafs*) is one, the attributions (*iḍāfāt*) differ due to the difference in relations (*nisab*). Therefore, His saying <<فَلا تُزَكُّوا أَنْفُسَكُمْ>> (So do not purify yourselves) does not contradict what we mentioned of His saying <<قَدْ أَفْلَحَ مَنْ زَكَّاهَا>> (He has succeeded who purifies it). For "yourselves" here means your likes. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "I do not purify anyone before Allah." We shall discuss, if Allah wills, in this chapter the obligation of *Zakat*, upon whom it is obligatory, upon what it is obligatory, how much is obligatory, from what amount it is obligatory, when it is obligatory, when it is not obligatory, to whom it is obligatory, and how much is due to those to whom it is obligatory, considering all of this in the esoteric sense (*bāṭin*) after establishing it in the exoteric sense (*ẓāhir*) according to the language of the prescribed ruling, just as we did with the Prayer (*Salat*), in order to combine the exoteric and the esoteric for the perfection of the manifestation (*nash’a*).

### The Consideration in Combining the Exoteric and the Esoteric

For no form appears in the world from any of Allah's creation, regardless of the cause of its appearance—whether shapes or otherwise—except that this contingent essence (*‘ayn al-ḥāditha*) in the sensory realm has a spirit (*rūḥ*) that accompanies that form and shape which appeared. For Allah is the true Originator (*al-Mūjid*) of that form, through the agency (*niyāba*) of one of His existents (*akwān*)—whether angel, jinn, human, animal, plant, or inanimate object. These are all the causes for the existence of that form in the sensory realm. Since we know that Allah has linked every sensory form to a spiritual, intelligible spirit (*rūḥ ma‘nawī*) through a Divine orientation based on the ruling of a Lordly Name (*ism rabbānī*), we therefore consider the address of the Lawgiver in the esoteric sense (*bāṭin*) according to the ruling of what is in the exoteric sense (*ẓāhir*), step by step. For the exoteric is its sensory form, and the Divine, intelligible spirit in that form is what we call the consideration (*i‘tibār*) in the esoteric sense, derived from the phrase "I crossed (*‘abartu*) the valley" when I traversed it. This is His saying the Exalted: <<إِنَّ فِي ذَلِكَ لَعِبْرَةً لِأُولِي الْأَبْصَارِ>> (Indeed, in that is a lesson (*‘ibra*) for those who have insight). And He said: <<فَاعْتَبِرُوا يَا أُولِي الْأَبْصَارِ>> (So take a lesson (*fa‘tabirū*), O people of insight)—meaning, cross over from the forms you see with your physical eyes to the meanings and spirits that those forms yield in your inner selves (*bawāṭin*), so that you may perceive them with your inner sight (*baṣā’ir*). He commanded and urged contemplation (*i‘tibār*).

### The Rigid Scholars Stopped Only at the Exoteric

This is a door neglected by scholars, especially those rigid upon the exoteric (*ẓāhir*). They have no contemplation (*i‘tibār*) except astonishment. There is no difference between their intellects and the intellects of children and infants. These people have never crossed over from that apparent form as Allah commanded them. May Allah grant us correctness in speech and in reporting what we have witnessed and known from the Real (*al-Haqq*)—knowledge of unveiling (*kashf*), witnessing (*shuhūd*), and direct experience (*dhawq*). For the expression (*‘ibāra*) of that is an opening from Allah that comes according to the rule of correspondence (*muṭābaqa*). How many a person is unable to express what is within his soul, and how many a person's expression corrupts the soundness of what is within his soul. Allah is the Granter of success; there is no Lord but Him.

### The Share of *Zakat* from the Divine Names

Know that since the meaning of *Zakat* is purification (*taṭhīr*), as Allah the Exalted said: <<تُطَهِّرُهُمْ وَتُزَكِّيهِمْ بِهَا>> (You purify them and cause them to grow thereby), its share of the Divine Names (*al-Asmā’ al-Ilāhiyya*) is the Name *al-Quddūs* (The Holy/The Pure), and what is synonymous with it among the Divine Names. Since the wealth given out in charity is not part of the wealth of the one addressed by *Zakat*, but is a trust (*amāna*) in his hand for its rightful owners, no one else deserves it, even if it is with this other person. It is with him by way of trust until he renders it to its owners. Likewise, in the *Zakat* of souls (*nufūs*), the souls have attributes that they deserve, which are every attribute deserved by the possible (*mumkin*). A human may also be described by attributes that the possible does not deserve, insofar as it is possible, but which Allah deserves when described by them, in order to distinguish them from His attributes that He deserves. Similarly, the Real (*al-Haqq*) the Glorified described Himself with what is the right of the possible, as a condescension (*tanazzul*) from Him the Glorified and a mercy to His servants.

### The *Zakat* of the Soul is the Extraction of Allah's Right from It

The *Zakat* of your soul (*nafs*) is the extraction of Allah's right (*ḥaqq*) from it. This is its purification (*taṭhīr*) through that extraction from the attributes that are not truly its right. Thus, you take what is yours from it and give what is His from you, even though, as Allah the Exalted said, <<بَلْ لِلَّهِ الْأَمْرُ جَمِيعاً>> (Rather, to Allah belongs the command entirely), which is the correct view. Our relation to Him is like the relation of the attributes to Him, according to the Ash‘arites. Everything other than Allah belongs to Allah, by Allah, since nothing deserves to belong to it except what originates from it. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "The client (*mawlā*) of a people is one of them." This is a subtle indication, for it is a phrase that implies the utmost connection (*wuṣla*), to the point that it is said only that "it is He," and it implies the utmost distance, to the point that it is not said that "it is He." For what is from you is not attributed to you, since a thing is not attributed to itself due to the lack of distinction (*mughāyara*). This is the utmost connection. And what is attributed to you is not from you. This is the utmost distance, because it establishes distinction between you and it. This attribution in this matter is like the hand of man being from man, or the life of man being from man. For the animality (*ḥayawāniyya*) is from the essence of man, and animality is attributed to him despite being from the very essence of his self, and his essence is not sound without it.

### The Relation of the Possibles to the Necessary in Essence

By contemplating this correspondence, you will understand what we alluded to regarding the relation of the possibles (*mumkināt*) to the Necessary of Existence (*wājib al-wujūd*) in Himself. For possibility (*imkān*) is necessary for the possible in itself, and this reality continues to be drawn upon it because it is its essence (*‘ayn*), and it is attributed to it. Sometimes, what is its very essence is attributed to it. This is the meaning of His saying: <<لِلَّهِ الْأَمْرُ جَمِيعاً>> (To Allah belongs the command entirely)—meaning, whatever you are described with and whatever the Real (*al-Haqq*) is described with, it all belongs to Allah. Why do you not understand what belongs to you in His saying, "Give me what is yours"? This is a negation in the sense of indication (*ishāra*) and a name in the sense of signification (*dalāla*)—meaning, that which is yours, and its origin is from the name of ownership (*māliyya*). For this reason, He said: "Take from their wealth (*amwālihim*)"—meaning, the wealth *in* their wealth that is not theirs, but is a charity (*ṣadaqa*) from Me upon those I mentioned in My Book. Allah says: Do you not see that He said, "Indeed, Allah has obligated upon us *Zakat* or *Sadaqa* *in* our wealth"? He made their wealth a container (*ẓarf*) for the charity, and the container is not the essence of what is contained (*maẓrūf*). Thus, the wealth of the charity is not the essence of your wealth; rather, your wealth is a container for it. So, the Real (*al-Haqq*) did not request from you what is yours.

### The *Zakat* of Souls is More Emphatic than the *Zakat* of Wealth

The *Zakat* on souls (*nufūs*) is more emphatic than that on wealth. For this reason, Allah prioritized it in the purchase, saying: <<إِنَّ الله اشْتَرَى مِنَ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ أَنْفُسَهُمْ>> (Indeed, Allah has purchased from the believers their souls), and then said: <<وَأَمْوَالَهُمْ>> (and their wealth). The servant spends his soul and his wealth in the way of Allah. We shall mention more of this in this chapter, if Allah wills.

(Continuation: Concerning the Obligation of *Zakat*)

*Zakat* is obligatory by the Book, the Sunnah, and consensus (*ijmā‘*). There is no disagreement on this.

### The *Zakat* of Existence is Returning What Belongs to Allah to Allah

Everything other than Allah has agreed that the Existence (*wujūd*) of everything other than Allah is only by Allah. They have returned their Existence to Him, the Glorified, due to this consensus. There is no disagreement on this among everything other than Allah. This is the consideration (*i‘tibār*) of consensus regarding the *Zakat* of Existence (*wujūd*). Thus, we have returned what belongs to Allah to Allah. There is no existent (*mawjūd*) except Allah. As for the Book, <<كُلُّ شَيْءٍ هَالِكٌ إِلَّا وَجْهَهُ>> (Everything will perish except His Face). And the Face (*Wajh*) is nothing but Existence (*Wujūd*), which is the manifestation of the essences (*dhawāt*) and the fixed entities (*al-a‘yān*). As for the Sunnah, "There is no power nor strength except with Allah." This is the consideration of the rational and legal obligation of *Zakat*.

(Continuation: Mentioning Upon Whom *Zakat* is Obligatory)

Scholars have agreed that it is obligatory upon every Muslim, free, adult, sane person who possesses the minimum threshold (*niṣāb*) with complete ownership (*milk tāmm*). This is the point of agreement. They differed regarding its obligation upon the orphan, the insane, the slave, the People of the Covenant (*Ahl al-Dhimma*), and those with incomplete ownership, such as one who is in debt or one who is owed a debt, and such as endowed property (*māl al-muḥabbas al-aṣl*).

### (Continuation) The Consideration of What They Agreed Upon

The consideration of what they agreed upon: The Muslim (*Muslim*) is the one who submits to what is desired of him. We have mentioned that everything other than Allah has submitted in returning its Existence (*wujūd*) to Allah, and that it only acquired Existence from Allah, and its Subsistence (*baqā’*) in Existence is only by Allah. As for freedom (*ḥurriyya*), it is similar, for whoever is in this state is free—meaning, no one among Allah's creation has ownership over his Existence. As for adulthood (*bulūgh*), its consideration is his realization of the distinction between what his Lord the Mighty and Majestic deserves and what He does not deserve. When he knows such a thing, he has reached the limit where he must return all matters to Allah the Exalted, which is the *Zakat* obligatory upon him. As for sanity (*‘aql*), it is that he comprehends from Allah what Allah desires of him in His address to him in his soul (*nafs*) through inspiration (*ilhām*) or through the tongue of His Messenger (peace and blessings be upon him). Whoever restricts his Existence by the Existence of his Creator has comprehended his soul, since *‘aql* (intellect) is derived from the hobble (*‘iqāl*) of the beast. In reality, the hobble of the beast is derived from the intellect, for the intellect precedes the hobble of the beast. Had he not comprehended that this rope, when tied to the beast, restricts it from wandering, he would not have named it a hobble.

### The Owner of the *Niṣāb*

As for their saying, "The owner of the minimum threshold (*niṣāb*) with complete ownership (*milk tāmm*)," his ownership of the *nisab* is the very essence of his Existence, due to what we mentioned of Islam, freedom, adulthood, and sanity. As for their saying "complete ownership," the complete (*tāmm*) is that which has no deficiency (*naqṣ*), and deficiency is a non-existent attribute. He said: "It is non-existence." Thus, the complete is Existence (*wujūd*). This is the saying of Imam Abu Hamid: "There is nothing more wondrous in possibility (*imkān*) than this world," since its origination (*ibdā‘*) is the very essence of its Existence, nothing else. That is, there is nothing more wondrous in possibility than its Existence, and it has been attained. For nothing accrues to the possible from the Real (*al-Haqq*) except Existence. This is the meaning of the consideration of their saying "complete ownership."

### (Continuation) The Consideration of What They Differed Upon

As for the consideration of what they differed upon, among that is the case of minors (*ṣighār*). Some said *Zakat* is obligatory on their wealth. Others said, "There is no charity (*ṣadaqa*) on the wealth of the orphan." Some differentiated between what the earth produces and what it does not, saying *Zakat* is due on what the earth produces, but not on livestock, currency (*nāḍ*), or trade goods (*‘urūḍ*). Others differentiated between currency and other things, saying *Zakat* is due on everything except currency specifically.

### The Orphan is One Who Has No Living Father and is Not an Adult

The consideration of what we mentioned: The orphan (*yatīm*) is one who has no living father and is not an adult—meaning he has not reached puberty by age, hair growth, or seminal emission. Allah the Exalted said: <<لَمْ يَلِدْ>> (He neither begets), and <<سُبْحَانَهُ أَنْ يَكُونَ لَهُ وَلَدٌ>> (Exalted is He above having a child). Thus, the Real (*al-Haqq*) is not a father to any of His creation, nor does any of His creation have a child for Him, Glorified and Exalted is He. Whoever considers the obligation (*taklīf*) to be inherent in the essence of the wealth says it is obligatory. Whoever considers the obligation to be inherent in the owner says it is not obligatory upon him because he is not legally responsible (*mukallaf*).

### Attributing Existence to Allah and to the Essence of the Possible

Likewise, whoever considers his Existence (*wujūd*) to be for Allah says *Zakat* is not obligatory, for there is none to accept it if it were obligatory, since there is none but Allah. And whoever considers the attribution of Existence to the essence of the possible (*mumkin*), which was previously not described by Existence, says *Zakat* is definitely obligatory, since attribution necessarily requires a comprehensible effect.

### The Division of Existents into Two Categories: Eternal and Contingent

For this reason, existents (*mawjūdāt*) are divided into two categories: Eternal (*Qadīm*) and Contingent (*Ḥādith*). The Existence (*wujūd*) of the possible is a contingent existence—meaning this attribute occurred to it. This division does not address whether Existence itself is contingent or eternal, because the contingency of a thing in our view does not imply that it had no existence before its contingency occurred to us. Based on this, we understand His saying the Exalted: <<مَا يَأْتِيهِمْ مِنْ ذِكْرٍ مِنْ رَبِّهِمْ مُحْدَثٍ>> (No fresh reminder comes to them from their Lord). This is the ancient Speech of Allah, but it is contingent *to them*, just as you say, "A guest arrived (*ḥadatha*) to us today," which does not imply that he had no existence before that. Whoever observes that contingent Existence is not the right (*ḥaqq*) of the one described by it, but is the right of someone other than the possible, says *Zakat* is obligatory upon the orphan, because it is the right of the Necessary of Existence (*wājib al-wujūd*) in what this possible is characterized by. This is similar to the view of those who hold that *Zakat* is obligatory on the orphan's wealth, seeing it as the right of the poor in the essence of that wealth, and thus the guardian, who has the authority to dispose of the wealth, extracts it.

### Establishing Obligation within the Essence of Unity

Whoever observes that *Zakat* is an act of worship (*‘ibāda*) does not make *Zakat* obligatory, because the orphan has not reached the age of legal responsibility (*taklīf*). We have alluded to this, and we have:

The Lord is Real (*Haqq*) and the servant is real (*ḥaqq*).
Oh, I wish I knew who is the one obligated (*mukallaf*)?

This is concerning the adult, and the minor is not obligated—he is the orphan. All other acts of worship follow this pattern, for a thing does not worship itself. When a Gnostic (*‘ārif*) verifies this and realizes that there is none but Allah, he fears the error that befalls those without gnosis (*ma‘rifa*) who are condemned by the Lawgiver for claiming the nullification of deeds. We seek refuge in Allah from failure. The Gnostic then looks at the Divine Names (*al-Asmā’ al-Ilāhiyya*) and the dependence of the rulings of some upon others, and their degrees of relation, as we have mentioned in various places. He thus makes acts of worship obligatory from that perspective and through that observation, so that the action may manifest in that locus from that Divine Name that subsists by it, when addressed by a Divine Name that holds the ruling of the state and the time. It becomes incumbent upon this other Divine Name that this locus moves in response to what was requested of it. This is called worship (*‘ibāda*), and it is the furthest point one can reach in establishing obligations within the very essence of Unity (*Tawḥīd*), such that the Commander is the commanded, and the Speaker is the listener.

### The Consideration of Those Who Differentiated Between What the Earth Produces and What It Does Not

As for the consideration of those who differentiated between what the earth produces and what it does not, their consideration is based on what purifies the one described by Existence (*wujūd*), who is the possible among things, through his hands, which are the cause of their manifestation. If he attributes the existence of that thing to the one to whom he attributes his own existence, he says there is no *Zakat*. If he does not attribute it and considers its manifestation to be from himself, he says it is obligatory.

### Those Who Differentiated Between Currency and Other Things

As for those who differentiated between currency (*nāḍ*) and other things, since currency possesses the attribute of perfection or resemblance to perfection, and everything other than currency falls short of the degree of perfection or resemblance to perfection and is characterized by deficiency (*naqṣ*), they made *Zakat* obligatory on the deficient to purify it from deficiency, and did not make it obligatory on the perfect, for perfection cannot exist in anything else, as there is no perfection except in Unity (*Waḥda*).

### The People of the Covenant and the Christians of Taghlib

Among these are the People of the Covenant (*Ahl al-Dhimma*). The majority holds that there is no *Zakat* upon a *Dhimmi* (non-Muslim subject), except for one group that narrated the doubling of *Zakat* upon the Christians of Banu Taghlib—that is, taking from them what is taken from Muslims in everything. A group adopted this view and narrated it from the action of Umar with them, as if they saw such a matter as a specific injunction (*tawqīf*), even though the general principles contradict it.

### It is Not Permissible to Take *Zakat* from a Disbeliever

The view I adhere to is that it is not permissible to take *Zakat* from a disbeliever (*kāfir*), even though it is obligatory upon him along with all other obligations, except that nothing he is obligated to perform is accepted from him until he attains faith (*īmān*). If he is one of the People of the Book, there is a consideration for us. The taking of the poll tax (*Jizya*) from them may be an affirmation by the Lawgiver of the religion they follow, so it is legislated for them, and they must uphold their religion. If their religion includes the payment of *Zakat* and they bring it, it is accepted from them, and Allah knows best. We are not required to demand *Zakat* from the polytheist (*mushrik*), but if he brings it, we accept it. Allah the Exalted says: <<وَوَيْلٌ لِلْمُشْرِكِينَ الَّذِينَ لا يُؤْتُونَ الزَّكَاةَ>> (And woe to the polytheists, those who do not give the *Zakat*). And Allah the Exalted says: <<قُلْ لِلَّذِينَ كَفَرُوا إِنْ يَنْتَهُوا يُغْفَرْ لَهُمْ مَا قَدْ سَلَفَ>> (Say to those who disbelieve, if they cease, what has passed will be forgiven for them). The disbeliever (*kāfir*) here is the polytheist, not the monotheist.

### (Continuation) The Consideration in the *Zakat* of the People of the Covenant

The consideration: Allah the Exalted said: <<لا يَرْقُبُونَ فِي مُؤْمِنٍ إِلًّا وَلا ذِمَّةً>> (They observe not concerning a believer any kinship (*ill*) or covenant (*dhimma*)). *Ill* is a Name of Allah, and *Dhimma* is the covenant and contract. If it is a prescribed covenant, then fulfilling it is its *Zakat*. Thus, *Zakat* is upon the People of the Covenant (*Ahl al-Dhimma*), for they must fulfill what they have covenanted. Whoever drops *Zakat* from them means that the *Dhimmi*, when he enters into a contract, equates two things in the contract, and whoever equates two things makes them similar. Yet Allah the Exalted said: <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him). Therefore, the Unity (*Tawḥīd*) of a polytheist is not accepted, even though the polytheist affirms the Unity of Allah in His greatness, based on his saying: <<مَا نَعْبُدُهُمْ إِلَّا لِيُقَرِّبُونَا إِلَى الله زُلْفَى>> (We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to Allah in proximity). This is undoubtedly *Tawhid*, yet the Lawgiver forbade its acceptance.

### The Proof of Unity is Unity Itself

Know that the proof (*dalīl*) contradicts the proven (*madlūl*), and Unity (*Tawḥīd*) is the proven, while the proof is distinct. Thus, there is no Unity. Whoever makes the proof of Unity to be Unity itself, there is no one upon whom *Zakat* is obligatory. Thus, there is no *Zakat* upon the *Dhimmi*. *Zakat* is purification (*ṭahāra*), so faith (*īmān*) is necessary, for faith is the purification of the inner self (*bāṭin*). The faith considered by us is only that a thing is affirmed based on the saying of the Informer, according to what he informed, or that an action is performed based on the saying of the Informer, not based on the essence of rational proof (*dalīl al-‘aqlī*).

### The Pervasion of Unity in Things

The science of polytheism (*shirk*) is one of the most difficult subjects to examine due to the pervasion of Unity (*Tawḥīd*) in things, since partnership (*ishtirāk*) is absolutely impossible in action. Everyone who has a specific level (*martaba khāṣṣa*) cannot possibly have a partner in it, and there is none except one who has a specific level. However, the polytheism considered in the Law (*Shar‘*) exists, and accountability (*mu’ākhadha*) occurs because of it.

(Completing Continuation)

Know that disbelievers (*kuffār*) are addressed by the foundation of the Law (*Sharī‘a*), which is faith (*īmān*) in everything the Messenger brought from Allah, including reports, fundamental rulings (*uṣūl al-aḥkām*), and their branches (*furū‘*). This is His saying (peace and blessings be upon him): "And that you believe in me and in what I have brought." This includes acting according to what the address requires, whether action or omission. Belief that voluntary charity (*ṣadaqat al-taṭawwu‘*) is voluntary is obligatory, and this is from the fundamentals of the Law. Giving voluntary charity is a branch. There is no difference between it and obligatory charity in the belief in it and in its payment. Even if they are not equal in reward, that does not undermine the fundamental principle. If they differ in one aspect, they are united in the stronger aspect.

### Faith is the Root and Action is the Branch

Faith (*īmān*) is the root (*aṣl*), and action (*‘amal*) is undoubtedly a branch of this root. For this reason, no act of disobedience (*ma‘ṣiya*) is purely isolated for the believer without being mixed with obedience. The one who mixes is the disobedient believer. When the believer disobeys in a matter, he is a believer that this is disobedience, and faith is obligatory, so he has performed an obligation. Thus, the believer is rewarded in the very essence of his disobedience, and faith is stronger.

### *Zakat* Does Not Suffice for the People of the Covenant

There is no *Zakat* upon the People of the Covenant (*Ahl al-Dhimma*) in the sense that it does not suffice for them if they pay it, despite it being obligatory upon them like all other prescribed duties of the Law, due to the absence of the condition that validates it, which is faith (*īmān*) in everything the Law brought, not just in *Zakat* or in some of what the Law brought. If he believed in *Zakat* alone, or in some of the obligatory duties as obligatory, or in some of the supererogatory acts as supererogatory, yet abandoned belief in a single matter, whether obligatory or supererogatory, his faith would not be accepted unless he believed in all of it. Despite this, we are not to ask a *Dhimmi* for his *Zakat*. If he brings it of his own accord, we are not to reject it, because he brought it to us without being asked. The ruler (*sulṭān*) takes it from him for the treasury of the Muslims (*bayt māl al-muslimīn*); he does not take it as *Zakat*, nor does he reject it. If he rejects it, he has disobeyed the command of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him).

### The *Zakat* of the Slave's Wealth

As for the slave (*‘abd*), people hold three doctrines concerning him. One group says there is no *Zakat* on his wealth at all because he does not possess complete ownership (*milk tāmm*), since the master has the right to seize it. Nor does the master possess complete ownership, because the slave's hand is the one disposing of it. Therefore, there is no *Zakat* on the slave's wealth. Another group holds that the *Zakat* on the slave's wealth is upon his master, because the master has the right to seize it from him. A third group holds that *Zakat* is upon the slave in his wealth, because the hand's control over the wealth necessitates *Zakat* upon it due to its disposal, likening it to the disposal of a free person. Our Shaykh and the majority of those who say there is no *Zakat* on the slave's wealth also hold that there is no *Zakat* on the wealth of the *mukātab* (slave contracted to buy his freedom) until he is freed. Abu Thawr said *Zakat* is due on the wealth of the *mukātab*. What I hold is that the matter must either be viewed as *Zakat* being a right (*ḥaqq*) inherent in the wealth, without regard for the owner, in which case the ruler must take it from all wealth that meets the conditions of the *nisab* and the passing of the year, from whoever holds it. Or, it must be viewed that the obligation of *Zakat* is upon the owners of the wealth, which leads to the doctrines we mentioned. The first view is that whoever is the disposer of the wealth is the one addressed with extracting the *Zakat* from it.

The Consideration of That

The slave and what he owns belong to his master. Whatever his master commands him, obedience is obligatory upon him. *Zakat* is a right (*ḥaqq*) that Allah made obligatory in the essence of the wealth for specific categories, and it is in the hands of the believers. No wealth is without an owner—meaning, a hand that has the authority to dispose of it. *Zakat* is a trust (*amāna*) in the hand of whoever holds the wealth for these categories. It is not the wealth of the free person nor the slave. Therefore, it is obligatory to render it to its rightful owners from whoever holds it and has the authority to dispose of it, whether free or slave, among the believers. All are servants of Allah. Thus, there is no *Zakat* upon the slave because he is rendering a trust. *Zakat* is upon him in the sense of delivering this right to its owners, for <<إِنَّ الله يَأْمُرُكُمْ أَنْ تُؤَدُّوا الْأَمَانَاتِ إِلَى أَهْلِهَا>> (Indeed, Allah commands you to render trusts to their rightful owners). And it is the purification of the wealth that contains the *Zakat* by means of the *Zakat*—meaning, by extracting it from it. *Zakat* is upon the master because he owns it from the perspective of what the Real (*al-Haqq*) made obligatory upon Himself for His creation, such as His saying: <<كَتَبَ رَبُّكُمْ عَلَى نَفْسِهِ الرَّحْمَةَ>> (Your Lord has prescribed mercy upon Himself), and His saying: <<فَسَأَكْتُبُهَا>> (I will prescribe it), and His saying: <<وَكَانَ حَقًّا عَلَيْنَا نَصْرُ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ>> (And incumbent upon Us was support of the believers), and His saying: <<أُوفِ بِعَهْدِكُمْ>> (I will fulfill My covenant with you). Everyone who saw a principle among those mentioned adopted a doctrine regarding the slave's wealth.

(Continuation) Among These Are Owners Who Have Debts

Among these are the owners who have debts that consume their wealth and consume the portion of their wealth upon which *Zakat* is obligatory, yet they possess wealth upon which *Zakat* is due.

### Sayings of the Scholars Regarding Debt Wealth

One group says there is no *Zakat* on wealth, whether grain or otherwise, until the debt is subtracted from it. If what remains meets the *Zakat* threshold, *Zakat* is paid; otherwise, not. Another group says that debt does not prevent the *Zakat* on grains, but prevents it on everything else. A third group says debt prevents *Zakat* only on currency (*nāḍ*), unless he has trade goods that cover his debt, in which case it does not prevent it. Some say debt does not prevent *Zakat* at all.

The Consideration of That

Zakat is an act of worship (*‘ibāda*); thus, it is a right of Allah, and the right of Allah is more deserving of fulfillment. The text (of the Sunnah) came down from the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) confirming this. Allah has made Zakat a right for those categories mentioned in the Glorious Qur’an, <<الذي لا يَأْتِيهِ الْباطِلُ من بَيْنِ يَدَيْهِ ولا من خَلْفِهِ تَنْزِيلٌ من حَكِيمٍ حَمِيدٍ>> (in which falsehood cannot come from before it or behind it; a revelation from One Wise and Praiseworthy). Debt (*al-Dīn*) is an established and preceding right, so debt is more deserving of fulfillment than Zakat.

(Section)
Among that is the wealth that is owed by another person, not being in the possession of the owner, which is debt (*al-Dīn*). Some say there is no Zakat due on it, even if it is collected, until a full year (*ḥawl*) passes while it is in the hands of the collector—and this is the view I hold. Others say that when he collects it, he must pay Zakat for the years that have passed. Some said he pays Zakat for one year only, even if it remained with the debtor for years, provided its origin was compensation (e.g., sale). If it was not based on compensation, such as inheritance (*al-Mīrāth*), then he starts a new year (*yastaqbil bihi al-ḥawl*).

(The Esoteric Consideration in that)
There is no owner except Allah. And he whom Allah has granted ownership, if what he owns is in his hand such that he can dispose of it, then Zakat becomes obligatory upon him, subject to its conditions. No consideration is given to the time that has passed, for the human being is the child of his moment (*ibn waqtihi*), not of the time that has passed, nor of the time he will face in the future. Although he may intend for the future and wish for the past, all of this occurs in the time of the present moment (*zamān al-ḥāl*); thus, it belongs to the moment, not to the past or the future.

[No Consideration is Given to the Time that Passed Over the Wealth]
Therefore, no consideration is given to the time that passed over that wealth while it was in the hands of the debtor. For he (the owner) is always in a state of spiritual opening (*al-Futūḥ*) with Allah the Exalted. The One in whose hand the wealth truly rests is Allah, so Zakat is obligatory upon it for the years that have passed over it.

The Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) said: "Perform Hajj on behalf of your father." And he (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) commanded the guardian of the deceased concerning the Ramadan fasts owed by the deceased.

This is nothing but the delivery of the fruit of the action to the one on whose behalf Hajj or fasting was performed, concerning what was obligatory upon him, unless he was negligent, in which case there is a different ruling.

[Whoever Performed Hajj or Any Action on Behalf of Another]
Nevertheless, whoever performs Hajj on behalf of another, or performs any action on his behalf, that action is a charity (*ṣadaqa*) from the doer to the one on whose behalf it was done, whether the latter is deceased or not. However, the living person is not relieved of his obligation unless he is unable to perform it. If his guardian performs it on his behalf, the guardian receives the reward of one who fulfilled his obligation. This applies only to Hajj, as we mentioned. The reward (*al-Thawāb*) is not received by the recipient unless the one on whose behalf the action was done is deceased, in which case the reward is otherworldly (*ukhrāwī*). If he is alive, the one who receives it on his behalf is the Agent (*al-Wakīl*), who is Allah. When Allah receives it, He gives it in the Hereafter to the one who performed the action for him here in the world.

(Section: From the Consideration of this Chapter)
And from the consideration of this chapter is the person who wishes he had wealth so he could perform an act of righteousness (*birr*). Allah records for him the reward of one who acted, for his intention (*niyya*) is better than his action. It is recorded for him with the fullest share, even though the wealth is owed by another and he possesses none of it. If he then obtains the wealth he wished for, or whatever he wished for that enables him to perform that act of righteousness, he is obligated to perform the act of righteousness he intended. If he does not do so, the reward for what he intended is not recorded for him. But if he dies before acquiring what he wished for, the reward for what he intended is recorded for him. Allah the Exalted said: <<أَنَّما أَمْوالُكُمْ وأَوْلادُكُمْ فِتْنَةٌ>> (Indeed, your wealth and your children are a trial). That is, they are a test for establishing the proof regarding the truthfulness or falsehood of the claim (of intention).

(Section)
And from this chapter is their disagreement concerning the Zakat on fruits whose origins (*uṣūl*) are endowed (waqf/ḥabs). Some say Zakat is due on them, and others say no Zakat is due. Some differentiated between whether the endowment is for the poor (*masākīn*), in which case no Zakat is due, and whether it is established for specific individuals, in which case Zakat is obligatory. I hold the view that Zakat is obligatory, regardless of whether the endowment is for specific individuals or not. If it is for specific individuals, they must pay the Zakat. If it is not for specific individuals, the ruler (*al-Sulṭān*) must take the Zakat from it by virtue of agency (*al-Wakāla*).

The Esoteric Consideration in that
The fruit (*al-Thamar*) is the action (*‘amal*) of the responsible human being (*al-Mukallaf*). The action may be purely for Allah, like prayer (*ṣalāh*) and fasting (*ṣiyām*) and their likes, or it may contain a right for others, like Zakat. However, it is legislated, such as when a person performs an action and says, "This is for Allah and for your sakes," then it is for their sakes, or (he says) "I have none but Allah and you."

The Prophet (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) said: "Whoever says, 'This is for Allah and for your sakes,' nothing of it is for Allah."

Then it was legislated for the one who says this to say, "This is for Allah, *then* for so-and-so," without including the conjunction *wāw* (of partnership). This action contains a portion for Allah, which is analogous to the Zakat in the endowed wealth (*al-Māl al-Muḥabbas al-Aṣl*), and it contains a portion for creation, which is his saying, "then for so-and-so," using the particle *thumma* (then) and not the particle *wāw* (and). This is what remains in the hand of the beneficiary of this fruit, exceeding the Zakat amount.

[Zakat is the Right of Allah and the Right of the Poor]
This is the consideration of those who see Zakat due on it, and those who see no Zakat due on it—meaning, no right of Allah in it. The consideration of the latter group is based on the Prophet’s saying (may Allah bless him and grant him peace): "It is for your sakes; nothing of it is for Allah," meaning Allah has no right in it. And he who holds that Zakat is the right of the poor sees in his consideration that the Zakat of the fruit of the endowed origin—which is the action of this servant who is perpetually dedicated to his Master and never freed—means that the action is for Allah by virtue of the endowment. And the wide-eyed maidens (*al-Ḥūr al-‘Īn*) and their likes have a share of that action, which is expressed as Zakat, as some have said concerning the Mujahidin (those who strive):

> The gates of Eden are opened wide,
> And the Ḥūr look out from them.
> So race forward, what a race!
> And hasten, O warriors!
> Before you are Gardens,
> In them are beautiful, blissful women.
> They say, while the horses are racing,
> "Our dowries are patience (*al-Ṣabr*) and steadfastness (*al-Thabāt*)."

[Patience and Steadfastness are the Zakat of Jihad]
Thus, patience and steadfastness from the act of striving (*al-Jihād*) are in the position of Zakat from the fruit. And the fact that its origin is endowed is His saying, the Exalted: <<وما خَلَقْتُ الْجِنَّ والْإِنْسَ إِلَّا لِيَعْبُدُونِ>> (And I did not create the jinn and mankind except that they should worship Me). He created them only for His worship, so they are perpetually dedicated (*Mawqūfūn*) to Him. Then He placed in their actions, which are like the fruit of the tree, a share for Allah, which is sincerity (*al-Ikhlāṣ*) in the action, and this is part of the action itself. And a right for the doer, which is the reward (*al-Thawāb*) he obtains from it, and this is in the position of the Zakat that the reward seeks. This is the consideration of the Zakat on the fruit of the endowed origin, according to their differences. And Allah is the Guide.

(Section)
And from this chapter is the question of upon whom the Zakat is obligatory for what the rented land produces. Some scholars said that Zakat is due upon the owner of the crop, and others said that Zakat is only obligatory upon the owner of the land, and nothing is due upon the tenant. I hold the first view, that Zakat is due upon the owner of the crop.

(Section) The Esoteric Consideration in that
The Imam, the Mu’adhdhin, the Mujahid, the collector of charity (*al-‘Āmil ‘alā al-Ṣadaqa*), and everyone who takes a wage for his work from the one who hires him for it (are analogous). The rented land is the soul (*Nafs*) of the responsible human being (*al-Mukallaf*), and what it produces is the action that manifests from this soul. The Sower is The Real (al-Ḥaqq), the Exalted. He says: <<أَ أَنْتُمْ تَزْرَعُونَهُ أَمْ نَحْنُ الزَّارِعُونَ>> (Is it you who sow it, or are We the Sower?). And the Lord of the land is the Lawgiver (*al-Shāri‘*), who is The Real, Glorified is He, by virtue of being the Lawgiver, just as He is the Granter of Success (*al-Muwaffiq*) in the sowing. He says, informing us about one of His prophets: <<وما تَوْفِيقِي إِلَّا بِاللَّهِ>> (And my success is not but through Allah).

[Allah Sows the Seed of Guidance in the Land of the Souls]
Glorified is He, He sows the seed of guidance (*al-Hudā*) and success (*al-Tawfīq*) in the land of the souls (*arḍ al-Nufūs*). Then the land of the souls produces according to what was sown in it. And in what manifests from this land, there is a right for Allah, and there is a right for the human being. That which is for Allah is expressed as Zakat, and what remains is for the human being. And renting (*al-Ijāra*) is legislated, for Allah bought our souls from us, then rented them back to us for tenfold. He said: <<من جاءَ بِالْحَسَنَةِ فَلَهُ عَشْرُ أَمْثالِها>> (Whoever comes with a good deed will have ten times its like). The good deed (*al-Ḥasana*) from us is the tenfold amount that we give to Him, Glorified is He, from what He sowed in the lands of our souls, which is the goodness that produced this righteous action.

[Allah is the Lord of the Land, the Sower, the Lessor, and the Lessee]
Glorified is He, He is the Lord of the land, the Sower, the Lessor, the Lessee, the One upon whom Zakat is obligatory, and the One who takes the charities (*al-Ṣadaqāt*), as He said: <<هُوَ يَقْبَلُ التَّوْبَةَ عَنْ عِبادِهِ ويَأْخُذُ الصَّدَقاتِ>> (It is He who accepts repentance from His servants and takes the charities). But this is through different aspects and relations. He is the Giver and the Taker. There is no god but He, and no doer other than Him. Thus, He makes things obligatory by virtue of being such-and-such, and things become obligatory upon Him by virtue of being such-and-such. He the Exalted said: <<كَتَبَ رَبُّكُمْ عَلى‏ نَفْسِهِ الرَّحْمَةَ>> (Your Lord has decreed upon Himself mercy). That is, He made it obligatory and decreed it. No obligator made it obligatory upon Him; rather, He, Glorified is He, is the One who made it obligatory upon Himself, as a favor and grace upon us. The realities of His Names (*Asmā’*) are how He makes Himself known to us, and upon the realities of these Names all the Divine Laws (*Sharā’i‘*) are established. <<قُلْ كُلٌّ من عِنْدِ الله فَما لِهؤُلاءِ الْقَوْمِ لا يَكادُونَ يَفْقَهُونَ حَدِيثاً>> (Say: "All is from Allah." So what is wrong with these people that they hardly understand any statement?).

[The Good Deed is from Allah and the Evil Deed is from Yourself]
And He divided, saying in the sequence of this discourse: <<ما أَصابَكَ من حَسَنَةٍ فَمِنَ الله وما أَصابَكَ من سَيِّئَةٍ فَمِنْ نَفْسِكَ>> (Whatever good befalls you is from Allah, and whatever evil befalls you is from yourself). This evil (*sayyi’a*) is that which harms you. You are the locus of the effect of the evil. But insofar as it is an act that is not characterized by evil, it belongs to the Divine Name (*al-Ism al-Ilāhī*) that brought it into existence, for the creation of such an act is good on His part. Thus, it is not evil except for the one who finds it evil or the one whom it harms, which is the human soul (*Nafs*), since pain is only felt by the one in whom it exists. In the soul, its ruling manifests, not in the One who brings it into existence, for the ruling does not apply to its Doer. This is the meaning of His saying: <<وما أَصابَكَ من سَيِّئَةٍ فَمِنْ نَفْسِكَ>> (And whatever evil befalls you is from yourself). Although the good deed (*al-Ḥasana*) is likewise (created by Allah), it is considered good by the human being, and it is also good from the side of The Real (al-Ḥaqq) who brought it into existence. So the good deed is attributed to Allah because He is the originator of it initially. Although it is also good in you after its origination, it is not called a good deed unless it is legislated (*mashrū‘a*), and it is not legislated except from Allah, so it is attributed only to Allah.

[The Evil Deed from The Real is a Good Deed]
For this reason, we said concerning the evil deed (*al-Sayyi’a*) that it is good from the perspective of The Real (al-Ḥaqq), because He clarified it so that it may be avoided. Thus, it is evil for the one who commits it, either in this world or the Hereafter. Abandonment (*al-Tark*) may be an evil deed, even though it is not an action (*fi‘l*), and action may be an evil deed. Likewise, the good deed may be an action or an abandonment. And Divine Success (*al-Tawfīq al-Ilāhī*) is the effective cause in action and abandonment, both insofar as it is an abandonment of something, and insofar as it manifests from him if it is an action.

[The Obligatory Right Upon the Servant in Action and Abandonment]
There is no obligatory right (*ḥaqq wājib*) upon the servant, whether in abandonment or action, except that Allah has a right in it, which the ruler (*al-Ḥākim*) fulfills as a deputy (*niyāba*) for Allah. If what remains of that action or abandonment is a right of Allah the Exalted, then it is a right of Allah in all its aspects, with no right for a creature in it, such as prayer (*al-Ṣalāh*) and the establishment of legal penalties (*al-Ḥudūd*). If what remains of that action or abandonment is a right of a creature, such as striking, insulting, or usurping wealth, then there is a right for Allah in it—which is what we mentioned—and a right for the creature. And the right of Allah in it is the very essence of Zakat, which is present in all of Allah’s acts concerning His creation. The ruler is His deputy in what He has made him successor over. If he wills, he takes it (the right), and if he wills, he leaves it, according to what the situation and the public interest (*al-Maṣlaḥa*) dictate, and there is no blame upon him for that. This is called discretionary punishment (*Ta‘zīr*) in cases where no fixed penalty (*ḥadd*) applies. Thus, the hand of the thief must be cut off, even if the wealth is taken from his hand and returned to its owner. The ruler is given a choice: if he wills, he may impose the discretionary punishment (*‘azzarahu*) for that portion of the legislated right that belongs to Allah; and if he wills, he may not impose the discretionary punishment and leave that to Allah, so that He may take charge of it in the Hereafter without intermediary.

(Section)
And from this chapter is the land of tribute (*Khirāj*) when it transfers to Muslims—that is, the land that was in the hands of the People of the Covenant (*Ahl al-Dhimma*). Is the tithe (*‘Ushr*) due on it along with the *Khirāj*, or not? Some say the tithe (meaning Zakat) is due on it, and others say no tithe is due. Know that Zakat is either the right of the land or the right of the seed/crop. If it is the right of the land, Zakat is not obligatory, because two rights—the tithe and the *Khirāj*—cannot be combined on it. If it is the right of the seed/crop, then the *Khirāj* is the right of the land, and the tithe is the right of the seed/crop. The disagreement regarding the sale of *Khirāj* land is known among the scholars.

(Section) The Esoteric Consideration in that
Bodily actions (*al-A‘māl al-Badaniyya*) are in the position of the crop, and the body (*al-Badan*) is in the position of the land. And the lower self/desire (*al-Hawā*) is the ruler over the land. When this land transfers to the rule of the Law (*al-Shar‘*)—which is acting according to the requirements of Islam—the *Khirāj* of the land is the rights due to Allah upon it, by virtue of His making it possess perceptions (*idrākāt*), which is knowledge that the intellect (*al-‘Aql*) perceives independently. Thus, Allah has the *Khirāj* in this land, since thanking the Benefactor is praiseworthy, and He, Glorified is He, is the Benefactor of it.

[Muslims are of Two Types: Gnostic and Non-Gnostic]
When this land comes into the hand of the Muslim—meaning the Law (*al-Shar‘*)—and transfers to him, Muslims are of two types: the Gnostic (*‘Ārif*) and the non-Gnostic. When the Gnostic sows righteous actions in this land, he sees that Zakat is the right of the action, not the right of the land. So he makes Zakat obligatory in the action, which is to return the actions to their Doer, who is The Real, Glorified is He. The non-Gnostic sees that the action belongs to the bodily powers, and *Khirāj* is already obligatory upon them, so Zakat is not obligatory according to him, lest two rights be combined upon it. This is because he sees the action as belonging only to himself, for he is not a Gnostic. And Allah does not burden a soul except with what He has given it. And He said: <<ذلِكَ مَبْلَغُهُمْ من الْعِلْمِ>> (That is the extent of their knowledge).

[It is Not Far-Fetched for Two Rights to be Combined on the Land]
As for our view on this matter, two rights may be combined on the land, and this is not far-fetched. Because the land, by virtue of being in the hand of its possessor, prevents others from disposing of it except with his permission, so there is a right upon him in it called *Khirāj*. And by virtue of his sowing it, the state of the land differs from its state before being sown. Thus, another right becomes obligatory in it by virtue of its having a crop. The tithe (*al-‘Ushr*) becomes obligatory in it by virtue of its being sown, and the *Khirāj* becomes obligatory in it by virtue of its being in his hand and under his rule. This is how we take it in the esoteric consideration (*al-I‘tibār*).

(Section)
As for tithe land (*arḍ al-‘Ushr*) when it transfers to a *Dhimmi* (non-Muslim subject) and he sows it, some say nothing is due on it—meaning neither *Khirāj* nor *‘Ushr*. Al-Nu‘man said that if a *Dhimmi* buys tithe land, it transforms into *Khirāj* land. It is as if he saw that the tithe is the right of Muslim land, and *Khirāj* is the right of *Dhimmi* land. And whoever holds this view should logically conclude that if *Dhimmi* land transfers to a Muslim, it should revert to tithe land.

(The Esoteric Consideration of that)
The intellect (*al-‘Aql*) has a ruling over the soul (*al-Nafs*) by virtue of its essence and contemplation, and the Law (*al-Shar‘*) has a ruling over the soul. If the intellect strips the soul from the hand of the Law through a specious argument (*shubha*) by which it bought it, will Allah accept every action whose form the Law praises, but whose performance was from the side of the intellect, not the side of the Law? Some of us say it is accepted, and he is rewarded for it in this world if he was not a monotheist but an idolater (*mushrik*). If he was a monotheist (*muwaḥḥid*), it is accepted from him, and he is rewarded with the reward of a non-believer (in terms of worldly good).

[The Believer Has Two Rewards on the Day of Resurrection for His Action]
The believer (*al-Mu’min*) has two rewards for his action on the Day of Resurrection: a reward by virtue of his being a believer acting according to the Law (*Sharī‘a*), and a reward by virtue of that action being among noble morals (*makārim al-akhlāq*) and being good (*khayr*). The Prophet (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) said to Ḥakīm ibn Ḥizām when he embraced Islam, having done good deeds in the pre-Islamic era (*Jāhiliyya*): "You embraced Islam upon the good you had previously done." So Allah rewarded him for the good that came from him during his time of *Jāhiliyya*.

[Goodness Seeks Reward for Itself]
For goodness (*al-Khayr*) seeks reward for itself. If faith (*al-Īmān*) is joined to it, the reward is multiplied due to the addition of this attribute, for it has another right. Thus, the ruling of the Law is the tithe (*al-‘Ushr*), and the ruling of the intellect is the *Khirāj*.

(Section) If Zakat is Paid and Lost
[Scholarly Views on the Loss of Zakat After Payment]
If one pays Zakat and it is lost, some say it suffices him, and others say he is responsible for it until he places it in its proper location. Some differentiated between paying it after he had the ability to pay it, and paying it at the very beginning of the time of obligation and possibility. Some said that if he paid it days after the possibility and obligation arose, he is responsible. But if he paid it at the beginning of the obligation and was not negligent (*tafrīṭ*), he is not responsible. Others said that if he was negligent, he is responsible—and this is the view I hold—but if he was not negligent, he pays Zakat on what remains. Others said that the lost amount is counted from the total, and the poor (*masākīn*) and the owner of the wealth remain partners in the remainder, according to their share of the owner’s share, like two partners whose shared wealth is partially lost, and they remain partners in the remainder according to the same ratio. Thus, there are five views on the matter: the view that he is not responsible absolutely; the view that he is responsible absolutely; the view that if he was negligent he is responsible, and if not, he is not responsible; the view that if he was negligent he is responsible, and if not, he pays Zakat on what remains; and the fifth view is that they remain partners in the remainder.

[If Some Wealth is Lost After Zakat Became Obligatory]
If some of the wealth is lost after the obligation arose, and it is said that the payment of Zakat was possible, some say he pays Zakat on what remains. Others said the situation of the poor and the situation of the owner of the wealth is like that of two partners whose wealth is partially lost. However, if Zakat became obligatory and payment was possible, but he did not pay until some of the wealth was lost, he is responsible by consensus—and Allah knows best—except concerning livestock, according to those who hold that the obligation is only completed upon the condition of the collector (*al-Sā‘ī*) coming forth, along with the passing of the year, which is the school of thought of Malik.

(Section) The Esoteric Consideration in that
The Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) said: "Do not grant wisdom (*al-Ḥikma*) to those who are unworthy of it, lest you wrong it, nor withhold it from those who are worthy of it, lest you wrong them." The expenditure of wisdom is the very essence of its Zakat, and it has worthy recipients (*Ahl*) just as Zakat has worthy recipients. If you give wisdom to one who is unworthy, believing him to be worthy, it is lost, just as this wealth was lost after being paid out and did not reach its owner. He is responsible for what was lost because he was negligent (*farraṭa*) by failing to ascertain the worthiness of the one with whom this wisdom was lost. Thus, he must pay it out again to one who is worthy of it, so that it falls into its proper place.

[The Bearer of Wisdom Who Places It with the Unworthy Based on Assumption]
As for the ruling of the two partners in this, as established, the bearer of wisdom who places it with the unworthy based on mere assumption is also wasting it. The one to whom it was given is not worthy of it, so it was lost with him, and some of its right is wasted. The giver of wisdom to the unworthy must recover what he missed by observing the state of the one with whom the wisdom was lost, and addressing him with the measure appropriate to him, so as to gradually lead him until he becomes worthy of it. And the right of the other (the worthy recipient) is lost to the extent that the first one lacked understanding of the initial wisdom that was lost with him.

[Whoever is Asked About Knowledge and Conceals It]
The situation regarding the remaining aspects of disagreement in the esoteric consideration follows this same pattern. Whoever adheres to the generality of his saying (may Allah bless him and grant him peace): <<من سئل عن علم فكتمه ألجمه الله بلجام من نار>> (Whoever is asked about knowledge and conceals it, Allah will bridle him with a bridle of fire)—and the one who asked him was unworthy of wisdom, and the wisdom was lost—that person says he is not responsible absolutely. And whoever takes the saying of the Prophet (may Allah bless him and grant him peace): "Do not give wisdom to those who are unworthy of it, lest you wrong it," says he is responsible absolutely. His responsibility is fulfilled by giving the questioner aspects appropriate to him, even if that is not correct in reality, such as discussing 'where-ness' (*al-Ayniyya*) with one who is not characterized by spatial limitation (*al-Taḥayyuẓ*). And whoever turns away from the first answer to an answer concerning the matter that is necessitated by the state of the questioner and the time, says he pays Zakat on what remains, and the ruling on what passed and was lost is like the ruling on wealth lost before the year passed. And whoever said that it is incumbent upon him to look into the state of the questioner, and since he did not do so, he was negligent (*farraṭa*). But if he did look and erred due to a specious argument that made him imagine the person was worthy of wisdom, then he was not negligent. This is equivalent to the view that if he was negligent, he is responsible, and if not, he is not responsible. The fifth view has already been presented concerning the partner.

[Knowledge is a Trust with the Scholar]
The scholar (*al-‘Ālim*) must either believe that the knowledge he possesses, which creation needs, is a trust (*Amāna*) held by him for them—in which case his ruling is that of a trustee (*Amīn*)—or he believes it is a debt (*Dayn*) owed by him to them—in which case his ruling is that of a debtor (*Gharīm*). The ruling concerning trust, debt, and loss is known, and the esoteric consideration proceeds according to those aspects. And Allah knows best.

(Section) If He Dies After Zakat Became Obligatory Upon Him
Some said it is paid from the principal of his wealth. Others said that if he bequeathed it, it is paid from the one-third (of his estate), and otherwise nothing is due upon him. Among these, some said it takes precedence even if the one-third is insufficient, and others said it does not take precedence.

(Section) The Esoteric Consideration in that
The man among the People of the Way of Allah (*Ahl Ṭarīq Allāh*) gives the Knowledge of Allah. We have said that the Zakat of knowledge is teaching it. A sincere, thirsty seeker (*Murīd Ṣādiq*) comes and asks him about a matter of knowledge that he possesses. This is the time when teaching him what he asked about becomes obligatory, just as Zakat becomes obligatory upon the completion of the year and the minimum threshold (*Niṣāb*). But he does not teach him the knowledge he asked for. Then Allah strips that matter from the scholar, and he remains ignorant of it. He seeks it within himself but does not find it. That is his death after the Zakat became obligatory. For ignorance is death. He said: <<أَ ومن كانَ مَيْتاً فَأَحْيَيْناهُ>> (Is he who was dead and We gave him life...). Or the scholar is obligated to teach one who is worthy, but he teaches one who is unworthy. That is his death, in that he was ignorant of the worthiness of the one who is worthy of wisdom, and he placed it with the unworthy. In the first case (where the scholar died/forgot), the sincere seeker may still be granted that matter, but through witnessing this scholar (in a vision), or by hearing him teach it to someone else, or by learning it from someone whom that scholar had taught previously. Thus, it is counted in the balance of the first scholar, even though he had forgotten it. This is the meaning of "it suffices him" and "it is paid from the principal of his wealth." If that scholar apologizes to the seeker and confesses his punishment and sin, and Allah grants the seeker the opening (*fatḥ*) concerning it, then his confession is equivalent to one who bequeathed it.

[The Sick Person Only Owns One-Third of His Wealth and No More]
As for paying it from the one-third, the sick person only owns one-third of his wealth and no more, so it is as if the obligation fell upon what he owns. Likewise, this scholar in this state only owns the apology from himself. The other two-thirds he does not own, which is the favor (*al-Minna*). He has no favor in teaching after this incident, nor is it obligatory upon him, for he has attributed it (the knowledge) to its source. In summary, whoever is in this state should renew his repentance (*Tawba*) for what he has fallen into and seek Allah’s forgiveness privately, for <<إِنَّ الله يُحِبُّ التَّوَّابِينَ>> (Indeed, Allah loves those who repent).

(Section Concerning Their Disagreement on Wealth Sold After Charity Became Obligatory Upon It)
Some said the Zakat collector takes the Zakat from the wealth itself, and the buyer seeks reimbursement for its value from the seller. Others said the sale is void (*mafsūkh*). Others said the buyer has the choice of executing the sale or rejecting it. The tithe is taken from the fruit or the grain upon which Zakat became obligatory. Malik said Zakat is due upon the seller, and this is the view I hold.

(Section) The Esoteric Consideration in that
He the Exalted said: <<قَدْ أَفْلَحَ من زَكَّاها>> (He has succeeded who purifies it)—meaning the soul (*al-Nafs*)—because he has made it into that upon which Zakat is not obligatory. The servant is commanded to purify his soul. Then <<إِنَّ الله اشْتَرى‏ من الْمُؤْمِنِينَ أَنْفُسَهُمْ>> (Indeed, Allah has purchased from the believers their souls). So some believers sold their souls to Allah after Zakat became obligatory upon them, for when the servant believes, the Zakat of his soul becomes obligatory upon him, and then he sells it to Allah after the Zakat became obligatory.

[Zakat on the Physical Asset and Zakat as a Liability Upon the Responsible Person]
Zakat must either be due on the physical asset (*‘ayn al-māl*) or be a liability upon the responsible person (*dhimmat al-mukallaf*). If it is a liability upon the responsible person, it is obligatory upon the seller. If it is due on the physical asset itself, its purification is obligatory upon the one who possesses the wealth, from the asset itself. Thus, the buyer pays it from the wealth and seeks reimbursement for the value from the seller. If the obligation is upon the seller, the seller may pay that amount of Zakat from the wealth he possesses.

[The Guiding Shaykh Owns the Souls of His Disciples]
Like the guiding Shaykh (*al-Shaykh al-Murshid*) who owns the souls of his disciples (*talāmidha*). He purifies them (pays Zakat from them) according to the amount of Zakat that was obligatory upon his own soul before he sold it to Allah, since Zakat had already become obligatory upon his soul. The Zakat of the souls of the seekers (*Murīdīn*) under him takes the place of that (original Zakat). If he is among those who hold that the sale is void, he retracts his sale until he purifies it (pays Zakat), and then he sells it to Allah. If he is among those who hold that the buyer has the choice of executing or rejecting the sale, then that is up to Allah: if He wills, He accepts it and purifies it; and if He wills, He returns it to the seller until he purifies it.

(Section) [Zakat on Gifted Wealth]
And from this chapter is their disagreement concerning the Zakat on gifted wealth (*al-Māl al-Mawhūb*). The esoteric consideration is that the recipient of the gift has a choice: if he wills, he accepts the gift, having known the right due upon it, so he delivers the right from it to its deserving recipient and keeps what remains. And if he wills, he returns the amount of Zakat due on it to the seller (donor) so that he may pay it. The recipient of the gift here is The Real (al-Ḥaqq). And those who have the Zakat from this soul—what Paradise and those within it demand from them—is that a right for them from the soul of the believer? End of the Fifty-First Part.

(In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful)

(Section Concerning the Ruling on One Who Withholds Zakat)
Concerning the ruling on one who withholds Zakat while not denying its obligation: Abu Bakr al-Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him) held that his ruling is the ruling of the apostate (*al-Murtadd*), so he fought them and took their descendants captive. Umar ibn al-Khaṭṭāb (may Allah be pleased with him) disagreed with him on this and freed those who had been enslaved. The majority holds the view of Umar. A group went so far as to declare anyone who withholds any obligatory duty (*farīḍa*), even if he does not deny its obligation, to be an unbeliever (*kāfir*).

(Section) The Esoteric Consideration in that
Know that in the soul of the believer (*Nafs al-Mu’min*) is the share of the Gardens (Paradise) and those within them, which is the Zakat. And what remains is for Allah, and that is what is valid for sale (to Allah). A group of the Verifiers (*al-Muḥaqqiqīn*) among the People of the Way of Allah (*Ahl Ṭarīq Allāh*) adopted this view, due to the multiplicity of categories of those upon whom Zakat from their souls is obligatory. Paradise contains categories that demand from the soul of the believer what they deserve, which is the Zakat. The palaces demand him for residence, and the spouses demand him for what they need from him. Just as Zakat is obligatory upon the eight responsible limbs (*al-A‘ḍā’ al-Mukallafa*) of the human being, they also have a relation to receiving Zakat from another perspective. Thus, what is in the Gardens takes the place of those upon whom the appropriate share is distributed.

[The Withholder of Zakat from His Soul is an Oppressor of It]
Whoever withholds the Zakat of his soul from one of these categories, while acknowledging that it is obligatory upon him, is an oppressor (*ẓālim*), not an unbeliever (*kāfir*), except specifically concerning prayer (*al-Ṣalāh*), for the one who abandons it is an unbeliever, as the Law called him an unbeliever merely for the abandonment, though I do not know what He intended. The withholder of Zakat is merely an oppressor, since he withheld the right of others that is due to them. I shall mention after this, if Allah wills, what Zakat is obligatory upon. <<والله يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way).

(Section Mentioning What Zakat is Obligatory Upon)
Scholars agreed that Zakat is obligatory upon eight things, confined to the generated things (*al-Mawalladāt*): mineral, plant, and animal. The mineral is gold and silver. The plant is wheat, barley, and dates. The animal is camels, cattle, and sheep. This is what is agreed upon, and it is the correct view according to us. As for raisins, there is disagreement concerning them.

(The Esoteric Consideration in that)
Zakat is obligatory upon the human being concerning eight limbs (*A‘ḍā’*): the sight, the hearing, the tongue, the hand, the belly, the private parts, the leg, and the heart. Upon every one of these limbs, there is an obligatory charity (*ṣadaqa wājiba*) by which Allah demands the servant in the Hereafter. As for voluntary charity (*ṣadaqat al-Taṭawwu‘*), there is a charity due upon every vein (*‘irq*) in the human being, as he (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) said: "Every joint (*sulāmā*) of a human being must give charity every morning." The *sulāmā* are the veins on the back of the hand, or it is said, the veins (in general). Every glorification (*tasbīḥa*) is a charity, and every declaration of oneness (*tahlīla*) is a charity, as are praise (*taḥmīd*) and magnification (*takbīr*).

[The Zakat of the Eight Limbs of the Human Being and the Zakat of the Eight Categories of Wealth]
The Zakat that is due on these limbs is the right of Allah the Exalted, which He made obligatory upon the human being concerning these eight limbs, just as He made it obligatory upon these eight categories of gold, silver, and the rest of what we mentioned upon which Zakat is due by consensus. Thus, it is incumbent upon the believer to fulfill the right of Allah the Exalted in every limb. The Zakat of the sight is the right of Allah due upon it, such as lowering the gaze from forbidden things, and looking at what leads to proximity (*Qurba*) to Allah, such as looking at the Qur’an, at the face of a scholar, at the face of a relative or child whose sight pleases you, and their likes, and looking at the Kaaba if you are residing near it, for it has been reported that the one who looks at the Kaaba receives twenty mercies every day, and the one who circumambulates it receives sixty mercies. In this manner, you should consider all the responsible limbs of the human being, concerning their use in what is proper and their restraint from what is improper.

(Statement and Clarification)
Know that these categories encompass the generated things (*Mawalladāt*) of the elements, as we said: mineral, plant, and animal. There is no fourth. Allah decreed Zakat upon specific types within each genus of the generated things for the purification (*ṭahāra*) of the genus. Thus, the type is undoubtedly purified from the claim of ownership made by the human being, for its origin is purity, insofar as it is absolutely the property of Allah.

[The Origin from Which Things Manifested]
This is because the Origin (*al-Aṣl*) from which things manifested is His Name, The Holy (*al-Quddūs*), who is Pure in His Essence (*Dhāt*) from the defilement of created things (*al-Muḥdathāt*). When things manifested in their fixed entities (*A‘yān*) and claims of ownership were made by owners, the attribution of ownership to other than their Originator brought upon them something that removed them from the original purity they possessed by virtue of their relation to their Originator, before this accidental defilement attached to them through the ownership of others. And sufficient is the created thing (*al-Ḥadath*) as a created thing. These genera have no disposal over themselves. So Allah made Zakat obligatory upon their owner and made that their purification. Allah designated a share in them that returns to Allah by His command, so that they may be attributed to their original Owner and thus acquire purity, for Allah only made Zakat a purification of wealth. And likewise in the esoteric consideration.

[The Eight Responsible Limbs of the Human Being are Pure by Virtue of Their Origin]
These responsible limbs are pure by virtue of their origin, for they are upon the primordial nature (*al-Fiṭra al-Ūlā*). That purity and justice (*‘Adāla*) do not depart from them. Do you not see that they will be called to testify on the Day of Resurrection, and their testimony will be accepted due to their original purification (*Zakātihā al-Aṣliyya*) and justice? For the origin of things is justice, because they stem from a pure origin, and injury/defilement (*al-Jarḥa*) is accidental. He the Exalted said: <<إِنَّ السَّمْعَ والْبَصَرَ والْفُؤادَ كُلُّ أُولئِكَ كانَ عَنْهُ مَسْؤُلًا>> (Indeed, the hearing, the sight, and the heart—all of those will be questioned). And He said: <<يَوْمَ تَشْهَدُ عَلَيْهِمْ أَلْسِنَتُهُمْ وأَيْدِيهِمْ وأَرْجُلُهُمْ>> (The Day their tongues, their hands, and their feet will testify against them). And He the Exalted said: <<وقالُوا لِجُلُودِهِمْ لِمَ شَهِدْتُمْ عَلَيْنا>> (And they will say to their skins, "Why have you testified against us?"). And He the Exalted said: <<وما كُنْتُمْ تَسْتَتِرُونَ أَنْ يَشْهَدَ عَلَيْكُمْ سَمْعُكُمْ ولا أَبْصارُكُمْ ولا جُلُودُكُمْ>> (And you were not concealing yourselves so that your hearing, your sight, and your skins would not testify against you). All of this is an announcement from Allah to us that every part of us is a just, purified, and pleasing witness. This is good news for us, but <<ولكِنَّ أَكْثَرَ النَّاسِ لا يَعْلَمُونَ>> (most people do not know) the form of goodness in it. For if the matter is of this nature, it is hoped that the outcome will be good, even if one enters the Fire, because Allah is too Majestic, too Great, and too Just to punish one who is compelled (*mukrah*) and overpowered (*maqhūr*). And He said: <<إِلَّا من أُكْرِهَ وقَلْبُهُ مُطْمَئِنٌّ بِالْإِيمانِ>> (Except for him who is compelled [to renounce faith] while his heart is secure in faith).

[The Connection of the Soul to the Senses and Limbs]
The ruling concerning the compelled person (*al-Mukrah*) is established in the Law, and the definition of the compelled person—both those agreed upon and those disagreed upon—is known. These limbs (*Jawāriḥ*) are among the compelled ones upon whom there is consensus that they are compelled. Thus, these limbs undoubtedly testify against the soul (*al-Nafs*) that manages them and holds authority over them. The soul is the one sought by Allah concerning His limits (*Ḥudūd*) and the one responsible for them. The soul is connected to the senses and powers; it cannot be separated from these physical, natural, just, purified, pleasing instruments whose testimony is heard. And there is no punishment for the soul except through the medium of punishing these bodies, which are the ones that feel perceptible pains due to the flow of the animal spirit (*al-Rūḥ al-Ḥayawānī*) within them.

[The Punishment of the Soul]
The punishment of the soul is through worries (*humūm*), sorrows (*ghumūm*), the dominance of delusions (*awhām*) and bad thoughts, and what it sees in its subjects (the body) of felt pains and changes that occur to it—each type receiving the punishment appropriate to it. Its ultimate destination has been announced to be happiness due to its faith, because the overpowered one (*al-Maqhūr*) is not held accountable for what he was compelled to do. The limbs are only punished with pain because they also felt pleasure in what they attained, by virtue of their animality—so understand this. Its image is like that of one compelled to commit fornication, concerning which there is disagreement. The soul is not held accountable for the worry (*al-Hamm*) unless it acts upon what it worried about using the limbs. The animal soul (*al-Nafs al-Ḥayawāniyya*) is inherently cooperative, despite being compelled in one aspect. Souls only act through these instruments, and the instruments only move in action through the soul’s purposes (*al-Aghrāḍ al-Nafsiyya*). Just as the action occurred through the totality, the punishment occurs through the totality. Then, the justice of the instruments ultimately leads to the happiness of the believers, and the sensory punishment (*al-‘Adhāb al-Ḥissī*) is lifted.

[The Lifting of Punishment from the People of Faith in the End]
Then the ruling of the Law, which lifted accountability from the soul for what it merely worried about, is executed, and the spiritual punishment (*al-‘Adhāb al-Ma‘nawī*) is also lifted from the believer. Thus, no spiritual or sensory punishment remains upon any of the People of Faith (*Ahl al-Īmān*). The duration of punishment upon the rational soul (*al-Nafs al-Nāṭiqa*) and the perceiving animal soul is short, corresponding to the short duration of the action in this worldly abode, due to the presence of pleasure in it, and the days of bliss are short. For the breaths of worries are long. How long the night is for those in pain, and how short it is for those in pleasure and bliss! The time of hardship is long for its subject, and the time of ease is short.

Know that Zakat has a minimum threshold (*Niṣāb*) and a year (*Ḥawl*)—that is, a measure in the asset and in time. Likewise, the esoteric consideration in the Zakat of the limbs has a measure in the asset and in time. The *Niṣāb* is the asset reaching the second glance, for that is the intended one, and listening to the second hearing, and likewise the second instances in all the limbs, due to intention (*al-Qaṣd*). And the temporal measure accompanies it. Let us mention what is appropriate for this chapter, issue by issue, according to what Allah Almighty casts into the mind (*al-Khāṭir*). And Allah is the Granter of Success and the Guide to a straight path.

(Section Concerning Zakat on Ornaments)
Scholars (may Allah be pleased with them) disagreed concerning the Zakat on ornaments (*al-Ḥulī*). Some say no Zakat is due on them, and others say Zakat is due.

(The Esoteric Consideration in that)
Ornaments are what is taken for adornment (*Zīna*), and adornment is commanded. Allah the Exalted said: <<يا بَنِي آدَمَ خُذُوا زِينَتَكُمْ عِنْدَ كُلِّ مَسْجِدٍ>> (O children of Adam, take your adornment at every mosque). And He the Exalted said: <<قُلْ من حَرَّمَ زِينَةَ الله الَّتِي أَخْرَجَ لِعِبادِهِ>> (Say: "Who has forbidden the adornment of Allah which He has produced for His servants?"). He attributed it to Himself, not to the world (*al-Dunyā*) or to Satan. Zakat is a right belonging to Him, and what is attributed to Him cannot have a right belonging to Him in it, because it all belongs to Him. Thus, there is no Zakat on the adornment of Allah.

[Allah Legislated for the Human Being to Seek His Aid in His Actions]
But whoever takes it for the adornment of the worldly life (*Zīnat al-Ḥayāt al-Dunyā*) and strips it of the adornment of Allah, Zakat is obligatory upon it. This Zakat is to assign a share in it to Allah, by which He revives what was attributed to the self, and it is purified and sanctified. Just as Allah legislated for the human being to seek help from Allah and ask for His aid in the actions He, Glorified is He, obligated him to perform—and He, Glorified is He, is the Doer, not them. Likewise, Zakat should be placed upon the adornment of the worldly life, even if it is <<زِينَةَ الله الَّتِي أَخْرَجَ لِعِبادِهِ>> (the adornment of Allah which He has produced for His servants). So they made Zakat obligatory upon that adornment, just as those who made it obligatory upon ornaments (*al-Ḥulī*).

(Section Concerning Zakat on Horses)
They disagreed concerning horses (*al-Khayl*). The majority holds that there is no Zakat on horses. Some said that if they are grazing (*sā’ima*) and intended for breeding, Zakat is due on them—meaning if they include males and females.

(Section) The Esoteric Consideration in that
This type of animal and its likes are among the adornment of Allah.
