He the Exalted said: <<والْخَيْلَ والْبِغالَ والْحَمِيرَ لِتَرْكَبُوها وزِينَةً>> (And [He created] horses, mules, and donkeys for you to ride and as adornment). They are part of <<زِينَةَ الله الَّتِي أَخْرَجَ لِعِبادِهِ>> (the adornment of Allah which He has produced for His servants). Furthermore, it is an animal capable of charging and retreating, making it the most beneficial animal for striving (*Jihād*) in the way of Allah. The predominant aspect of it is that it is for Allah. And what is for Allah has no right of Allah in it, because it all belongs to Allah.

[The Soul’s Mount is the Body]
The soul (*al-Nafs*) has the body (*al-Badan*) as its mount. If the body, in its temperament and the composition of its natures, is such that it assists the pure believing soul in what it desires—namely, turning toward obedience to Allah and fleeing from disobedience to Allah—then it is for Allah. And what is for Allah has no right of Allah in it, because it all belongs to Allah. If the body assists at one time but not at another due to a defect in it, then restraining the soul by force in what it fails to assist in obedience to Allah is the Zakat due upon it. Like one who intends to pray but finds laziness and sluggishness in his limbs, so he holds back from it despite desiring it. The fulfillment of Zakat at that time is to establish the prayer and not abandon it despite the laziness. And the soul in that moment is grazing (*sā’ima*)—from the consideration of being taken for breeding—because it contains males and females, meaning thoughts of the intellect (*khawāṭir ‘aql*) and thoughts of the soul (*khawāṭir nafs*).

(Section) Concerning Grazing Camels, Cattle, and Sheep, and Non-Grazing Ones
Some groups made Zakat obligatory upon all of them, grazing and non-grazing. The majority held that there is no Zakat on the non-grazing animals of these three types.

(The Esoteric Consideration of this Section)
The grazing (*al-Sā’ima*) are all permissible actions (*al-Af‘āl al-Mubāḥa*). The non-grazing are everything other than the permissible. Whoever said Zakat is due on the grazing animals said that because permissible actions are accompanied by heedlessness (*al-Ghafla*), they made it obligatory for the human being to be present when performing the permissible action, recognizing that it is permissible by the permission of the Lawgiver—for had He not permitted it, he would not have done it. This degree of contemplation (*al-Naẓar*) is its Zakat. As for the non-grazing, there is no Zakat on them because they are all actions restricted by obligation (*wujūb*), recommendation (*nadb*), prohibition (*ḥaẓr*), or dislike (*karāha*). In all of them, there is no absolute choice for the servant, so they are all for Allah the Exalted. And what is for Allah has no Zakat due on it, for Zakat is a right of Allah in all of this. Some of our companions attached the recommended and the disliked actions to the permissible, making Zakat due on them just like the permissible. Another group said that they are not like the permissible, for they contain aspects resembling the obligatory and the forbidden, and aspects resembling the permissible. If the time dictates prioritizing one of the two considerations in them, then their ruling is according to the ruling of the time: sometimes they are considered permissible, and sometimes they are considered obligatory and forbidden.

[The Grazing is Owned and the Non-Grazing is Owned]
The image in the analogy is that the grazing animal is owned, and the non-grazing animal is owned. The common factor between them is ownership. However, the ownership of the non-grazing animal is more established due to the owner’s preoccupation with it and his constant care for it. The grazing animal is not like that, even though it is owned. Likewise, concerning the recommended and the disliked, one has a choice in action and abandonment, so they resemble the permissible. Yet, one is rewarded for acting upon them or abandoning them, so they resemble the obligatory and the forbidden. This is the soundest of the schools of thought among us.

[The Servant’s Actions are Attributed to Him and to Allah in Two Different Aspects]
Whoever said Zakat is due on all of them said that it was made obligatory on all actions, grazing and non-grazing, because the actions performed by the servant are attributed to the servant by a Divine attribution, even if the evidence suggests otherwise. Thus, Zakat became obligatory on all actions due to the attribution to the creature that entered them.

[The Form of Zakat in Human Actions]
The form of Zakat in them is your realization that everything that occurs from you is by Divine Decree (*Qaḍā’*) and Destiny (*Qadar*), through complete witnessing (*mushāhada*) and presence in every action at the moment of commencing the action. That realization is the time of Zakat, analogous to the completion of the year (*Ḥawl*). And the measure of that action which can be returned to Allah is the *Niṣāb* of that action. This is the school of thought of the Scholars of Allah (*‘Ulamā’ bi-Allāh*): that all actions belong to Allah in one aspect and are attributed to the servant in another aspect. So let not one aspect veil them from the other, just as no concern distracts Him from another concern.

(Section Concerning Zakat on Grains)
As for the plants concerning which they disagreed after agreeing on the three types (wheat, barley, dates): some held that Zakat is only due on those three types. Others said Zakat is due on all storable, staple plants. And others said Zakat is due on everything the earth produces, except grass, firewood, and reeds.

(The Esoteric Consideration in its Being a Plant)
This type (plant/grain) is specific to the heart (*al-Qalb*), for it is the place where thoughts (*al-Khawāṭir*) grow, and in it their ruling manifests upon the limbs. Every thought that grows in the heart and whose essence manifests on the surface of the land of his body has Zakat due upon it, because every observer testifies that it is an action of the one upon whom it appeared. Thus, he must purify it by returning it to Allah; that is its Zakat. As for what does not manifest, the person in whose heart it grew must consider whether he saw Allah in it or before it. If he is of this type, no Zakat is due upon it, for it is for Allah. And whoever saw Allah after it, because of it, that is the very essence of Zakat which he has paid. If he did not see Allah in any aspect, Zakat is obligatory upon him according to the Scholars of Allah (*‘Ulamā’ bi-Allāh*), but Zakat is not obligatory upon him according to the Jurists (*Fuqahā’*) among the People of the Way, because the Lawgiver did not consider them accountable until the action occurs. Thus, it was a growth upon which Zakat was dropped, just as accountability for it was dropped.

[The Sustenance by Which Everything Subsists]
If the growth is among the thoughts that contain sustenance (*Qūt*) for the soul, Zakat is obligatory due to the soul’s share in it. If the soul’s share is secondary, there is no Zakat. For the sustenance of the one whose description is this is Allah, by whom everything subsists. Sahl ibn Abdullah was asked, "What is sustenance (*al-Qūt*)?" He said, "Allah." He was asked, "We asked you about the sustenance of the bodies (*al-Ashbāḥ*)?" He said, "Allah." When they insisted, he said, "What concern is it of yours? Leave the dwellings to their Owner and Builder. If He wills, He populates them, and if He wills, He ruins them."

(Section Concerning the Minimum Threshold in the Esoteric Consideration)
[The Minimum Threshold of the Responsible Limbs]
As for the *Niṣāb* (minimum threshold) in the limbs, it is that you proceed in every limb from the first instance to the second, but from the first instance that is pardoned, not the first instance that is recommended. The first pardoned instance has no Zakat due on it, for it is for Allah. The second is for you, so Zakat is obligatory upon it, whether it is the first glance, the first hearing, the first utterance, the first strike, the first stride, or the first thought.

[Every Movement Without Intention Has No Zakat Due Upon It]
The comprehensive rule is that every movement of a limb in which there is no intention (*Qaṣd*) has no Zakat due upon it. If the second movement follows it, it must be volitional (*Nafsiyya*) based on intention, so Zakat becomes obligatory—meaning its purification. And the Zakat due upon it is repentance (*al-Tawba*) and nothing else. Thus, it joins the first movement in purity because of repentance, and repentance is its Zakat.

[The Limit of the Minimum Threshold for Zakat on the Limbs]
This is the limit of the *Niṣāb* concerning everything upon which Zakat is obligatory on the limbs. There is no need to enumerate them according to the manifest, legislated ruling concerning those categories, because the objective is the esoteric consideration (*al-I‘tibār*), which has become clear, so we suffice with this instead of detailing it. The consideration of the time of Zakat has preceded, and there remains for us the consideration of one who pays Zakat before its time. Some groups prohibited this—and this is the view I hold—while others permitted it. The purification of the locus for the thought (*al-Khāṭir*) before it occurs is by preparing for it, along with his knowledge of what will occur to him through the unveiling (*al-Kashf*) he possesses. If he is certain of its inevitable occurrence, he should not pay it (Zakat) early, for it reverts to the original purity. When it occurs, purification is undoubtedly necessary due to its occurrence. Therefore, one should not transgress the times appointed for matters, for the ruling belongs to the time. Whoever pays it before the time has suspended the ruling of the time.

(Section Mentioning Those for Whom Charity is Obligatory)
They are the eight categories mentioned by Allah in the Qur’an: the poor (*al-Fuqarā’*), the needy (*al-Masākīn*), those employed to collect it (*al-‘Āmilūn ‘alayhā*), those whose hearts are to be reconciled (*al-Mu’allafa Qulūbuhum*), for freeing slaves (*al-Riqāb*), those in debt (*al-Ghārimūn*), in the cause of Allah (*fī Sabīl Allāh*), and the traveler (*Ibn al-Sabīl*). The mentioned limbs pay Zakat from their actions and it is returned to their essences (*A‘yān*), which is expressed as their reward (*Thawāb*). Zakat is due on the actions of these limbs, and Zakat is distributed upon their essences. Whoever purifies his sight by himself gives Zakat to his sight, so he returns to seeing by his Lord after he used to see by himself. Likewise, whoever purifies his hearing by himself gives Zakat to his hearing, so he begins to hear by his Lord. This is the meaning of His saying: "I was his hearing and his sight." Likewise, he speaks, strikes, and strives—all of that is by his Lord—and he conducts all his affairs by his Lord.

(Section) Concerning the Designation of the Eight Categories
Upon whom Zakat is distributed in the esoteric consideration, among them are the poor. Allah the Exalted said: <<إِنَّمَا الصَّدَقاتُ لِلْفُقَراءِ والْمَساكِينِ والْعامِلِينَ عَلَيْها والْمُؤَلَّفَةِ قُلُوبُهُمْ وفي الرِّقابِ والْغارِمِينَ وفي سَبِيلِ الله وابْنِ السَّبِيلِ فَرِيضَةً من الله>> (Zakat expenditures are only for the poor, the needy, those employed to collect [Zakat], those whose hearts are to be reconciled, for [freeing] slaves, those in debt, in the cause of Allah, and the traveler—an obligation imposed by Allah). He says Allah made it obligatory for these mentioned categories, so it is not permissible to give it to others. There is disagreement concerning giving it to only one category.

[Distribution of Zakat to the Categories of Recipients, Not to Individuals]
The view I adopt is that whoever is found among these categories, the charity (*al-Ṣadaqa*) is distributed among them according to who is present, but based on the categories, not the individuals. Even if only one person is found in a category, the share of that category is given to him. If more than one person is found in a category, the share designated for that category is distributed among those present, whether the individuals are few or many. Likewise, the collector’s share in that land is distributed according to the categories found. If all are found, then each category receives a share ranging from an eighth of the charity to a seventh, a sixth, a fifth, a quarter, a third, a half, or the whole amount.

[Prioritizing the Categories Upon Whom Zakat is Distributed]
Furthermore, we prioritize in giving those whom Allah prioritized in mention. Likewise, I do so here in designating them in this chapter. When the Messenger of Allah (may Allah bless him and grant him peace) came to perform the running (*Sa‘y*) between Safa and Marwa during his Farewell Pilgrimage, he recited His saying, the Exalted: <<إِنَّ الصَّفا والْمَرْوَةَ من شَعائِرِ الله>> (Indeed, al-Safa and al-Marwa are among the symbols of Allah), and he said: "I begin with what Allah began with."

[A Story Narrated by One of Ibn Arabi’s Shaykhs]
One of our Shaykhs narrated a story to me concerning this. He said: A man from Qayrawan intended to perform Hajj, and he remained undecided whether to travel by sea or by land, neither option prevailing in his mind. He said, "I will ask the first man I meet, and whichever path he tells me, I will take it." The first person he met was a Jew. He was perplexed whether to ask him, but then resolved to consult him. The Jew said to him, "O Muslim, does not Allah say: <<هُوَ الَّذِي يُسَيِّرُكُمْ في الْبَرِّ والْبَحْرِ>> (It is He who enables you to travel on land and sea)? He prioritized the land, so prioritize what Allah prioritized." This is the Way: we begin with what Allah began with, and we prioritize what Allah prioritized, for whoever adheres to this will see goodness in his movements.

(The Consideration of the Poor)

The one to whom charity must be given is not obligated to take it, according to the People of the Way (أهل الطريق), except according to us, for it is obligatory upon him to take it if you give it, and he should never ask for it. Even if he has realized the highest degree of servanthood (العبودية) within it, and it comes to him, he takes it. For Zakat, even though it is designated for these categories, is the right of Allah (حق الله) in these properties. And the servant is permitted to eat from the property of his Master, for it is His right. It was only forbidden to the People of the House (Ahl al-Bayt) as a specification of this attribution [to Allah]. Whether they realized servanthood or not, if the prohibition were due to the realization of servanthood, it would only have been forbidden to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) and those who follow his path, but this is not the case. Thus, the People of Allah (أهل الله) are the most entitled to dispose of the rights of Allah (حقوق الله).

### [The Poor Person is the One Who is in Need of Everything]

Then we return and say: The poor person (الفقير) according to us, who has no rank of poverty beyond him, is the one who is in need of everything, and nothing is in need of him. Up until now, I have not seen anyone who has realized this quality (صفة). Allah the Almighty says, out of Divine Jealousy (الغيرة الإلهية): <<O mankind, you are the poor [in need] of Allah>> (يَا أَيُّهَا النَّاسُ أَنْتُمُ الْفُقَرَاءُ إِلَى اللَّهِ). He has thus alluded to Himself in this verse by everything that is needed. And Allah <<is the Self-Sufficient (الغَنِيُّ), the Praiseworthy (الحَمِيدُ)>>. No poor person is in need except of Allah, whether that person knows it or not. For the Divine Poor (الفقير الإلهي) sees the Real (الحق) as the very essence (عين) of everything, and he is immersed and submerged in his servanthood (عبودية) when he witnesses Allah.

[Allah] names Himself to him by the name of everything that is needed. And there is nothing in Existence (الوجود) except that someone is in need of it, yet nothing among all things is in need of him [the poor person], due to this poor person standing firm upon this verse: <<O mankind, you are the poor [in need] of Allah, and Allah is the Self-Sufficient, the Praiseworthy.>> So, he realized this verse, and Allah made purification (الطهارة) and Zakat obligatory for him, since he observed proper conduct (تأدب) with Allah and knew what Allah intended by this verse. For it is one of the greatest verses revealed in the Quran for the Gnostics of Allah (العلماء بالله) who understood from Allah. The quality of self-sufficiency (غنى) is not manifested upon him, neither through Allah nor through anything other than Allah, such that others would be in need of him from that aspect. Thus, absolute poverty (مطلق الفقر) is confirmed for him. Thus, Allah became his self-sufficiency, since he is among those who are self-sufficient through Allah. For the one who is self-sufficient through Allah is he whom creation needs, and he boasts over them by his self-sufficiency in his Lord. Such a person is not obligated to take this Zakat.

The Real (الحق) did not mention the poor first, above those who are in greater need than them—neither the needy (مسكين) nor anyone else. For the poor person (الفقير) is the one whose spine (فقار ظهره) is broken, so he cannot straighten his back or his loins. He has no share in the Self-Subsistence (القيومية) whatsoever. Rather, he remains perpetually bowed down due to his brokenness. Understand this subtle indication (الإشارة).

### [The Needy Person is One Who is Governed by Another]

And the needy (المساكين): The *Miskin* (needy) comes from *sukun* (stillness), which is the opposite of movement. Death is stillness. If the dead moves, it is by the movement of another, not by itself. Thus, the *Miskin* is one who is governed by another. For this reason, Allah prescribed that Zakat be given to him, and it is not said that he is taking it. He is characterized neither by need nor by lack of need. This is why we said concerning the *Faqir* (poor) that there is no one above him who is in greater need than him. For the *Miskin* is the very essence (عين) of the Muslim who entrusts his affair to Allah (المفوض أمره إلى الله) without his own choice; rather, the Unveiling (الكشف) granted him that. For this reason, we likened him to the dead. The *Miskin* is like the earth which Allah made subservient (ذلول) to us. So, whoever is inherently subservient (ذلة ذاتية) beneath the might (عز) of every mighty one, whoever that mighty one may be, that person is the *Miskin*, due to his realization that <<Indeed, all might belongs to Allah>> (فَإِنَّ الْعِزَّةَ لِلَّهِ). And that His might is the one manifested in every mighty one. This is a Prophetic Gnosis (معرفة نبوية).

### [The Worker is the Guide to the Knowledge of Meanings]

And those employed to collect them (العاملين عليها): The *Amil* (worker) is the guide (المرشد) to the knowledge (معرفة) of these meanings, the one who clarifies their realities (حقائقها), the teacher, the master, and the indicator to them. He is the one who gathers them by his knowledge from everyone upon whom they are obligatory. He receives a share from it according to his work, and the ruling concerning his right to it is only as we have previously stated. It is more fitting for the guide (المرشد) to say what the Messengers said: <<My reward is only from Allah>> (إِنْ أَجْرِيَ إِلَّا عَلَى اللَّهِ). This portion they receive may be from the Divine Zakat (الزكاة الإلهية). Thus, they are entitled to take the Zakat of Consideration (زكاة الاعتبار), not the Zakat of wealth (زكاة المال). For outward charity (الصدقة الظاهرة) is forbidden to the Prophets because they are servants, and the servant does not take charity insofar as it is attributed to creation. Know this.

### [Those Whose Hearts Are Reconciled to the Love of the Benefactor]

And those whose hearts are reconciled (المؤلفة قلوبهم): They are those whom beneficence (الإحسان) reconciles to the love of the Benefactor, because hearts fluctuate. Their reconciliation is that they fluctuate in all matters according to what their realities (حقائقها) demand, but for one single Essence (عين واحدة), which is the Essence of Allah (عين الله). This is their reconciliation upon Him. They are not possessed by scattered essences due to the dispersion of the matters in which they fluctuate.

### [The Streams That Return to a Single Source]

If the streams (الجداول) return to a single source (عين واحدة), then that source must be observed and reconciliation must be made through it. For if heedlessness (الغفلة) overtakes him concerning it, and that source withholds its water, the streams will not benefit him; rather, they will dry up and their source will vanish. But if he observes the Source and is reconciled through it, his streams will become vast and his channels will widen.

### [Those Who Seek Freedom]

And for [the freeing of] captives (في الرقاب): They are those who seek freedom from the servitude (رق) of everything other than Allah. For the secondary causes (الأسباب) have enslaved the necks of the world, such that they know nothing else. The highest among them in servitude are those enslaved by the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية). There is no servitude higher than this, except the servitude to the Oneness (أحدية) of the First Cause, insofar as it is a cause, not insofar as it is the Essence (ذات). Nevertheless, they should not be enslaved by the Names, due to the dominance of their contemplation of the Oneness of the Essence (أحدية الذات) insofar as it is the Essence, not insofar as it is a God. It is for the freeing of such captives (رقاب) that Zakat is disbursed.

### [Those Who Loaned Allah a Goodly Loan]

And the debtors (الغارمين): They are those who <<loaned Allah a goodly loan>> (أَقْرَضُوا اللَّهَ قَرْضًا حَسَنًا) by His command, which is His saying, exalted is He, commanding: <<And loan Allah a goodly loan>> (وَأَقْرِضُوا اللَّهَ قَرْضًا حَسَنًا). This is conjoined with two obligatory commands, which are His saying: <<Establish prayer>> (وَأَقِيمُوا الصَّلَاةَ) and <<Give Zakat>> (وَآتُوا الزَّكَاةَ). He made the third saying: <<And loan Allah a goodly loan.>> The loan is the third of three, but He did not specify what you should loan, just as He did not specify what you should purify (زكاة), nor did He specify a particular prayer. Thus, it encompasses every prayer we are commanded to establish, every Zakat, and every loan, except that He qualified the loan (قَرْضًا) by saying "goodly" (حَسَنًا), with emphasis by the verbal noun. The reason for this is that in prayer and Zakat, the servant is a servant of necessity (عبد اضطرار), but in the loan, he is a servant of choice (عبد اختيار). Among people are those who loan Allah a loan of choice, who were not reached by the command [to loan], but were reached by [the verses]: <<If you loan Allah...>> (إِنْ تُقْرِضُوا اللَّهَ) or His saying: <<Who is it that would loan Allah a goodly loan?>> (مَنْ ذَا الَّذِي يُقْرِضُ اللَّهَ قَرْضًا حَسَنًا).

The first debtor (الغارم الأول), who gave charity based on obligation—meaning it is obligatory for him [to receive]—takes the Zakat. The second takes it by the choice of the giver of charity, who distinguished him above others, especially according to the school of thought that holds that the number of these categories restricts the recipients to those mentioned—meaning it is not permissible to give to others. If you give to one category among them but not another, the obligation is fulfilled, though this is a matter of dispute. This lender, based on the verse <<Who is it that would loan Allah...>> and <<If you loan Allah...>>, does not take it by the ruling of obligation. But the lender based on the verse of command takes it by the ruling of obligation, because the commanded person fulfilled an obligation, so his reward is obligatory. <<And incumbent upon Us was support of the believers>> (وَكَانَ حَقًّا عَلَيْنَا نَصْرُ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ). For faith (الإيمان) is obligatory. <<I will decree it for those who fear Me and give Zakat and those who believe in Our verses>> (فَسَأَكْتُبُهَا لِلَّذِينَ يَتَّقُونَ وَيُؤْتُونَ الزَّكَاةَ وَالَّذِينَ هُمْ بِآيَاتِنَا يُؤْمِنُونَ). All of these are obligations, so He made the reward obligatory through mercy for them, without a doubt.

### [The Way of Allah is All Paths of Goodness Leading to Allah]

And in the way of Allah (في سبيل الله): It is possible that He means the fighters (المجاهدين) and spending from it on *Jihad*. For the customary meaning of *Sabil Allah* (Way of Allah) in Sacred Law (الشرع) is *Jihad*, and this is the most apparent meaning in this verse. However, it is possible that by *Sabil Allah* He means all paths of goodness (سبل الخير) that draw one near to Allah. As for this category, according to what the Path (الطريق) requires, *Sabil Allah* is what this Name, which is Allah, grants, excluding the other Divine Beautiful Names (الأسماء الحسنى الإلهية). Thus, he disburses it for what noble character (مكارم الأخلاق) demands, without considering any specific category of creatures, like Allah providing sustenance to His servants. Rather, it is what the general welfare (المصلحة العامة) demands for every human, indeed, for every animal and plant—even a tree he sees dying of thirst, so he uses Zakat money to buy what will water it, and he waters it with that, for that is part of *Sabil Allah*. (Though no one holds this opinion [in jurisprudence]).

### [The Lesser Jihad and the Greater Jihad]

If He meant the fighters, the fighters are known by custom who they are. And the fighters themselves are also in the Way of Allah, so they are assisted by this [Zakat] in their struggle against their own selves (جهاد أنفسهم).

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "You have returned from the Lesser Jihad (الجهاد الأصغر) to the Greater Jihad (الجهاد الأكبر)."

He meant the struggle against the souls (جهاد النفوس) and opposing them in their aims that divert one from the path of Allah the Almighty.

### [The Traveler is the Child of the Path of Allah]

And the traveler (ابن السبيل): The travelers are known. In consideration (الاعتبار), they are the children of the Path of Allah (أبناء طريق الله), because the definite article (alif and lam) is for definition, and they stand in place of the possessive construction. The share of these people is from the Zakat, which is the Divine Purification (الطهارة الإلهية) that we mentioned previously.

### (A Supplementary Note) [Zakat of the Rights of Allah]

Then know—may Allah grant you success—that the matters in which a human acts are all the rights of Allah (حقوق الله). However, these rights, though numerous, are in one respect confined to two divisions. One division is the right of creation upon Allah, which is his (peace and blessings be upon him) saying: "Indeed, your self has a right over you, your eye has a right over you, and your visitor has a right over you." The other division is the right of Allah upon Allah, which is his (peace and blessings be upon him) saying: "I have a time in which none but my Lord can contain me."

### [The Eight Categories of Rights]

This right that belongs to Allah is the Zakat of the rights that creation has upon Allah. These rights, in their totality, fall into eight categories: Knowledge (العلم) and Action (العمل), which are in the position of gold and silver. From the animal kingdom: the Spirit (الروح), the Soul (النفس), and the Body (الجسم), corresponding to sheep, cattle, and camels. From the plant kingdom: wheat, barley, and dates.

### [What the Spirits, Souls, and Limbs Cultivate]

In consideration, what the Spirits (الأرواح), Souls (النفوس), and Limbs (الجوارح) produce—of knowledge, thoughts (خواطر), and actions—is: sheep for the Spirit, cattle for the Soul, and camels for the Body. We assigned sheep to the Spirits because Allah made the ram the ransom for the spirit of a noble Prophet, saying: <<And We ransomed him with a great sacrifice>> (وَفَدَيْنَاهُ بِذِبْحٍ عَظِيمٍ). Thus, He magnified it and made it the ransom for the son of Abraham, a Prophet, son of a Prophet. Therefore, in this consideration, there is no animal of higher degree than sheep, and they are the sacrifices of this Community. Do you not see that [the sheep] was also made the right of Allah in camels—namely, one sheep for every five camels—and one hundred camels were made the ransom for a soul that was neither a Messenger nor a Prophet? Look then at the rank of sheep compared to the rank of camels.

### [Sheep Pens and Camel Resting Places]

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) commanded us to pray in the sheep pens (مرابض الغنم). Prayer is an act of drawing near (قربة) to Allah, and its places are the mosques of Allah. Thus, sheep pens are among the mosques of Allah, possessing the degree of proximity (القربة). Camels do not have this rank, even though they are greater in creation. For this reason, we assigned them to the bodies (الأجسام). Do you not see that one of their names is *al-Badana* (a large sacrificial animal), and the body is called *al-Badan*? The body belongs to the world of Nature (عالم الطبيعة). Nature is two degrees removed from Allah in the cosmos—these are the Soul (النفس) and the Intellect (العقل). Thus, it is in the third degree of proximity, far from Divine Proximity (القرب الإلهي). Do you not see that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) forbade praying in the resting places of camels (معاطن الإبل)? He explained this by saying they are devils (*shayatin*). *Shaytana* (devilishness) means distance. It is said: a well is *shatun* if it is deep-bottomed (far). Prayer is proximity to Allah, and distance contradicts proximity. Thus, praying in camel resting places was forbidden because of the distance inherent in them.

### [The Natural Body and the Spirit]

Likewise, where does the natural body stand compared to the degree of proximity belonging to the Spirit (الروح), which is the Intellect (العقل)? For it is the First Existent (الموجود الأول), and it is what was breathed into [Adam] in His saying: <<And breathed into him from My Spirit>> (وَنَفَخْتُ فِيهِ مِنْ رُوحِي). For this reason, we placed the Spirit in the position of the ram and the Body in the position of the camel.

### [Cattle Corresponding to Souls]

As for cattle (البقر) corresponding to the Souls (النفوس): they are lower in rank than sheep and higher than camels, just as the Soul is above the Body but below the Intellect, which is the Divine Spirit (الروح الإلهي). This is because when the Children of Israel killed a soul (نفسا) and disputed over it, Allah commanded them to slaughter a cow and strike the dead person with a part of it, so that he would come back to life by Allah’s permission. When the soul (نفس) of the dead person was revived by it, we knew there was a correlation (نسبة) between the cow and the Soul, so we assigned it to the Soul.

### [The Cultivation of the Intellect, Soul, and Limbs]

Furthermore, the Spirit, which is the Intellect (العقل), manifests from what Allah has sown within it—of knowledge (علوم), wisdom (حكم), and secrets (أسرار)—what none knows but Allah. All this knowledge, some of which relates to the cosmos (الكون) and some to Allah, is in the position of Zakat from wheat, because wheat is the highest of grains. And the Soul (النفس) manifests from what Allah has sown within it—of thoughts (خواطر) and desires (شهوات)—what none knows but Allah the Almighty. This is its produce, and it is in the position of dates (التمر). The Zakat of Allah from this is the first thought, and from the desires, the desire that is purely for the sake of Allah. We associated it with dates because the date palm is our paternal aunt. It stands in relation to the Intellect as the date palm stands in relation to Adam, for it was created from the remainder of his clay. As for the Limbs (الجوارح), Allah sowed all actions within them, and they produced actions. The share of Zakat from this is the prescribed actions (الأعمال المشروعة) in which Allah is witnessed.

### [Obligation of Zakat in the Actions of Intellect, Soul, and Limbs]

These are eight categories in which Zakat is obligatory. As for Knowledge (العلم), which is in the position of gold, what is obligatory in gold is obligatory in it. As for Action (العمل), which is in the position of silver (الفضة), what is obligatory in silver (الورق) is obligatory in it. As for the Spirit (الروح), what is obligatory in sheep is obligatory in it. As for the Soul (النفس), what is obligatory in cattle is obligatory in it. As for the Limbs (الجوارح), what is obligatory in camels is obligatory in them. As for what the Intellect produces of gnosis (معارف) and cultivates of secrets (أسرار), what is obligatory in wheat is obligatory in it. As for what the Soul produces of desires and thoughts (خواطر) and cultivates of spiritual influxes (واردات), what is obligatory in dates is obligatory in it. As for what the Limbs produce of actions and cultivate of forms of obedience and otherwise, what is obligatory in barley is obligatory in it.

(A Note on the Consideration of Sustenance and Times)

Know that the times (الأوقات) on the Path of Allah for the knowledgeable practitioners (العلماء العاملين) are in the position of sustenance (الأقوات) for the welfare of natural bodies. Just as some sustenance is the Zakat of that category, so too the Divine Time (الوقت الإلهي) is the Zakat of the existential times (الأوقات الكيانية). For in Time there is the nourishment of the Spirits (الأرواح), just as in sustenance there is the nourishment of animal and plant bodies (الأشباح), and the nourishment of the limbs is actions.

### [Knowledge and Action are Two Mines]

Knowledge (العلم) and Action (العمل) are two mines (معدنان). Through their existence, the Divine aims (المقاصد الإلهية) are attained in this world and the Hereafter, just as through gold and silver all aims—of goods and purposes—are attained. Let us clarify what relates to this type and these types concerning the right of Allah, which is Zakat.

(A Note on the Comparison and Balance of the Categories Obligated to Receive Zakat with the Accountable Organs of the Human)

The poor (الفقراء) correspond among the organs to the private parts (الفرج). The needy (المساكين) correspond to the belly (البطن). The workers (العاملين) correspond to the heart (القلب). Those whose hearts are reconciled (المؤلفة قلوبهم) correspond to hearing (السمع). Captives (الرقاب) correspond to sight (البصر). Debtors (الغارمين) correspond to the hand (اليد). Fighters (المجاهدين) correspond to the tongue (اللسان). And the traveler (ابن السبيل) corresponds to the foot (الرجل). If you consider this comparison between these categories and these organs as we have mentioned, you will find the wisdom of what we have indicated. Poverty in the private parts is clear, and likewise, neediness in the belly is manifest. The worker by the heart is explicit. Those whose hearts are reconciled by hearing is evident. Captives by sight is actual. The debtor by the hand is expressive. The fighter by the tongue is sound. And the traveler by the foot is the clearest of all.

(A Note on the Knowledge of Measure by Volume, Weight, and Number)

Muslim narrated from Abu Sa’id al-Khudri that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "There is no Zakat on grain or dates until it reaches five *awsuq* (measures), nor is there Zakat on less than five camels (ذود), nor is there Zakat on less than five *awāq*."

He meant silver (الورق).

### [What the Realization of the Divine Names Cultivates in the Human]

He made the *wasq* (measure) for grains, which are plants. It is a known measure, sixty *sa’s*. Five *awsuq* is three hundred *sa’s*. This is what the realization of the Names—meaning the Divine characteristics (الأخلاق الإلهية)—cultivates in the human, because we have narrated that Allah has three hundred characteristics (خلق); whoever realizes one of them enters Paradise. All of them are characteristics that a human employs with creatures and with whomever they should be employed, according to Allah’s command. The Zakat from this is the characteristic he employs with Allah, for He is the most worthy of being treated with good character. It is impossible for a human to achieve the satisfaction of the world through his characteristics. Prioritizing the Divine Presence (جناب الله) is more fitting, which is to employ with every category the Divine characteristic that Allah employed with them, thus being in conformity with the Real (الحق).

### [The Numerical and Conceptual Count]

And His saying: "Nor is there Zakat on less than five camels (ذود)." This is from the count of fixed entities (الأعيان), and only action (العمل) is counted as a fixed entity, not knowledge (العلم), for the measure of knowledge is conceptual (معنوي) and the measure of action is sensory (حسي).

### [The Symbolism of the Number Forty]

"Nor is there Zakat on less than five *awāq*." An *ūqiyya* is forty *dirhams*. The forty in the *ūqiyya* is analogous to the forty mornings (أربعين صباحا): whoever perfects them, the springs of wisdom flow from his heart onto his tongue. If [this wisdom] manifests from the servant in five states, just as there are five *awāq* in Zakat: a state in his outward aspect, which is one *ūqiyya* (outward sincerity); a state in his inward aspect, likewise; a state in his limit, likewise; a state in his rising, likewise; and a state in the totality, likewise. These are five states multiplied by forty, resulting in two hundred, which is the threshold (*nisab*). In it, there are five *dirhams* [of Zakat]. This is what relates to every forty of the Oneness (التوحيد) appropriate to that type. The measures of meanings (المعاني) and Spirits (الأرواح) are estimations, derived from His saying: <<And they did not appraise Allah with true appraisal>> (وَمَا قَدَرُوا اللَّهَ حَقَّ قَدْرِهِ). The measures of sensory things, which are actions, are weights. And by weights, the estimations are known.

(A Note on the Timing of What is Irrigated and What is Not)

Al-Bukhari mentioned from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) that for what is irrigated by effort (النضح), the Zakat is half of the tenth, and for what is not irrigated by effort, the Zakat is the tenth.

(And its Consideration)

[This relates to] the actions of the Sought (المراد) and the actions of the Seeker (المريد). The Seeker is with his self for his Lord, so half of the tenth is obligatory upon him, which means he purifies from his action what his self (نفسه) manifested in it. The Sought is with his Lord, not with his self, so the tenth is obligatory upon him, which is his entire self, because the burden has been lifted from him. Likewise, the consideration applies to gifted knowledge (العلم الموهوب) and acquired knowledge (العلم المكتسب). Only half of the acquired knowledge is purely for Allah, while the gifted knowledge is entirely for Allah. The totality refers only to the measure of Zakat, which is what is attributed to Allah from that knowledge or action, and what is attributed to the servant insofar as the servant is present with his self in that knowledge or action.

(A Note on Disbursing Zakat from a Different Category than the Purified Item)

For every five camels (ذود), there is one sheep.

Indeed, to Allah belongs the pure religion (الدين الخالص). Thus, the Zakat of actions is sincerity (الإخلاص), and sincerity is not an action, due to its need for sincerity, which is intention (النية).

(A Note on Separating Partners in Zakat)

Al-Daraqutni mentioned from Sa’d ibn Abi Waqqas that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "The two partners (الخليطان) are those who gather at the watering trough, the shepherd, and the stud camel."

(A Note on the Consideration of That)

His saying, the Almighty: <<And cooperate in righteousness and piety>> (وَتَعَاوَنُوا عَلَى الْبِرِّ وَالتَّقْوَى). Cooperation in a thing means sharing in it, and this is the meaning of the two partners (الخليطين).

### [The Meaning of the Trough]

The trough (الحوض) is every action or knowledge that leads to the life of the hearts. They seek help for it according to what each one needs from the other in it. In the human, the heart and the limb are two partners. The limb helps the heart with action, and the heart helps the limb with sincerity (الإخلاص). Thus, they are partners in the action they undertake or the knowledge they seek.

### [The Meaning of the Shepherd]

As for the shepherd (الراعي), he is the meaning that preserves that action, which is presence (الحضور) and recollection (الاستحضار). For example, in prayer, one cannot turn his face away from the *Qibla*, nor can he intend by that worship anything other than his Lord. This is the preservation of that worship, and the heart and the senses are partners in it.

### [The Meaning of the Stud Camel]

As for the stud camel (الفحل), it is the cause that necessitates the acceptance and reward that that knowledge or action produces with Allah. They are partners in the reward. Thus, the Soul (النفس) takes what is appropriate for it from what the knowledge grants, and the sense (الحس) of the body takes what is appropriate for it from the beauty of form in the Hereafter. The meaning that produced this for them is the stud camel, and they are partners in it.

(A Note on What Actions Have No Zakat)

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "There is no Zakat on working animals (العوامل) nor on the forehead (الجبهة)." This hadith was narrated by Al-Daraqutni from Ali (may Allah be pleased with him). The working animals are the camels used for labor, and the forehead refers to horses. The discussion of Zakat on horses has already preceded.

(A Note on the Consideration of That)

The physical structures (الهياكل) are the working animals of the Spirits (الأرواح), because the Spirits perform the commanded actions upon them, and the actions occur through them. There is no Zakat upon the worker in his body; rather, the Zakat is upon the Spirit working through it. Its Zakat is its intention and its piety (تقواه), which is sincerity (الإخلاص) to Allah in that action. Allah the Almighty said: <<Never will their meat reach Allah, nor their blood, but what reaches Him is piety from you>> (لَنْ يَنَالَ اللَّهَ لُحُومُهَا وَلَا دِمَاؤُهَا وَلَكِنْ يَنَالُهُ التَّقْوَى مِنْكُمْ).

(A Note on Disbursing Zakat from the Same Category)

Abu Dawud narrated from Mu’adh ibn Jabal that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) sent him to Yemen and said: "Take grain from grain, a sheep from sheep, a camel from camels, and cattle from cattle."

(A Note on the Consideration of That)

The Zakat of the outward is what the Sacred Law (الشرع) restricts it to, concerning obligatory actions that have a resemblance in the recommended actions. The obligatory prayer is the Zakat of the supererogatory prayers, for it is the obligatory one, or a prayer a person vows upon himself, or any act of worship. Likewise, in the inward, the Zakat is of its own kind: that the motive for worship be fear or hope. The Zakat in the inward motive is that it be what the Lordship (الربوبية) deserves, which is compliance with its command and prohibition, without desire [for Paradise] or fear [of Hell].

(A Note on What is Not Taken in Charity)

Abu Dawud mentioned in the letter of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him): "No decrepit animal (هرمة), nor one with a defect (ذات عوار), nor a stud ram (تيس الغنم) shall be taken in charity, unless the collector wishes."

(A Note on the Consideration of That)

The decrepit animal (الهرمة) is like His saying: <<And when they stand for prayer, they stand lazily>> (وَإِذَا قَامُوا إِلَى الصَّلَاةِ قَامُوا كُسَالَى). And He said: "Let one of you pray with his enthusiasm." The one with a defect (ذات عوار) is action without intention, or intention without action, despite the ability to act and the absence of impediment. As for the collector’s wish regarding the stud ram, its consideration is that he should not be unjust to the owner of the wealth, which is presence (الحضور) in the action from beginning to end. Perhaps he says: "The action is not accepted unless it is like this." However, intention at the beginning of the action is sufficient for the action, and the accountable person is not burdened with more than this. If the accountable person maintains the intention throughout the entire action, he is permitted that, and he is thanked for it, as he has perfected his action and brought the most precious thing into it. The comprehensive principle for this chapter is avoiding what blemishes acts of worship, such as looking around in prayer, fidgeting in it, talking to oneself about forbidden or disliked things, imagining them, and similar defects, which are like the *ja’rur* (a bad kind of date) and the color of the *hubayq* (a bad kind of date) in the Zakat of dates, and similar defects.

(A Note on the Zakat of Silver)

### [Silver is Action and Gold is Knowledge]

It has preceded that silver (الورق) is Action (العمل) and gold (الذهب) is Knowledge (العلم). The Zakat in action is the obligatory part of it, and the Zakat in knowledge is also the obligatory part of it. For the supererogatory actions and knowledge are numerous, and their Zakat is the obligatory duties, because Zakat is obligatory. As for the supererogatory acts that are voluntary charity (صدقة تطوع), they are the servant’s presence in that action from its beginning to its end. And there is another Zakat—meaning voluntary Zakat—which is that he intends by that action the completion of the obligatory duties.

### [Completing Obligatory Duties with Supererogatory Acts]

It was narrated from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) that he said: "The first thing examined in the servant’s action is the prayer. If it is complete, it is written as complete for him. If something is missing from it, [Allah] says: 'Look, does My servant have any supererogatory acts?' If he has supererogatory acts, Allah says: 'Complete My servant’s obligatory duty from his supererogatory acts.' Then the actions are taken in the same manner."

Meaning Zakat, fasting, Hajj, and the rest of the obligatory duties upon him. As for intending by that supererogatory act the completion of the obligatory duties, or magnifying the Divine Presence (جناب الحق) by entering into the servanthood of choice (عبودية الاختيار), without being driven by greed for Paradise or fear of Hell.

(A Note on the Zakat of the Treasure Trove)

Muslim narrated in his *Sahih* from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) that for the treasure trove (الركاز), the Zakat is one-fifth (الخمس). This is wealth found in the earth, buried by the people of ignorance or the disbelievers.

(A Note on the Consideration of That)

What is embedded (مركوز) in the human nature (طبيعة الإنسان) is the treasure trove (الركاز), which is the love of leadership (الرئاسة), precedence over one’s peers, attracting benefits, and repelling harms. The one-fifth (الخمس) in it is:

### [Zakat of Leadership and Precedence over One’s Peers]

If he finds leadership in his heart, he should intend by it the exaltation of the Word of Allah (كلمة الله) over the word of those who disbelieve, as it is in reality. For in reality, the Word of Allah is the highest, and <<the word of those who disbelieved is the lowest>> (وَكَلِمَةَ الَّذِينَ كَفَرُوا السُّفْلَى). Disbelief (*kufr*) here means polytheism (*shirk*) and nothing else. And as the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) mentioned concerning arrogance (*khuyala’*) in war, regarding Abu Dujana, when he took the sword from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) with its right, and walked with it drawn arrogantly between the ranks. When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) saw him in that state, he said: "This is a walk that Allah and His Messenger hate, except in this situation." Its Zakat is what we mentioned: intending to humiliate the disbelievers, diminish their status, exalt the Word of Allah, which is Islam, and disregard the polytheists.

### [Zakat of Attracting Benefits and Repelling Harms]

Likewise, attracting benefits and repelling harms. The Zakat of attracting benefits is that he intends by the benefit assistance for performing obedience to Allah, whether it be sleep, eating, drinking, rest, or saving money, and similar things. As for repelling harms, it is that he repels them only because they prevent him from establishing obedience to Allah and His religion, and what leads to happiness in the Hereafter. That is the one-fifth of its treasure trove. If you ask how it harms his religion, I mean that if he does not repel that harm from himself, it will prevent him from performing an obligatory duty of Allah or prevent him from means of goodness. Repelling it is the one-fifth of its treasure trove, which is in his nature, of repelling harms that do not lead to the abandonment of an obligatory duty incumbent upon him or a recommended act. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) was asked about the treasure trove (الركاز) and he said: "It is the gold that Allah created in the earth the day He created the heavens and the earth." He meant minerals.

(A Note on One Whom Allah Provides Wealth Without Effort or Earning)

It was narrated in the tradition from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) that he said concerning the acquisition of such wealth: "There is no Zakat on it until a year has passed," while it is in his possession.

The aspect of consideration for this is what manifests upon the servant of noble characteristics (مكارم الأخلاق) that he does not perform as an act of drawing near (قربة) to Allah. He benefits from this in the Hereafter, and he is not necessarily required to intend proximity to Allah, but without dispute, if he intends proximity by it, it is more fitting and better for him. The hadith narrated concerning this is what Abu Dawud mentioned from Duba’a bint al-Zubayr, who said: Al-Miqdad went out for his need, and behold, a rat came out of a hole with a *dinar*. Then it kept bringing out *dinar* after *dinar* until it brought out seventeen *dinars*. Then it brought out a *dinar* in a red cloth, making nineteen *dinars*. He took them to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) and informed him, saying: "Take its charity." The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said to him: "Did you approach the hole?" He said: "No." The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said to him: "May Allah bless you in it."

(A Note on the Zakat of the Intended)

The narrator (may Allah be pleased with him) said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) used to command us to disburse charity from what we prepared for sale.

(A Note on the Consideration of That)

If a person speaks to himself inwardly about performing a good deed or adopting a noble characteristic (خلق كريم) from noble characteristics, he should intend by what he spoke to himself the proximity (القربة) to Allah.

(A Note on Charity Before Its Due Time)

Some Imams held this opinion, based on the hadith of Abu Dawud from Ali ibn Abi Talib (may Allah be pleased with him) that Al-Abbas asked the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) about advancing his charity before it was due, and he permitted him. He said another time: "He authorized him." There is discussion about this hadith, but even if it is authentic, it is a concession in a specific case and cannot be used for analogy.

(A Note on the Consideration of That)

The intention for the obligatory prayer upon the accountable person is only obligatory at the moment of commencing it. If a person intends it before that, from the moment he begins ablution, and then maintains the intention until he commences the prayer, it is permissible for him, and he gains much good. However, a prayer restricted by time is not valid before the time enters, except according to the school of thought that permits combining two prayers at the beginning of the first time. Thus, it is not far-fetched to permit advancing charity, taking comfort in His saying: <<Those hasten to good deeds, and they are forerunners thereof>> (أُولَئِكَ يُسَارِعُونَ فِي الْخَيْرَاتِ وَهُمْ لَهَا سَابِقُونَ).

### [Looking at the Betrothed Woman]

An example of this in consideration is one who is permitted to look at the woman he intends to marry, but refrains from doing so out of shyness before Allah and caution against exceeding the necessary gaze, so he does not look until the marriage contract is concluded. I have a division regarding looking at the betrothed woman: if the betrothed woman is from the progeny of the Ansar, and he did not look at her before the contract, he is disobedient. If he looked at her face before the contract, his looking was an act of proximity to Allah and obedience to His Messenger (peace and blessings be upon him). As for a non-Ansari woman, this is not the case, although if he looks, it is more fitting if he proposes marriage.

### [The Basmala is the Key to Every Surah]

As for what we mentioned about combining two prayers, if the second is joined to the first, inwardly this means finding in the *Basmala* (In the Name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful) the spirit of the *Fatiha* or the *Surah* he intends to recite, for the *Basmala* is the key to every *Surah*.

(A Note on the Zakat of Breaking the Fast - Zakat al-Fitr)

Scholars differed regarding the ruling on *Zakat al-Fitr*. Some say it is an obligation (*fard*), some say it is a recommended practice (*sunnah*), and some say it is abrogated by Zakat [on wealth].

(Consideration of *Fitr*)

<<[All] praise is [due] to Allah, Originator (فَاطِرِ) of the heavens and the earth>> (الْحَمْدُ لِلَّهِ فَاطِرِ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ). <<Did not those who disbelieve see that the heavens and the earth were a joined entity, and We separated them?>> (أَوَلَمْ يَرَ الَّذِينَ كَفَرُوا أَنَّ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضَ كَانَتَا رَتْقًا فَفَتَقْنَاهُمَا). *Fitr* (فطر) is the separation (*fatq*). From this comes the saying that every newborn is born upon the primordial nature (*fitra*).

### [The First Separation of Names and Tongues, and the Meaning of the Fasting People and the People of Paradise]

The first thing Allah separated (*fataqa*) was the hearing of the created things (المكونات) at the moment of their existence—which is the state of the Power’s (القدرة) connection between non-existence and Existence (الوجود)—by His saying "Be" (*kun*), so they exist by themselves upon this address, in compliance with Allah’s command. That is the word of the Presence (الحضرة). The first thing He separated their hearing with, while they were in the First Existence, was His saying: <<Am I not your Lord?>> (أَلَسْتُ بِرَبِّكُمْ). So they said: <<Yes>> (قَالُوا بَلَى). This is specific to humans, while the creation (*takwin*) is general. The first thing He separated their tongues with was their saying "Yes." The first thing He separated the stomachs of the fasting people with was what they ate on the day of Eid al-Fitr before going out to the prayer ground. The first thing He separated the stomachs of the People of Paradise with was their eating the extra lobe of the whale’s liver.

### [What the Servant Must Know Regarding Zakat al-Fitr on Eid Day]

The servant should know regarding *Zakat al-Fitr* on Eid day that the quality of Self-Sufficiency (الصفة الصمدانية) belongs only to Allah the Almighty, for fasting is for Allah, not for the servant. This Zakat is an obligation upon every person—free or slave, young or old, male or female—to know what the Lordship (الربوبية) deserves of the quality of Self-Sufficiency. Furthermore, according to us, it is not valid except from dates and barley; anything else is not valid. According to the majority of scholars, it is permissible from any staple food, but this is a matter of dispute.

### [Sustenance of Bodies and Sustenance of Spirits]

Sustenance (*al-qut*) is what sustains this natural constitution (النشأة الطبيعية). The sustenance of the Spirits (قوت الأرواح) is what they are nourished by, of the knowledge of Unveiling (علوم الكشف) or faith (الإيمان) specifically. For by this measure of knowledge, the constitution of the rational Spirits is sustained, and their Zakat is the knowledge of Unveiling specifically.

(A Note on Its Obligation Upon the Rich and the Poor, the Free and the Slave, the Male and the Female, the Young and the Old)

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) made it obligatory upon every two: young or old, learner and scholar.

### [Freedom and Servitude]

And his saying: "free or slave." The free person is one who is liberated from the servitude of the existent things (رق الأكوان), so his time is the witnessing of his freedom from them. The slave is one whose time is the witnessing of servanthood (العبودية) without looking at the existent things.

### [Masculinity and Femininity]

And his saying: "male or female." In the male is the Intellect (العقل), and in the female is the Soul (النفس). It is also considered in them: the male is the one who contemplates Divine Knowledge (العلم الإلهي), and the female is the one who contemplates the knowledge of Nature (علم الطبيعة). Thus, every contemplator is attributed to what is appropriate for him based on what he contemplates.

### [Wealth and Poverty]

And his saying: "rich or poor." Rich through Allah (غني بالله) or poor toward Allah (فقير إلى الله).

### [The Four Measures, the Four Humors, the Four Stages, and the Four Relations]

And his saying: "a *sa’* of dates." The *sa’* is four *amdad* (measures). Its constitution is a *sa’* from four humors (أخلاط), one *mudd* for each pillar or humor, for the completion of its constitution: Spirit, Intellect, Body, and Rank. Then, his witnessing in it the four relations (النسب) by which he describes his Lord in the creation of his essence and the principles of his existence: Life, Knowledge, Will, and Power. One *mudd* for each attribute, so the total is a *sa’*, since by these relations it is valid for Him to be a Lord and for you to be a servant (مربوب) of Allah the Almighty.

(A Note on Disbursing Zakat al-Fitr for Everyone One Supports)

Al-Daraqutni mentioned from the hadith of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) that he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) commanded *Zakat al-Fitr* for the young and the old, the free and the slave, from those whom you support (تمونون).

(A Note on the Consideration of That)

The master (الأستاذ) intends for the disciple (التلميذ) in spiritual training (التربية) what the disciple’s knowledge cannot reach, until the benefit intended by the Shaykh is achieved for him. That is the Zakat of his teaching. If that intended favor returns to the disciple, then the disciple has given to the master because of the favor that returns to him. The master may receive an opening (فتح) through the disciple’s sincerity regarding something he did not possess. This issue also includes the guardian (الولي) purifying the wealth of the orphan under his care and supervision.

(A Note on Disbursing It for the Jew and the Christian)

Abu al-Hasan al-Daraqutni (may Allah have mercy on him) mentioned in his book from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him)—meaning the disbursement of *Zakat al-Fitr* for the Jew and the Christian.

(The Consideration of That)

The intention of goodness in action for one who is not of your kind returns its favor to you. I believe in what the Jew and the Christian believe in, of what is true in their religion and their book, based on my faith in my Book. Allah the Almighty said: <<And the believers, all of them have believed in Allah and His angels and His books and His messengers, [saying], 'We make no distinction between any of His messengers'>> (وَالْمُؤْمِنُونَ كُلٌّ آمَنَ بِاللَّهِ وَمَلَائِكَتِهِ وَكُتُبِهِ وَرُسُلِهِ لَا نُفَرِّقُ بَيْنَ أَحَدٍ مِنْ رُسُلِهِ). From that perspective, he disburses it for them, for they are also among those I support, since my Book encompasses their book, and my religion encompasses their religion. Thus, their religion and their book are subsumed within my Book and my religion.

### [The Soul, If It Associates in Action, Seeks Its Share]

If the Soul (النفس) associates in the action, it seeks its share. It is in the position of the Jew and the Christian who say that Ezra is the son of Allah and the Messiah is the son of Allah. The believer must disburse Zakat for it while it is in this state. For the Prophet (peace be upon him) stood up for a Jewish funeral and said: "Is it not a soul (نفسا)?"

### [The Christian is Derived from Help, and the Jew from Guidance]

This is the consideration for disbursing Zakat for the Jew and the Christian. This is if you consider the meaning. If you consider the derivation of the word from *nusra* (help) and *huda* (guidance), then the Zakat for them is the intention for the Face of Allah (وجه الله) and nothing else. End of the Fifty-Second Part.

(In the Name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful)

(A Note on the Time for Disbursing Zakat al-Fitr)

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) commanded that *Zakat al-Fitr* be paid before the people go out to the prayer ground.

(The Consideration of That)

Haste in delivering comfort to those in need of it. Then he goes out to the prayer ground, which is His saying: <<Then present before your private consultation a charity>> (فَقَدِّمُوا بَيْنَ يَدَيْ نَجْوَاكُمْ صَدَقَةً). The one praying is consulting his Lord privately, and he is going out to the prayer ground, so that is better and purer for him.

(A Note on Transgression in Charity)

The narrator reported from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) that he said: "The transgressor in charity is like the withholder of it." Narrated by Abu Dawud.

(The Consideration of That)

Your self has a right over you, and your eye has a right over you. If you burden it beyond its capacity, you weaken it, which leads to the abandonment of much good. Thus, you are in the position of the withholder of good, even in the very thing you desire of good. You know that the soul exists only through these limbs. If the instruments are disabled and weakened from action by being initially subjected to severe labor, you are like the withholder of action. We have a saying regarding this meaning:

> What the meticulous craftsman does in the work of his instruments,
> He has permitted its corruption.

And increasing the limit is a deficiency in the limited thing.

(A Note on the Zakat of Honey)

Al-Tirmidhi mentioned from Ibn Umar from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) concerning honey: "In every ten *azqāq* (skins), there is one *ziqq*."

(The Consideration of That)

The knowledge that the saint (الولي) receives through revelation (الوحي) concerning others must be disseminated to its people, for it was given to him for their sake. We specified it to revelation rather than other attributes, because the attributes for acquiring knowledge are many. We likened it to honey, which is the result of revelation. Allah the Almighty said: <<And your Lord inspired to the bee>> (وَأَوْحَى رَبُّكَ إِلَى النَّحْلِ). Its Zakat is teaching it.

(A Note on Zakat Being Obligatory on the Free, Not on Slaves)

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "There is no Zakat on the wealth of the *mukātab* (slave under contract) until he is freed." Mentioned by Al-Daraqutni from the hadith of Jabir.

(The Consideration of That)

Just as it is not permissible for the slave to take charity—it was said that this is why the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) was prevented from charity, due to his realization of his servanthood (عبوديته), so nothing proceeded from him (peace and blessings be upon him) in movement or stillness that would make him free through heedlessness or otherwise, absolutely—likewise, Zakat is not obligatory on his wealth until he is free. For the slave does not own anything with his master. The reason for Zakat on the free person is the claim of ownership, and the slave has no claim to anything. The slave is the very essence of his value, which is the price he was bought for. Just as no claim or refusal can be conceived regarding his price concerning what the master wishes to dispose of, so too the slave. Any slave whose contemplation is not focused on his price in his dealings with his master has no realization of his servanthood and no knowledge of his self. This is the undisputed doctrine of the Sufi community (الطائفة).

### [The Origin of Manifestation is Claim]

When the servant is in this state with his master, the servant disappears and the Master manifests. For the origin of manifestation (الظهور) is the claim. In this state, the Master appears to others with the attribute of the servant, in honor of the servant. This is His saying, the Almighty: "I was hungry, and you did not feed Me," and "I was sick, and you did not visit Me." Hunger and sickness are attributes of servants. Likewise, Allah said in the answer: "So-and-so was sick, and you did not visit him. Had you visited him, you would have found Me with him." Thus, Allah is with a servant whose attribute is this, and when the servant’s attribute is this, he is with his Lord. Understand.

(A Note on Where Charities Are Taken)

Abu Dawud narrated from the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) that charity is only taken in their dwellings (دورهم). The dwelling (*dār*) of the human is his body. The taking of charities from human Spirits (الأرواح الإنسانية) is only in the Hereafter. Therefore, the resurrection of bodies is necessary, for charities are only taken from those upon whom they are obligatory in their dwelling, and the Spirits of humans have no dwellings except their bodies.

(A Note on the Imam Taking Half the Wealth of One Who Withholds Zakat After Taking Zakat From Him)

Abu Dawud mentioned that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said in a hadith about taking Zakat: "And whoever withholds it, I will take it and half of his wealth, as a decree (عزمة) from the decrees of our Lord." What a person owns of his actions is divided into two parts: a part specific to his self, and a part specific to his limbs. The Zakat obligatory upon him in his action is what Allah has prescribed for him of his actions, both recommended and permissible. If he does not pay the Zakat of his wealth, Allah looks at the actions he performed during the time when the fulfillment of Allah’s obligation was due. If they were noble characteristics (مكارم الأخلاق), He does not reward him for them with the recompense he deserves, but withholds that reward as the Zakat of the action of his time. If they were base characteristics (سفسافها), He doubles the burden upon him, for he is the author of a blameworthy action while neglecting to fulfill what was obligatory upon him, thus combining two blameworthy things: action and neglect. If the action was merely permissible, He takes him to task only for neglecting the obligatory duty.

### [Taking Half the Wealth from the Zakat Withholder]

As for taking half of his action, it is the half in which the claim [of ownership] can be conceived, which is the action. For accountability is divided into action and neglect. Neglect has no claim in it, so the action remains. The Real (الحق) takes it from him by the argument that Allah is the Doer of that action. When he is unveiled to this, he no longer has a claim for reward, since the reward is based on his being the doer, and it has become clear to him that the Doer is Allah. He remains in confusion until Allah bestows favor upon him, either after punishment or before punishment, and forgives him. This is the half of his wealth that is taken from him in the Hereafter, where accountability is conceived.

(A Note on the Satisfaction of the Zakat Collector)

Al-Harith ibn Abi Usama mentioned in his *Musnad* from Anas that a man from Banu Sulaym came and said: "O Messenger of Allah, if I pay Zakat to your messenger, am I absolved of it before Allah and His Messenger?" The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Yes, if you pay it to My messenger, you are absolved of it, and you have its reward, and the sin is upon the one who alters it."

Abu Dawud also mentioned from the hadith of Jabir that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Riders who are disliked will come to you. When they come to you, welcome them and leave them to what they seek. If they are just, it is for their own selves, and if they are unjust, it is against them. And satisfy them, for the completion of your Zakat is their satisfaction, and let them pray for you."

In his hadith also, from Bashir ibn al-Khasasiyya, he said: "We said, 'O Messenger of Allah, the collectors of charity transgress against us. Should we conceal some of our wealth equal to what they transgress against us?' He said: 'No.'"

(The Consideration of That)

The collector of charity is the Time (الوقت), and his satisfaction is that you fulfill what his state requires of what he brought, even if he came with severity and coercion, like the thought (خاطر) a person finds in an action—meaning an action of goodness—except that it is difficult, perhaps leading to destruction. Abu Madyan (may Allah be pleased with him) used to say that the blood money is upon the killer. Allah the Almighty said concerning the emigrant: <<Then death overtakes him, his reward has already fallen upon Allah>> (ثُمَّ يُدْرِكْهُ الْمَوْتُ فَقَدْ وَقَعَ أَجْرُهُ عَلَى اللَّهِ). The form of transgression in this is that Allah has made your self have a right over you, and your eye have a right over you, and you transgressed against yourself in that. This is His saying concerning the chosen ones: <<Among them is he who wrongs himself>> (فَمِنْهُمْ ظَالِمٌ لِنَفْسِهِ). The transgressor is the Time, which is the thought that occurs with what occurred. He is the transgressor, and he is the just one.

(A Note on Hastening Charity)

Muslim ibn al-Hajjaj mentioned in his *Sahih* from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) that he said: "Give charity, for soon a man will walk with his charity, and the one he gives it to will say: 'Had you brought it to us yesterday, we would have accepted it. But now, I have no need for it.' So he will not find anyone to accept it."

(The Consideration of That)

Haste in repentance (التوبة), which is one of the obligatory duties. If he delays it until the moment of death, it is not accepted. Here is a subtle issue that few of our companions stumble upon.

### [The Most Difficult States for the Heart of the Sought/Attracted]

It is that the Sought (المراد) may not be repentant, yet he receives an Unveiling (كشف) from Allah, as a favor to him. The first thing unveiled to him is that Allah is the Creator of everything. He sees no movement, outward or inward, no action, no intention, and nothing of the affair belonging to himself, but only to Allah. Is repentance conceivable from him in this state or not, when he sees himself stripped of actions? And if he repents, is his repentance accepted with this Unveiling, or is he like one who repents after the sun rises from the west? For the sun of Reality (شمس الحقيقة) has risen for him here from the west of his heart, through the soundness of his knowledge. This is one of the most difficult states for the heart of the Sought/Attracted (المراد المجذوب). For the acceptance of repentance and the acceptance of action only occur with the veil (الحجاب)—the veil of attributing the action to you. Here, nothing proceeded from him for Him to accept it; rather, it is in His hands, and acceptance only comes from another.

### [The Relation of the Contemplator and the Relation of the Doer]

Know that the relationship of the observer (الناظر) is not the relationship of the agent (العامل). The observer accepts from the agent, and the agent is the one who acts upon this Essence (الذات) which is the locus of the manifestation of the action, whatever that action may be. Thus, repentance is conceived from the possessor of this Unveiling (الكشف), and Allah is the Acceptor of Repentance (التواب) here. This is the utmost limit of his witnessing (مشهده). Therefore, let him hasten to acts of obedience, whatever his state may be, and let him not pause, for the breaths are not his own. There is no obligation (تكليف) except here and on the Day of Resurrection, when they are called to prostration (السجود)—a prostration of distinction (تمييز), not a prostration of trial (ابتلاء). In the call to prostration in the Hereafter, those who prostrated to Allah will be distinguished from those who prostrated out of fear or hypocrisy. In the world (الدنيا), they were not distinguished due to the mixing of forms.

[Section on the effect that charity (الصدقة) contains regarding the Divine Relations (النسب الإلهية) and others]

Among these is His saying, the Exalted: <<وَمَا أَنفَقْتُم مِّن شَيْءٍ فَهُوَ يُخْلِفُهُ>> (And whatever thing you spend [in His cause]—He will compensate [for] it). Muslim recorded in his *Sahih* on the authority of Abu Hurayrah, who said that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There is no day upon which the servants awaken except that two angels descend. One of them says: 'O Allah, grant compensation (خلفا) to the spender.' And the other says: 'O Allah, grant destruction (تلفا) to the withholder.'"

### [Identity is the Essence itself, and the compensation for what is given in charity]

Look, O my brother, how He made His Identity (هويته) a compensation (خلفا) for your spending, and how you gave life to the one upon whom you bestowed charity, so Allah gave you eternal life (حياة أبدية) through it. For if The Real (الحق) is not your life, then there is no life. If you were to say that the *ya* should be in the accusative and the *lam* in the nominative [a grammatical point], we would reply: Identity (الهوية) is the Essence (الذات) itself, and Identity is the compensation for the thing given in charity by a Divine Name (اسم إلهي) through which the life of that spender comes to be. His Names are not other than Him, but this is how the expression concerning them occurs, due to the difference in the Relations (النسب) understood therein. Our discussion of these meanings is only with our companions who already know what we are saying and what we are pointing to, based on what has been established in our technical terminology (الاصطلاح) concerning this. Therefore, the objection of the outsider is not accepted.

### [The tongue of the angels is a tongue of goodness]

Do you not see the angel saying, "O Allah, grant compensation to the spender," even though He has promised compensation, and His promise is true? Spending (الإنفاق) here implies destruction and annihilation—that is, he annihilated what he had, and there is no void. So, put in its place that which corresponds to its effect upon the one for whom it was annihilated. Thus, he receives the reward of one who gives life. Do you not see the other [angel] saying, "O Allah, grant destruction to the withholder"? This is because the angels are a tongue of goodness. This angel is saying: "O Allah, grant the withholder what You granted the spender, so that his wealth is destroyed like his companion's." It is as if he is saying: "O Allah, grant the withholder the ability to spend, so that he may spend. But if You have not decreed in Your prior Knowledge (علمك) that he will spend by his own choice, then destroy his wealth so that You may reward him with the reward of the afflicted. Thus, he attains goodness." And You have said: <<وَلِلَّهِ يَسْجُدُ مَن فِي السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ طَوْعًا وَكَرْهًا>> (And to Allah prostrates whoever is in the heavens and the earth, willingly or unwillingly). This person's wealth has been destroyed unwillingly, so prepare for him the reward of one who found comfort through it, even if the one afflicted by the destruction of his wealth did not intend it. This is a prayer for goodness for him, not what is assumed by one who has no Gnosis (معرفة) of the Levels (مراتب) of the angels, for an angel does not pray for evil, especially concerning a believer in His Existence (وجوده), let alone in His Unity (توحيده), let alone in what comes from Him.

### [The prayer of the angel is answered]

There is no doubt that the prayer of the angel is answered for two reasons: first, his purity; and second, it is a prayer on behalf of another. It is a prayer for the owner of the wealth by a tongue that has not disobeyed Him, which is the tongue of the angel. This is also found in the tongue of the children of Adam, despite their tongues being disobedient. However, Allah the Exalted said to Moses, peace be upon him: "Pray to Me with a tongue with which you have not disobeyed Me." Moses asked, "And what is that?" He replied, "The prayer of your brother for you, and your prayer for him. For neither of you has disobeyed Me with the tongue of the other when praying to Me on his behalf. Thus, he has only prayed to Me with a pure tongue."

He attributed the prayer to him because the supplicant is a deputy (نائب) for the one prayed for, and the tongue of the supplicant has not been used by the one prayed for to disobey Allah.

### [Your spending causes The Real to spend upon you]

Also among these is what Muslim recorded on the authority of Abu Hurayrah, who said that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, said to me: 'Spend, and I shall spend upon you.'"

Thus, Allah the Exalted has informed us that your spending causes The Real (الحق) to spend upon you. This is among the effect of charity (الصدقة) in the Divine Relation (النسبة الإلهية).

### [Charity extinguishes the wrath of the Lord]

Among these is what Al-Tirmidhi mentioned on the authority of Anas ibn Malik, who said that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, charity extinguishes the wrath of the Lord and wards off an evil death (ميتة السوء)." This is a good and rare *hadith*. This effect of charity is the warding off and the extinguishing of the fire of wrath. For Allah will be angry on the Day of Resurrection with a wrath unlike any He has been angry with before, and unlike any He will be angry with after, in a manner befitting His Majesty (جلاله). The wrath with which He addresses us is undoubtedly known, but its relation (نسبته) to Allah is unknown—not that the wrath itself is unknown, or that it should be interpreted based on what it produces in the angry person, or that it should be interpreted as another meaning unknown to us. For if that were the case, we would be addressed with what we do not understand, and it would have no effect on us and would not serve as an admonition. The purpose is to make us understand through what we know. However, we are ignorant only of the Relation (النسبة) specifically, due to our ignorance of the One to Whom it is related, not the thing related. Know this.

### [What happened to one of Ibn Arabi's Shaykhs in the Far West]

Indeed, something happened to one of our Shaykhs, one of the people of balance (أهل الموازنة), in the Far West (المغرب الأقصى). Matters were raised to the Sultan concerning him that necessitated his execution. The Sultan ordered him to be brought in chains and commanded the people to gather entirely so that he could question them about him.
