The people were unanimous in their desire to kill him and in asserting what necessitated that, namely his heresy (زندقته). On his way, the Shaykh passed by a man selling bread and said to him, "Lend me half a loaf." The man lent it to him, and the Shaykh gave it in charity to a passerby. Then he was carried and seated before that great assembly. The ruler had resolved that if the people testified against him regarding what was mentioned, he would kill him in the worst manner, and the ruler was among those who hated him most. The ruler said, "O people of Marrakesh, this is so-and-so. What do you say about him?" They all spoke with one tongue, saying that he was a righteous and acceptable man. The ruler was astonished. The Shaykh said to him, "Do not be astonished, for this matter is not far-fetched. Which wrath is greater: your wrath, or the wrath of Allah and the wrath of the Fire?" The ruler said, "The wrath of Allah and the wrath of the Fire." The Shaykh asked, "And which protection is greater in weight and value: half a loaf or half a date?" The ruler said, "Half a loaf." The Shaykh said, "I repelled your wrath and the wrath of this assembly with half a loaf, because I heard the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, say: 'Protect yourselves from the Fire, even with half a date,' and he said: 'Indeed, charity extinguishes the wrath of the Lord and wards off an evil death.' Allah has done just that: He warded off your evil and an evil death from me with half a loaf, despite your insignificance and the greatness of my charity. For my charity is greater than half a date, and your wrath is less than the wrath of the Fire and the wrath of the Lord." The attendees were astonished by the strength of his faith.

### [The worst deaths]

The worst of deaths is for a person to die in a state that leads him to wretchedness (الشقاء), and Allah only becomes angry with the wretched. Look at the effect of charity: how it affected the Divine Wrath (الغضب الرباني), the worst of deaths, and the authority of Hell. The one who gives charity to himself during anger does so merely by controlling himself at that moment. For his control over himself during anger is charity upon himself, without him realizing it. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The strong man is not the one who overcomes others in wrestling; rather, the strong man is the one who controls himself when angry." For anger is a consuming fire. This is part of a person's charity upon himself.

### [Protecting oneself from the Fire through charity and a good word]

Furthermore, Allah has mentioned that He does not forgive a polytheist (مشرك). Yet, Allah alleviates his punishment according to what he spent. Abu Dawud mentioned on the authority of Aisha, who said: "O Messenger of Allah, where is Abdullah ibn Jud'an?" He replied, "In the Fire." This was hard for her, so he said, "O Aisha, what is hard for you?" She said, "He used to feed the poor and maintain kinship ties." He said, "Indeed, it is alleviated for him by what you mention of his noble character (مكارم الأخلاق)."

Al-Bukhari said in his *Sahih* that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Protect yourselves from the Fire, even with half a date. If one does not find half a date, then with a good word (كلمة طيبة)."

He, peace and blessings be upon him, also said: "Indeed, a good word is charity (صدقة), every glorification (*tasbih*) is charity, and every declaration of God's Oneness (*tahlil*) is charity," and other such remembrances (*adhkar*) and actions necessitated by noble character. Muslim mentioned in his *Sahih* on the authority of Abu Hurayrah, who said that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "A dinar you spend in the way of Allah, a dinar you spend to free a slave, a dinar you give in charity to a poor person, and a dinar you spend upon your family—the greatest in reward is the one you spent upon your family."

[Section on one who spends from what he loves]

Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, said: <<لَن تَنَالُوا الْبِرَّ حَتَّىٰ تُنفِقُوا مِمَّا تُحِبُّونَ>> (You will never attain righteousness until you spend from that which you love). Abdullah ibn Umar used to buy sugar and give it in charity, saying, "I love it," acting upon this verse. The dearest thing a person possesses is his own self (نفسه). If you spend it in the way of Allah, you attain that which is equivalent to its value. For whoever consumes something must pay its value. And The Real (الحق) has consumed the self of this servant, for He commanded you to spend what you love, and its only value with Him is Paradise. This is why, when we find nothing, we find Allah, for He is only found when the things one relies upon are absent. The human self (نفس الإنسان) is the essence of all things, and it has been annihilated (هلكت), so its value is what we have mentioned. Look at how sublime the merit of charity is.

[Section on declaring charity]

Declaring charity is from the Name The Manifest (الظاهر), and initiating it is from the Name The First (الأول). Emulating it is from His saying: <<فَاتَّبِعُونِي يُحْبِبْكُمُ اللَّهُ>> (So follow me, [and] Allah will love you). The Imam's request to the people for those in need who come to him, when he has nothing in the treasury to give them, is analogous to the heart (القلب) devoid of knowledge (العلم) whose benefit extends to the other parts of the body. And whoever holds a good opinion of Him asks the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) to grant him states (الأحوال) and sciences (العلوم) by which his manifest and hidden powers (قواه الظاهرة والباطنة) may seek aid in fulfilling the duties Allah has obligated upon them.

### [The heart is responsible for its flock]

Indeed, Allah informed the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, that every day, charity is due upon every joint (سلامي). He made every glorification (*tasbih*) charity, and every declaration of God's Oneness (*tahlil*) charity, and so on. These are states (أحوال) that require intention (*niyyah*) and sincerity (*ikhlas*). Intention only occurs after knowing the One for Whom sincerity is due, which is Allah the Exalted. Therefore, the Imam must ask for what is to be given in charity upon every joint and on behalf of every joint. The heart (القلب) is responsible for its flock (رعيته), which are all its manifest and hidden powers. The comprehensive Prophetic *hadith* supporting what we have established and considered is that which Muslim recorded on the authority of Jarir ibn Abdullah, who said: "We were with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, early in the day, when a group of people came to him, barefoot, naked, wearing striped woolen garments, girded with swords. Most of them were from Mudar—indeed, all of them were from Mudar. The face of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, changed color when he saw the poverty they were in. He went inside, then came out, ordered Bilal to call the *adhan* and the *iqamah*, prayed with them, and then delivered a sermon. He said: <<يَا أَيُّهَا النَّاسُ اتَّقُوا رَبَّكُمُ الَّذِي خَلَقَكُم مِّن نَّفْسٍ وَاحِدَةٍ وَخَلَقَ مِنْهَا زَوْجَهَا وَبَثَّ مِنْهُمَا رِجَالًا كَثِيرًا وَنِسَاءً وَاتَّقُوا اللَّهَ الَّذِي تَسَاءَلُونَ بِهِ وَالْأَرْحَامَ إِنَّ اللَّهَ كَانَ عَلَيْكُمْ رَقِيبًا>> (O mankind, fear your Lord, who created you from one soul and created from it its mate and dispersed from both of them many men and women. And fear Allah, through whom you ask one another, and the wombs. Indeed, Allah is ever, over you, an Observer). And: <<يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا اتَّقُوا اللَّهَ وَلْتَنظُرْ نَفْسٌ مَّا قَدَّمَتْ لِغَدٍ وَاتَّقُوا اللَّهَ إِنَّ اللَّهَ خَبِيرٌ بِمَا تَعْمَلُونَ>> (O you who have believed, fear Allah. And let every soul look to what it has put forth for tomorrow—and fear Allah. Indeed, Allah is Acquainted with what you do). [He then said:] 'Let a man give charity from his dinar, from his dirham, from his garment, from a *sa'* of wheat, from a *sa'* of dates,' until he said, 'even if it is half a date.' A man from the Ansar then came with a purse that his palm could barely hold—indeed, it failed to hold it. Then the people followed suit until I saw two heaps of food and clothing, and I saw the face of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, beaming as if it were gold. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Whoever establishes a good practice (*sunnah hasanah*) in Islam will have its reward and the reward of whoever acts upon it after him, without anything being diminished from their rewards. And whoever establishes a bad practice (*sunnah sayyi'ah*) in Islam will bear its burden and the burden of whoever acts upon it after him, without anything being diminished from their burdens.'"

[Section on the complaint of the limbs to Allah against the self and Satan regarding the evil they cast upon them]

The People of Unveiling (أهل الكشف) see and hear the complaint of the limbs (الجوارح) to Allah the Exalted against the wicked self (النفس الخبيثة) that manages the body and directs the limbs toward evil, due to what Satan casts upon it. The self, in terms of its luminous structure (هيكلها النوري), complains to the animal self (النفس الحيوانية) which accepts the evil cast upon it by Satan, which it then directs through the manifest and hidden powers. If they are truthful in their complaint, Allah grants them security from what they fear, provides them with the acceptance of what the angel casts upon them, and employs them through that inspiration (الإلقاء) in obedience to Allah the Exalted and His Messenger. This continues until those actions bequeath to them the Witnessing (مشاهدة) of The Real (الحق) and intimate conversation (*munajat*) with Him, based on Unveiling (الكشف) and Witnessing (الشهود), without intermediary, where He addresses them with an address of affirmation concerning blessings and favors.

### [The blind common people, the people of letters, do not hear the complaint of the limbs]

The blind common people, the people of letters (أهل الحروف) and forms (الرسوم), are unaware. They are deaf, dumb, and blind, so they do not understand or hear this complaint due to the intensity of their deafness and the obscuring of their eyes. If they acted upon what they were obligated to do, Allah would teach them knowledge like this, and they would see it with the eye of witnessing, just as the People of Allah (أهل الله) see and attain it. Allah the Exalted says concerning one of them: <<وَعَلَّمْنَاهُ مِن لَّدُنَّا عِلْمًا>> (And We had taught him knowledge from Us). And: <<وَاتَّقُوا اللَّهَ وَيُعَلِّمُكُمُ اللَّهُ>> (And fear Allah; and Allah teaches you). And: <<إِن تَتَّقُوا اللَّهَ يَجْعَل لَّكُمْ فُرْقَانًا وَيَجْعَل لَّكُمْ نُورًا تَمْشُونَ بِهِ>> (If you fear Allah, He will grant you a criterion [to judge between right and wrong] and will grant you a light by which you will walk).

### [The opening of the treasures of Khosrau]

The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, alluded to what we have mentioned in a *hadith* that encompasses what occurred in the world, and the allusion in it is to what we have discussed. This is what Al-Bukhari recorded on the authority of our grandfather's brother, Adi ibn Hatim, who said: "While I was with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, a man came to him and complained of poverty. Then another came and complained of highway robbery. He said, 'O Adi, have you seen Al-Hirah?' I said, 'I have not seen it, but I have been told about it.' He said, 'If your life is prolonged, you will surely see a woman traveling from Al-Hirah until she circumambulates the Kaaba, fearing no one but Allah.' I said to myself, 'Where are the brigands of Tayy who have set the land ablaze?' [The Prophet continued:] 'And if your life is prolonged, the treasures of Khosrau will surely be opened for you.' I asked, 'Khosrau son of Hormuz?' He said, 'Khosrau son of Hormuz.' 'And if your life is prolonged, you will surely see a man taking out a handful of gold or silver, seeking someone to accept it from him, but finding no one to accept it.' 'And surely, one of you will meet Allah on the Day of Resurrection, and there will be no interpreter between him and Him to translate for him. He will say to him, "Did I not send a messenger to you who conveyed [My message]?" He will say, "Yes." He will say, "Did I not give you wealth and favor you?" He will say, "Yes." Then he will look to his right and see nothing but Hell, and he will look to his left and see nothing but Hell.' Adi said: 'I heard the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Protect yourselves from the Fire, even with half a date. If one does not find half a date, then with a good word."'"

### [Security from the Greatest Fear]

As for his saying, "fearing no one but Allah," this refers to the Greatest Fear (الخوف الأعظم), for He is the One Who grants authority, and <<وَبِيَدِهِ مَلَكُوتُ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ>> (and in His hand is the dominion of all things). So, where is the security? This is an alert to our turning away. For the person who is in such a state is secure in his worldly life, his wealth, and his self from those who would harm him. This was the intention of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. Allah is the One Who granted him security in that state. He fears Allah concerning what is in the Unseen (غيبه), which he does not know and whose time he does not know. If this fearful person feared Allah absolutely, his fear would be attached to his religion (دينه), for the path of Satan to his heart is not secure, unlike the manifest path where travelers pass. When he fears Allah, his fear distracts him from his wealth and his self. Even if the path were not secure, this fearful person would be in security, for no thought would cross his mind except concerning his religion, which he fears might be stripped away from him. Even if he were afflicted on his journey by the destruction of wealth or life due to robbers, he might rejoice and be gladdened by the great, stored-up reward and expiations he would receive therein. His case would be like that of a merchant who sold on credit for a great profit. How excellent is the Prophetic simile in his saying, "fearing no one but Allah." So, where is the security? The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, only mentioned this to Adi because the customary security was achieved at that time, when the man complained of highway robbery. However, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, included the fear of Allah within that security for the people of understanding (أولي الألباب) and prohibition, so that the address would encompass the common people with security and the elite with fear. Thus, it is a clarification of the states of Allah's elite: that is, be in this state of security while fearing Allah the Exalted. This is among the comprehensive words (*jawami' al-kalim*) for one who reflects and gains insight.

[Section on charity to the nearest, then the next nearest, and observing neighborhood in that]

### [The nearest of a person's people to him is his own self]

The nearest of a person's people to him is his own self (نفسه). For Allah says concerning His proximity to His servant that He is nearer to him than the <<حَبْلِ الْوَرِيدِ>> (jugular vein). It is as if He is saying that He is nearer to him than his own self. Thus, the self is more deserving of charity than others, just as Allah is more deserving of the loan because He is nearer to him than his self. Every recipient of charity among the creatures has a charity appropriate for him: first his limbs (جوارحه), then the nearest after that, which is the family (الأهل), then the child (الولد), then the servant (الخادم), then the kin (الرحم) and the neighbor (الجار), just as one gives charity to his student and the seeker of benefit from him. When the Gnostic (العارف) realizes The Real (ربه) such that he becomes entirely light, and The Real (الحق) becomes his hearing, his sight, and all his powers, then he is entirely The Real. Whoever is the People of Allah (أهل الله) is undoubtedly the people of this person whose description this is, just as the People of the Quran are the People of Allah and His elite. Likewise, those who are the People of Allah and His elite are the people of the one we have mentioned, for he is entirely The Real, just as the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said in his supplication: "And make me light," when he saw The Real name Himself Light. For he is the deputy (نائب) of Allah among His servants. Therefore, the one who gives charity to the People of Allah is giving charity to his own people, if the giver of charity is of this rank.

### [Those nearest to Allah are more deserving of kindness]

One day I was sitting with our Shaykh, Abu al-Abbas al-Arabi, in Seville. We intended, or someone intended, to give a kindness (*ma'ruf*). A person from the group said to the one who wished to give charity, "The nearest are more deserving of kindness." The Shaykh immediately replied, connecting his words to the speaker's: "...to Allah." How cool that was upon my liver! By Allah, I did not hear it in that state except from Allah, until it seemed to me that it had been revealed in the Quran, due to the realization I attained and the way my heart absorbed it, and likewise for all those present. Therefore, no one should consume the blessings of Allah except the People of Allah (أهل الله); they were created for them. Others consume them by virtue of dependence. They are the intended recipients of the blessings. As for everyone else, as we said, they only consume them dependently, by virtue of the totality. In terms of detail, there is no single atom (جوهر فرد) or accident (*'arad*) in the cosmos that does not glorify Allah, so it is among the People of Allah. Thus, there is nothing in the World (العالم) that is outside this general eligibility. The elite (الخاصة) only achieved success by realizing this through Unveiling (كشفا).

### [The obedience of the Oneness of Gathering and the obedience of the individuals of the totality]

This issue is one of the most obscure matters on the path to Allah, for the totality is nothing but these parts. The parts are the essence of the whole. Every part and portion is obedient, but the whole or the totality is not described by this attribute; rather, it is obedient by the obedience of the Oneness of Gathering (أحدية الجمع), which is an obedience distinct from the obedience of the individuals of this totality.

### [The greatest reward is spending on the family]

A report has been transmitted concerning spending on the family, which is known and established outwardly, and its merit is such that this consideration applies to it. This is what Muslim recorded in his *Sahih* on the authority of Abu Hurayrah, who said that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "A dinar you spend in the way of Allah, a dinar you spend to free a slave, a dinar you give in charity to a poor person, and a dinar you spend upon your family—the greatest in reward is the one you spent upon your family."

[Section on maintaining ties with kin and that the womb is a branch of the All-Merciful]

### [Charity given to kin is both charity and a tie]

Understand—may Allah grant you understanding from Him—that since the womb (الرحم) is a branch (*shujnah*) of the All-Merciful (الرحمن), whoever maintains ties with it, Allah maintains ties with him—meaning, with the One of Whom it is a branch—and whoever severs it, Allah severs him. Therefore, charity given to kin (أولي الأرحام) is both charity and a tie to the All-Merciful, whereas charity given to non-kin is charity that falls into the Hand of the All-Merciful, but without the tie to the All-Merciful.

### [The Adamic Form is a Caliph]

This Adamic Form (الصورة الآدمية) is a Caliph (خليفة). Its rank dictates that the Caliph manifests in the form of the One Who appointed him as Caliph. Thus, whoever gives charity to his own self (نفسه) with that which contains its life, that charity is a tie to Allah, of Whose attributes is the All-Merciful (الرحمن). For Allah created Adam upon His form, despite their disagreement regarding the pronoun [referent]. Allah the Exalted said: <<بِسْمِ اللَّهِ الرَّحْمَنِ الرَّحِيمِ>> (In the Name of Allah, the All-Merciful, the Especially Merciful). Thus, Allah is described by the All-Merciful.

### [The further the relation, the greater the rank]

Al-Tirmidhi recorded on the authority of Salama ibn Amir that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Charity given to the poor person is one charity, but charity given to kin is two: charity and maintaining ties." [The text continues:] The stronger the relation (النسبة), the greater the rank (المنزلة). This is according to our companions, but the matter is not so with us. Rather, the further the relation, the greater the rank. We have concerning this:

I saw my Lord with the eye of my Lord,
So I said, "My Lord," and He said, "You."

Some Gnostics (العارفين) imagine that this verse follows the first pattern, but it is not so. The first-person pronoun in this verse is the essence of the servant through his Lord, not through his own self. Reflect upon this composition, for it is among the most wondrous of Divine Gnosis (المعارف الإلهية), containing great secrets and vast knowledge.

[Section on the recipient giving charity to the giver by taking from him]

### [The self gives charity to the intellect by accepting from it]

The self (النفس) gives charity to the intellect ('Aql) by accepting what the intellect casts upon it, since some selves do not accept. The self also imagines the selves of its disciples (*muridin*), who are orphans (أيتام) without a mother, because their own selves have died to them. They have no manager except the self of their Shaykh. Thus, the Shaykh's self gives charity to them through what Allah casts upon it from the Divine Spirit (الروح الإلهي), provided it is in the station of the state (*hal*) that actively affects. The disciple's self then finds matters that his own station or state does not grant him, matters outside his acquisition (*kasb*). He imagines that Allah has granted him an opening without an intermediary. However, that opening, if it originates from the state of the self of this person who is the Shaykh, means the disciple is an orphan in the Shaykh's care. For this, the Shaykh has a great reward with Allah. For there is no prophet who, in conveying benefit and delivering the message, did not say, when commanded: <<قُلْ مَا أَسْأَلُكُمْ عَلَيْهِ مِنْ أَجْرٍ إِنْ أَجْرِيَ إِلَّا عَلَى اللَّهِ>> (Say, "I ask you for no reward for it; my reward is only from Allah"). Thus, it is a teaching that necessitates reward.

### [The reward that does not remove you from your servitude]

This is the reward (الأجر) that does not remove you from your servitude (*'ubudiyyah*). You are the servant in the form of the hired worker, but it is not the wage of the hired worker. For the hired worker is one who is hired, and he is an outsider, and the master does not hire his own slave. However, the work necessitates the wage, and the slave does not take it; rather, the agent (العامل) takes it, and the servant is the agent. Thus, he is the recipient of the wage from Allah. He resembles the hired worker in receiving the wage but differs from him in being hired. What supports what we have mentioned is what Muslim recorded in his *Sahih* on the authority of Bilal, concerning the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who was asked about a woman's charity to her husband and to orphans under her care. He said: "Two rewards: the reward of kinship and the reward of charity."

[Section on knowing who the parents of the human self are]

### [The natural body and the Divine Spirit]

The partial self (النفس الجزئية) that manages his body and powers, which is the human self, is the child of his natural body, which is its mother, and the Divine Spirit (الروح الإلهي) is its father. This is why it says in its intimate conversation (*munajat*): "Our Lord, and the Lord of our celestial fathers and our terrestrial mothers." <<فَإِذَا سَوَّيْتُهُ وَنَفَخْتُ فِيهِ مِن رُّوحِي>> (And when I have proportioned him and breathed into him of My Spirit). [And concerning Mary:] <<أَحْصَنَتْ فَرْجَهَا فَنَفَخْنَا فِيهِ مِن رُّوحِنَا>> (She guarded her private part, so We breathed into it of Our Spirit). Thus, Jesus, peace be upon him, was her child, and she was his mother.

### [The orphan child who has no father]

The proportioned body had a self (نفس) breathed into it from the Spirit. So the body is the mother, and the source of the breathing is the father. However, this child is like an orphan who has no father, because his intellect ('Aql) has not been strengthened by looking toward Him. It is as if he has no intellect. He is thus in the position of a young child who has no father to teach and discipline him. His vegetative self (نفسه النباتية), which is his body, manages him according to the soundness of temperament upon which Allah created it. Thus, the inner and outer powers are in the utmost purity and balance. The self then benefits from sciences (العلوم) that are equivalent to the charity of a woman upon her orphan child. This person receives Divine Knowledge (العلم الإلهي) from the direction of his body, as a reward for the charity he gave to his self, the value of which none can estimate but Allah.

Umm Salama, the wife of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Will I have a reward for spending upon the children of Abu Salama? I will not leave them like this and that; they are only my children." He said: "Yes, you will have a reward for whatever you spend upon them." Muslim recorded this in his *Sahih*.

[Section on the one who gives charity of wisdom to those who are worthy of it]

This is charity given to the needy.

### [Wisdom should not be given beyond those worthy of it]

He the Exalted said: <<أَلَمْ يَجِدْكَ يَتِيمًا فَآوَىٰ>> (Did He not find you an orphan and give [you] refuge?) and <<وَوَجَدَكَ ضَالًّا فَهَدَىٰ>> (And found you lost and guided [you]?). And He said: <<وَأَمَّا السَّائِلَ فَلَا تَنْهَرْ>> (And as for the petitioner, do not repel [him])—meaning the petitioner for knowledge (العلم). A person gives charity of knowledge to the People of Allah (أهل الله) who are worthy of it. Wisdom (الحكمة) should not be given beyond those worthy of it. He should seek the reward for that charity from Allah—that is, he should not see any favor of his own upon the one he taught, nor any superiority that would demand service, respect, or subservience from the student in return for the favor he bestowed upon him. If he does that, he will not receive reward for it from Allah. We have met Shaykhs who followed this path, and it is our way. The Law (الشرع) has drawn attention to this in the science of forms and its world.

He said: "Indeed, when a Muslim spends upon his family, seeking reward for it, it is counted as charity for him"—meaning, it falls into the Hand of the All-Merciful. Muslim recorded this *hadith* on the authority of Abu Mas'ud al-Badri from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.

[Section on Inspired Knowledge and Acquired Knowledge]

### [Inspired Knowledge has no scale]

Knowledge (العلم) is of two kinds: inspired (*mawhub*) and acquired (*muktasab*). Inspired Knowledge (العلم الموهوب) has no scale [by which to measure it]. Acquired Knowledge (العلم المكتسب) is that which results from piety (*taqwa*) and righteous action. It is subject to balancing and specification, for every specific piety and action has a specific knowledge that belongs only to it. Thus, there is one who fears Allah for Allah, one who fears Allah for the Fire, one who fears Allah for Satan, and one who fears Allah for the sake of one who does not fear Allah. Every piety has a specific action and a specific knowledge that is attained by the one who possesses that piety.

### [A man's spending on himself for which he receives charity]

A man's spending on himself for which he receives charity is that with which he nourishes it from this Acquired Knowledge, through which his eternal life (حياته الأبدية) is secured in this world and the Hereafter. This is because every kindness (*ma'ruf*) is charity, and the people of kindness in this world are the people of kindness in the Hereafter. There is no kindness except Allah, so there are no people except the People of Allah.

### [The one who advises his self is he who protects his honor]

The one who advises his self is he who protects his honor (*'ird*), for this is among his charities upon his self. Protecting one's honor means that no tongue of blame runs against him from the side of The Real (الحق)—nothing else. Thus, he is praised by the tongue of the Law (الشرع) and by every Divine tongue: of angels, animals, plants, minerals, and celestial spheres, and everything besides the two weighty ones (الثقلين) [jinn and humans], and some of the two weighty ones. Is it conceivable that he protects his honor from all of the two weighty ones? This is inconceivable, because the Origin, which is Allah, did not protect His honor from the tongues of His creation. However, it is possible for him to rise above the honor, and if that is possible, he has protected his self, which is his honor, from having an effect upon his self—not that he protected his honor from being spoken about. This is the meaning of His saying: <<وَمَا أَنفَقْتُم مِّن شَيْءٍ فَهُوَ يُخْلِفُهُ>> (And whatever thing you spend—He will compensate for it).

### [The Hand of Allah that spends and His Hand that receives]

If he spends seeking glory (مجدا) on the tongues of creation, then that is for what he spent. If he seeks the return of praise upon Allah, in that He is the Family of Allah, then he spends in this regard and does not see himself as the spender. And he spends in the disobedience of Iblis, yet he sees protection (*'ismah*) and spending only from the Hand of Allah. Such a person is an exception in every spending, if this is his state (*hal*) and his spiritual taste (*dhawq*). He finds that the reward does not return to anyone except the Giver. Thus, the Hand of Allah is the spender, and the Hand of the All-Merciful (الرحمن) receives from it.

The Hand of Allah is the spender,
And the Hand of the All-Merciful is the receiver.
The one for generosity is empty,
And the one for the servant is idle.
Its signs are detailed wondrously,
And they reach the Fixed Entities (الأعيان الثابتة).
If you saw them in their transformation,
While they traverse the cosmos (الأكوان),
You would say, "My purposes direct them,"
Yet they are still by the proof (البرهان).

### [Every kindness is charity]

What supports what we have mentioned is the allusion in his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Every kindness is charity. Whatever a man spends upon himself and his family is written as charity for him. Whatever a man protects his honor with is charity. Whatever a man spends, Allah will compensate for it, except for spending on construction or disobedience." Abu Ahmad mentioned this *hadith* from the narration of Jabir. Abdul Hamid, who narrated from Abu Ahmad, said: "I asked Ibn al-Munkadir, 'What is meant by a man protecting his honor?' He said, 'He gives to the poet and the eloquent speaker.'"

[Section on the distinction between Servitude and Freedom]

### [The station of servitude is nobler than the station of freedom for a human being]

The attribution of a person to his Lord by servitude (*'ubudiyyah*) or to worship (*'ubudah*) is superior to his attribution to others by freedom, such that he is called free from the bondage of others (رق الأغيار). For freedom from Allah is not valid. When a person is in the station of freedom (مقام الحرية), his witnessing (مشهوده) is only the entities of others (أعيان الأغيار), because freedom from them is established by witnessing them. In this state, he is absent from both his servitude and his worship. Thus, the station of servitude is nobler than the station of freedom for a human being, and worship (*'ubudah*) is nobler than servitude (*'ubudiyyah*). The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, alluded to something similar in the *hadith* of Maymunah bint al-Harith, when she freed a slave girl during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. She mentioned this to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "Had you given her to your maternal uncles, it would have been greater for your reward."

Thus, the station of servitude was preferred over the reward of freedom.

### [The preference between the grateful rich and the patient poor]

Just as poverty toward Allah was preferred over richness through Allah. One of our Shaykhs, Abdullah al-Qalfat, narrated to me on the island of Tarifa in the year 590 AH [1194 CE]—we were discussing the preference between the rich and the poor, meaning the grateful rich and the patient poor, which is a well-known issue—and the state of poverty and richness was drawn into the discussion. He said to me: "I was present with some Shaykhs," and he related it to me from Abu al-Rabi' al-Kafif al-Malaqi, the student of Abu al-Abbas ibn al-Arif al-Sanhaji, who said: "If two men each had ten dinars, and one of them gave one dinar in charity from the ten, and the other gave nine dinars in charity from the ten he had, which of them is superior?" The attendees said, "The one who gave nine in charity." He asked, "By what criterion did you prefer him?" They replied, "Because he gave more in charity than his companion." He said, "Good, but you missed the spirit of the issue, and it escaped you." He was asked, "What is it?" He replied, "We assumed they were equal in wealth. The one who gave more in charity had a greater entry into poverty (الفقر) than his companion, so he was preferred by his precedence toward the side of poverty."

### [The Sufis do not stop at rewards but at Realities]

This is not denied by anyone who knows the Stations (المقامات) and States (الأحوال). For the people [Sufis] did not stop at rewards (الأجور); rather, they stopped at the Realities (الحقائق) and the States, and what Unveiling (الكشف) grants. By this, they were preferred over the scholars of forms (علماء الرسوم). Had he given all of it in charity and remained upon his origin—having nothing—that would have been higher. His deficiency in rank and spiritual taste (*dhawq*) is proportional to what he held onto. Do you not see what our Shaykh, Abu al-Abbas al-Sabti, may Allah have mercy on him, said concerning the dying person who bequeaths a third? The dying person only owns a third of his wealth, so he departed from what he owned and left nothing behind. The Lawgiver permitted him to give the entire third that he owned in charity, and he is praised for this legally. Thus, he met Allah poor, according to the rule of the Origin: just as he came forth from Him, he returned to Him empty-handed. Someone said concerning this meaning:

When the newborn is born, he clenches his fist,
A sign of the greed inherent in the living.
And he opens them at death, admonishing:
"Behold me! I have departed with nothing."

Thus, he was superior to one who did not give that third he owned in charity, or who gave less than a third, even if he intended what he kept to be charity for his heirs. There is a wondrous allusion in this.

[Section on the merit of one who leaves behind a continuous charity among the people after his death, whether of wealth or knowledge]

### [What is from a person's striving belongs to him with Allah]

The Gnostic (العارف بالله) is dying, and in his heart, if he could speak, he would benefit people with knowledge of their Lord. His tongue is tied, so a student conveys a point of beneficial knowledge—of Unity (*tawhid*) or otherwise—which benefits the listeners present. That dying Gnostic reaps its fruit, and the student reaps the fruit of his conveyance with Allah. Allah rewards the deceased for it as a necessary reward, for it is from his striving (*sa'y*). Allah says: <<وَأَن لَّيْسَ لِلْإِنسَانِ إِلَّا مَا سَعَىٰ>> (And that there is not for man except that [good] for which he strives). The best thing a man consumes is from his own earning, and his child is from his earning. The student is undoubtedly a spiritual child. Thus, whatever is from a person's striving belongs to him with Allah, by way of the Divine Obligation (الإيجاب الإلهي) that He has obligated upon Himself.

### [The action of another by virtue of deputyship]

As for what another person does on his behalf by virtue of deputyship (النيابة)—something the deceased neither authorized, nor bequeathed, nor had any action in—Allah grants him that station if another person gifts it to him. The deceased takes it, not by way of Divine Obligation, but he must necessarily take it, for it came to him without asking. In the authentic *hadith*: "Whatever comes to you without asking, take it; and whatever does not, do not let your self follow it." A trace of this has been transmitted in the science of forms, in what Muslim recorded on the authority of Aisha: A man came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and said, "O Messenger of Allah, my mother died suddenly and did not leave a will, but I think that if she had spoken, she would have given charity. Will she have a reward if I give charity on her behalf?" He said, "Yes."

[Section on what the Next Creation grants]

### [The beginning of creation without precedent and its return likewise]

Allah the Exalted said: <<كَمَا بَدَأَكُمْ تَعُودُونَ>> (Just as He originated you, you will return). And: <<وَلَقَدْ عَلِمْتُمُ النَّشْأَةَ الْأُولَىٰ فَلَوْلَا تَذَكَّرُونَ>> (And you had already known the first creation; so will you not remember?). He originated us without a precedent, and we know that. Likewise, He will recreate us without a precedent.

### [A person being in different places at the same time]

Know that among the rewards of the Hereafter and the relation of the human being to it is the knowledge of the Next Creation (النشأة الآخرة). It is not far-fetched for a person to be in different places at the same time (الزمن الواحد). This is something that intellects deem impossible, but Unveiling (الكشف) testifies to its validity. Thus, it is impossible rationally but not impossible in terms of Divine Relation (نسبة إلهية). Every worshipper is intimately conversing with his Lord, and the human being, in terms of the Reality (حقيقته) upon which he is created in the Hereafter, is created upon the Form.

### [The Gnostic being with the Divine Names, with the oneness of his essence and their essence]

The Gnostic (العارف) is with many of the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) in different states, with the oneness of the essence ('ayn) of the Gnostic and the essence of the Named. Every person sees him according to the essence by which this man wishes to manifest to him. Thus, Zayd, the one praying, is seen by Amr as sleeping, by Khalid as writing, by Muhammad as sewing, and by Qasim as eating. The essence is one, and all of that is actually witnessed by every observer, and every observer is in a country different from his companion's country, just as one enters any form he wishes in the market of Paradise. I have not heard anyone draw attention to this station except Abu Bakr al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, regarding his entering all eight gates of Paradise at one time, and Dhu al-Nun al-Misri, in his famous issues, such as the deceased being seen by his guardian as dead and motionless, while another sees him with his own eye as alive and asking questions, all at the same instant.

### [Entering all the gates of Paradise at the same instant]

As for the *hadith* of Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, Al-Bukhari mentioned it in his *Sahih* on the authority of Abu Hurayrah, who said: "I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: 'Whoever spends a pair of anything in the way of Allah will be called from any of the gates of Paradise: "O servant of Allah, this is good." Whoever was among the People of Prayer will be called from the Gate of Prayer. Whoever was among the People of Jihad will be called from the Gate of Jihad. Whoever was among the People of Charity will be called from the Gate of Charity. And whoever was among the People of Fasting will be called from the Gate of Al-Rayyan.' Abu Bakr said, 'There is no necessity upon the one who is called from those gates.' He asked, 'Will anyone be called from all of them, O Messenger of Allah?' He said, 'Yes, and I hope that you will be one of them, O Abu Bakr.'"

Allah's call to people to enter on the Day of Resurrection is a single call for entering the Gardens. One person enters through one gate, another through two or three. The most comprehensive entry is for the one who enters through all eight gates, because the limbs of obligation (أعضاء التكليف) are eight, and there is a gate for every limb. So, do not deny this regarding the reward in a single instant, when you witness it in action, both in doing and refraining—such as lowering one's gaze while listening to an admonition, while reciting [Quran], while fasting, while giving charity, while exercising piety (*wara'*) and while guarding one's private parts—all with the intention of drawing near to Allah the Exalted. In every gate there are stations, just as faith in Allah has seventy-odd branches, the highest of which is *La ilaha illa Allah* (There is no god but Allah), and the lowest of which is removing harm from the road. There is no harm greater than the harm of polytheism (*shirk*), and no road greater than the road of faith. Thus, it concludes with the same thing with which it began. *La ilaha illa Allah* is the negation of everything besides Allah that is worshipped or claimed to possess divinity, and removing harm from the road is the negation of harm from the path. Thus, the end of the circle meets its beginning and folds back upon itself. What lies between these two are the remaining branches of faith, and for every branch there is a station in the Garden of Faith. Whoever knows what we have said will enter all the gates of Paradise at one time. The Next Creation grants these matters, just as the worldly creation granted the gathering of the branches of faith in the human being at one time, and this is not impossible.

[Section on giving the good of charities with a good self]

### [The best charities are those that proceed according to sound Knowledge]

Know that the good (الطيب) of charities is that you give in charity what you own, and you only own what is lawful for you to own, with a good self (طيب نفس). The highest level of this is that you are fulfilling a trust (*amanah*) that the Lawgiver named charity in the language of forms. Thus, your hand is the Hand of Allah when giving. This is why we called it a trust, for things like this do not benefit their Creator; rather, they are deserved by the one for whom they were created, which is the creature. Thus, it is a trust from Allah, held by Allah, for this servant, which he delivers to him, either directly from Him or through the hand of another servant. This is the best of charities because it proceeds according to sound Knowledge (العلم الصحيح).

### [The Hand of Allah that spends and the Hand of the All-Merciful that receives]

When it reaches the hand of the recipient, the All-Merciful (الرحمن) takes it with His Right Hand. If the Giver, in the self of this servant when he gives it, is Allah the Giver, then his hand must necessarily be above the hand of the recipient, who is the beggar, for the upper hand is the Hand of Allah, and it is the spender. Even if this giver witnesses the Hand of the All-Merciful receiving it from him when the beggar takes it, his hand remains superior to the Hand of the All-Merciful, in that the Giver is Allah, just as it is. For the All-Merciful is an Attribute (صفة) of Allah and a description of His descriptions. However, what He takes from it is not its essence ('ayn), but rather the piety (*taqwa*) of the giver in his giving. The most perfect aspect of this is what we have mentioned: that the giver witnesses that Allah is the Giver, and the All-Merciful is the Receiver, and that Mercy (الرحمة) is the Giver, and it is the charity. When the All-Merciful takes it in His Right Hand, He makes this servant its locus, and the All-Merciful gives it to him. Only this can occur, for charity is mercy, and only the All-Merciful gives it in its Reality (حقيقته). Allah receives it in His capacity as the One described by the All-Merciful, the Especially Merciful (الرحمن الرحيم), not in terms of the Absolute Name. The charity falls into the Hand of the All-Merciful before it falls into the hand of the beggar—this is how the report came.

### [Your charity to Zayd is the essence of your charity to yourself]

Such charity, when the beggar consumes it, yields for him obedience, guidance, light, and knowledge. All of this is the nurturing of the All-Merciful for it. For everything that the power of this charity grants in the self of the beggar—of obedience, guidance, light, and knowledge—he sees it in the Hereafter in his scale and in the scale of the one who gave it, who is the giver of charity, the deputy (نائب) of Allah. It will be said to him: "This is the fruit of your charity; its blessing has returned to you and to the one upon whom you bestowed charity." For your charity to Zayd is the very essence of your charity to yourself, since its goodness returns to you.

### [The best charities]

The best of charities is what a person gives to his own self. The giver of this charity is also present in the most perfect aspects within his self. Such charity is not questioned on the Day of Resurrection as to where it was given or to whom it was given, because he is of this rank. If the recipient is like him in this level (المرتبة), they are equal in felicity, and the giver is superior by only one degree. If the recipient is not of this rank, then the charity is according to the attribute in which Allah establishes him. If the charity is voluntary (*tatawwu'*), it is a cosmic Divine favor (*minnah ilahiyyah kawniyyah*). If it is obligatory *zakat*, it is a Divine favor. If it is a vow (*nadhr*), it is a coercive cosmic Divine favor, for the vow is used to extract [wealth] from the miser. If this giving is a gift (*hadiyyah*), it does not belong to this section, for this section is specific to giving what is charity and nothing else.

### [Charity grows in the Hand of the All-Merciful, sensually and spiritually]

This charity grows in the Hand of the All-Merciful, sensually (*hissan*) and spiritually (*ma'nan*). The sensual aspect is that, since it is perceptible, he finds it in Paradise as a sensory scene, visible to the eye. The spiritual aspect is related to the lawful earning, the piety (*taqwa*) involved, the hastening to give it, the goodness of the self when it departs, and his witnessing of the Divine Affairs (الشئون الإلهية) we mentioned concerning it. He finds it on the dune (*kathib*) during the general witnessing, and he finds it at every time the scales pass over him for the time of its expenditure, while he is in Paradise. He is singled out by Allah for a witnessing in the essence of his Paradise that only one of this rank witnesses.

Muslim recorded on the authority of Abu Hurayrah, who said that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "No one gives charity from good [lawful] earnings—and Allah accepts nothing but the good—except that the All-Merciful takes it with His Right Hand, and even if it is a single date, it grows in the palm of the All-Merciful until it becomes greater than a mountain, just as one of you raises his foal or his young camel."

Whoever falls short of this degree of charity that we have described, his rank with Allah will be according to the limit of his knowledge and intention.

### [Charity is from the Name The Rich, The Severe]

Charity only proceeds from the Name The Rich (الغني), The Severe (الشديد), Possessor of Strength (ذي القوة), The Firm (المتين), by way of favor (*imtinan*), without seeking thanks for it. If the seeking of thanks is associated with it, it is not from the Name The Rich, but rather from the Names The Willing (المريد), The Wise (الحكيم), The Knowing (العالم).

### [Charity and the intention of a good loan]

If it occurs to the giver of charity to lend Allah a <<قَرْضًا حَسَنًا>> (good loan) with that charity, responding to Allah's command, then this section is also attached to charity because he is commanded to give a loan. The loan may be the obligatory *zakat* itself. If he seeks an additional compensation by which he benefits from what he loaned, he has departed from the limit of a loan and it becomes charity not described by the quality of a loan, for he did not give the prescribed loan.

"Indeed, Allah does not forbid usury (*riba*) and then take it from us," thus said the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.

For every loan that draws a benefit is usury. This occurs when this thought crosses his mind at the moment of giving, so he only gives it for this reason. The giver, who is the lender, should excel in repayment and add to it whatever he wishes, without it being a condition in the loan itself. Allah has promised the multiplication of reward for the loan, but the servant should not lend for the sake of multiplication, but rather for the sake of the command and for excellence in the recompense on the Day of Resurrection for Allah the Exalted concerning that.

### [Allah's dealing with us according to what He legislated for us]

This is the meaning of His saying "good" in the description of the loan. For Allah deals with us according to what He legislated for us, and not otherwise. Do you not see that He commanded His Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, to ask Him on the Day of Resurrection to judge with the Truth (الحق) with which He sent him, between His servants and Him? So He said to him: <<قَالَ رَبِّ احْكُم بِالْحَقِّ>> (He said, "My Lord, judge with the Truth"). The *alif* and *lam* in *al-Haqq* refer to the known Truth with which He was sent. The states of creation on the Day of Resurrection will proceed according to this. Whoever wishes to see Allah's judgment on the Day of Resurrection should look at the judgment of the Divine Laws (الشرائع الإلهية) in this world, exactly like one sandal matching another, without addition or diminution. So, be insightful regarding your Law, for it is the very essence of The Real (الحق) to which you return. Let us not be deceived, but be cautious, hold a good opinion of your Lord, and know the loci of His address to His servants in His Glorious Book and the *Sunnah* of His Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him.

[Section on concealing charity]

Know that concealing charity (إخفاء الصدقة) is a condition for attaining the High Station (المقام العالي) that Allah has reserved for the Seven Substitutes (الأبدال السبعة). The manner of concealing it is manifold. One way is that the one upon whom you bestow charity does not know that it came from you, and you use subtlety in delivering it to him by whatever means, for the means are many.

### [Taking charity from Allah, not from you]

Another way is that you teach him how to receive, and that he receives from Allah, not from you, so that he does not see any favor of yours upon him for what you gave him, and no trace of humiliation or destitution appears upon him in your presence. He gains sublime knowledge of the One Who gave him, and you disappear from his sight when you give him. For it has been established with him that he takes nothing but what is rightfully his. This is part of concealing charity.

### [The most hidden concealment is that your left hand does not know what your right hand spent]

Another way is that you conceal the fact that it is charity, so the recipient does not know [it is charity] in the presence of the giver. When the agent appointed by the ruler takes it, he takes it from you with authority and compulsion. When it reaches the hand of the ruler, who is the deputy appointed by Allah over it, he gives it to the authority of its eight owners. Its owners take it with dignity, not humiliation, for it is their right held by this deputy. The recipient does not know specifically who the owner of that wealth is in his giving. Thus, the rich owner of the wealth has no favor or authority over this poor person, nor does the poor person know whether the specific essence of the wealth reached him specifically. This, too, is part of concealing charity, because the giver did not know the specific essence of the one upon whom he bestowed charity, nor did the recipient know the specific essence of the giver. There is no concealment more hidden than this: that his left hand does not know what his right hand spent. This is the very essence of that.

### [The characteristics of The Real, those shaded by the shade of the Throne]

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) mentioned what we have said concerning the concealment of charity (الصدقة) when explaining the seven stations (المنازل) belonging to the specific characteristics (خصائص) of The Real (الحق), who will be sheltered on the Day of Resurrection by the shade of the Throne of the All-Merciful (عرش الرحمن), because they are the People of the All-Merciful (أهل الرحمن).

Al-Bukhari narrated on the authority of Abu Hurayrah that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Seven whom Allah will shade in His shade on the Day when there is no shade but His shade: a just ruler; a youth who grew up in the worship of Allah; a man whose heart is attached to the mosques; two men who loved each other for the sake of Allah, meeting and parting upon that love; a man whom a woman of high status and beauty invites (to sin), but he says, 'Indeed, I fear Allah'; a man who gives charity (صدقة) and conceals it so that his left hand does not know what his right hand spends; and a man who remembers Allah in solitude, and his eyes overflow with tears."

(Section concerning the designation of the owner of the wealth in one's possession before giving it as charity)

### [Charity Exists Where Ownership Exists]

Indeed, among the servants of Allah are those to whom it is unveiled (يكشف له) concerning the provision (الرزق) in their hands—which is their property (ملك)—that it belongs to so-and-so and so-and-so. He sees the names of its rightful owners upon it, but it remains in his hand. If a person of this description gives charity (صدقة), is it recorded for him as charity? We say: Yes, it is recorded for him as charity, based on the fact that Allah attributed ownership (الملك) to him. Even if he receives the unveiling (كوشف), that unveiling does not invalidate the act. Do you not see that the dying person (المحتضر) has the name of owner removed from him, and his disposal of the property is restricted? He is only permitted to dispose of one-third of it; anything beyond that is not accepted from him, because he speaks concerning what he does not own.

### [The Soul is Naturally Inclined to Stinginess]

Know that the soul (النفس) is naturally inclined to stinginess (الشح). Allah the Exalted said: <<وَإِذَا مَسَّهُ الْخَيْرُ مَنُوعًا>> (And when good touches him, he is stingy) [Q. 70:21], and He said: <<وَمَن يُوقَ شُحَّ نَفْسِهِ>> (And whoever is protected from the stinginess of his own soul) [Q. 59:9]. The reason for this is that the soul is contingent (ممكن), and every contingent thing is essentially poor (فقير بالأصالة), needing a determinant (مرجح) to favor its existence over its non-existence. Thus, need is intrinsic (ذاتية) to it. As long as a human’s life is connected to his body, his need is before his eyes, and his poverty is witnessed by him. Through this poverty, the accursed one approaches him with his promise, saying: <<الشَّيْطَانُ يَعِدُكُمُ الْفَقْرَ>> (Satan promises you poverty) [Q. 2:268]. No one overcomes his soul and the Satan who aids it against him except the one who is strong (الشديد) through Divine success (التوفيق الإلهي). He fights his soul and the Satan assisting it. This is why the Lawgiver (الشارع) called it *sadaqah* (charity), because it issues from strength and power. It is said, "a true spear (*rumh sidq*)," meaning strong and severe. If he did not hope for subsistence (البقاء) and was certain of separation (الفراق), giving away wealth would be easy for him, because it will be taken from him by compulsion, whether he wills it or not. It is from the greed of the soul (طمع النفس) that it seeks to be generous in that state, hoping perhaps to obtain in another place the equivalent of what it has parted with. All of this stems from its avarice (حرصها). Such a soul has not been generous out of true nobility, nor has Allah protected it from its stinginess.

Muslim mentioned concerning this, on the authority of Abu Hurayrah, who said: A man came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) and said, "O Messenger of Allah, which charity has the greatest reward?" He said, "By your father, you shall be informed! That you give charity while you are healthy and stingy (شحيح), fearing poverty and hoping for subsistence (تأمل البقاء), and that you do not delay until the soul reaches the throat (الحلقوم)..."

"...and you say, 'This is for so-and-so,' when it had already belonged to so-and-so." Therefore, it is incumbent upon the one whom Allah has not protected from the stinginess of his soul, and who has reached this limit and designated a portion of his wealth for a specific person, that this designation should be considered charity (صدقة). Let him resolve within himself, when making the designation, that he is fulfilling a trust (أمانة) and that this is its appointed time. Thus, he will be resurrected with the trustworthy ones who fulfilled their trusts, not with those who gave charity. The thought of charity should not even cross his mind if he wishes to be sincere to himself.

(Section concerning the excellence of the types of ownership and granting of ownership according to the People of Allah)

### [Ownership by Right (Istihqaq), Ownership by Trust (Amanah), and Existential Ownership (Wujudi)]

The Gnostic (العارف) is told by Allah, "This is your property (ملكك)." He accepts it from Him with proper conduct (الأدب) and knowledge. The knowledge concerning this is that there is ownership by right (ملك استحقاق) for the one who deserves it and to whom it rightfully belongs; ownership by trust (ملك أمانة) for the one who holds it in trust; and existential ownership (ملك وجود) for the one who exists through Him. All things are existentially owned (ملك وجودي) by Allah, and they belong to the servant according to the circumstance (الحال). That which is absolutely necessary for the benefit of the soul (النفس) in reality is ownership by right (ملك استحقاق) for him. This includes the food and drink he consumes at the time of consumption—that which nourishes him, not what is left over or excreted—and the clothing that protects him from the heat and cold of the air. As for anything beyond this measure, it is in his hand as ownership by trust (ملك أمانة) for the one whom he also protects with it, just as he protected himself with the things mentioned.

### [The States of the Gnostics Regarding the Types of Ownership and Granting of Ownership]

The Gnostic (العارف) is either one to whom the names of the owners of things are unveiled (كشف) as being written upon them. He holds them for those owners until he delivers them at the time appointed and designated by the All-Wise (الحكيم). He distinguishes between what belongs to him—which he calls ownership by right (ملك استحقاق) because his name is upon it and he deserves it—and what belongs to others—which he calls ownership by trust (ملك أمانة) because the owner’s name is upon it. Yet, according to the tongue of the Law (لسان الشرع), all of it is his property in the apparent ruling (الحكم الظاهر). Or, this Gnostic may be one to whom this unveiling has not occurred, so he does not know specifically what is his provision (رزقه) among what he possesses. If he is granted the unveiling (كوشف), he acts according to his unveiling, for the ruling in this matter belongs to Knowledge (العلم). If he is not granted the unveiling, the preferable course for him is to give away all his wealth as charity for Allah. His provision will inevitably come to him, trusting in what is with Allah, if he still has anything due to him from Allah. If nothing remains for him with Allah, then his retention of what is legally his property will not benefit him, for he does not deserve it by way of unveiling (كشفا) in reality. He is leaving it behind, and this is not praiseworthy. These are the states of the Gnostics.

### [The Gnostic Who Receives Unveiling Giving Away His Wealth]

The one who receives the unveiling (صاحب الكشف) may give away all his wealth based on his unveiling, because he sees the name of another upon it and thus deserves nothing from it. In appearance, he resembles the one who gives away all his wealth without having received the unveiling. If the latter does not possess trust in Allah (ثقة بالله), then the Law (الشرع) condemns him if he gives away all his wealth and then subsequently begs people for charity. The charity of such a person is not accepted, as has been narrated in the Hadith of An-Nasa’i concerning the man who was given two garments as charity, and then another man came asking for charity. The first recipient gave one of his two garments as charity to the second. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) rebuked him, saying, "Take your garment," and did not accept his charity.

If a person knows himself that he will neither beg nor expose himself (to need), then he is permitted to give away all his wealth, but only according to the measure of preference (ميزان الأفضلية) if he is a scholar (عالما) and does not possess the unveiling. If he is a possessor of unveiling (صاحب كشف), he acts according to his unveiling. Abu Dawud narrated what corresponds to what we have mentioned, from the Hadith of Umar ibn al-Khattab, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) commanded us one day to give charity. This coincided with wealth I possessed. I said, "Today I will surpass Abu Bakr, if I am ever to surpass him." So I brought half of my wealth. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) asked, "What have you left for your family?" I said, "The like of it." Then Abu Bakr came with everything he possessed. He asked, "What have you left for your family?" He replied, "I have left Allah and His Messenger for them." I said, "I shall never compete with you in anything."

### [Treating the Soul According to the Law Governing It]

It is incumbent upon the one who knows his soul (العالم بنفسه) to treat it according to the Law (الشرع) that governs him. The seeker (المريد) should not look to what crosses his mind at the moment, lest he fall under the rule of his passing thought (خاطره), resulting in his errors being greater than his correctness. Herein lies the distinction between the intelligent scholar (العاقل العالم) and the ignorant one. However, all this applies to the People of Allah (أهل الله) who do not possess the unveiling. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) remained silent regarding Abu Bakr when he brought all his wealth, due to his knowledge of Abu Bakr’s state and station (مقامه). He did not say to him, "Why did you not keep something of your wealth?" He praised Umar for his action in the presence of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) and did not disapprove of it. But he said to Ka’b ibn Malik in this Hadith, "Keep some of your wealth." Ka’b ibn Malik had given away all his wealth as charity due to a thought (خاطر) that crossed his mind. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) did not treat him according to his passing thought, but according to what his state required, saying, "Keep some of your wealth, for that is better for you."

(Section concerning what the Gnostic observes regarding the Grace of Allah, His Justice, and the Cunning of Allah the Exalted)

### [The Gnostics Always Observe the States of Their Souls]

Indeed, it is part of the Cunning of Allah (مكر الله), His Justice (عدله), and His Grace (فضله) that He clarifies to people what is beneficial for them—this is from His Grace. As for His Justice and His Cunning, it is that He deals with them according to their attributes (صفاتهم). The Gnostics (العارفون) in such a station always observe the states of their souls (أحوال أنفسهم) and what Allah grants them, inwardly and outwardly. They weigh this with the balance (الميزان) that the All-Merciful (الرحمن) established, so that the weight may be maintained with justice (القسط) and the balance not be deficient. If the two pans are balanced, that is sound knowledge (العلم الصحيح). If the pan of the bestowal (العطاء) outweighs the pan of the state (الحال), then let him examine the state. If the state is one that the Law praises, then that is either a hastened reward or an increase in grace (زيادة فضل). If the state is one that the tongue of the Law condemns, then that is Cunning from Allah (مكر من الله). If the state is neither condemned nor praised, then that is Justice from Allah, which will lead either to Grace (فضل)—if he thanks Allah and acts in obedience in the future with those bestowals—or it will lead to hidden Cunning (مكر خفي) if he acts therein with disobedience to Allah. If he is inspired to seek forgiveness and repentance, or to realize that it is Divine Cunning (مكر إلهي), then he will either rectify the matter or remain in his state. If he remains in his state, it is Cunning within Cunning (مكر في مكر). If he rectifies the matter, that is from the Grace of Allah, and the ruling of Cunning is removed from him in this state.

### [The Upper Hand is Better than the Lower Hand, in terms of Cunning and Grace]

Part of the Cunning of Allah and His Grace is that the upper hand (اليد العليا) is better than the lower hand (اليد السفلى), for charity falls into the Hand of the All-Merciful (يد الرحمن). In this, there is Cunning and Grace, for it has been narrated that it falls into the Hand of the All-Merciful before it falls into the hand of the beggar.

Al-Bukhari mentioned, concerning what we have drawn attention to, on the authority of Hakim ibn Hizam, that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "The upper hand is better than the lower hand. Begin with those whom you support. The best charity is that which is given from surplus wealth (عن ظهر غنى). Whoever seeks self-sufficiency (يستعفف), Allah will make him self-sufficient. Whoever seeks richness (يستغن), Allah will enrich him."

This Hadith contains the details of the states we have mentioned.

### [The Highest Richness is Richness in Allah]

The highest richness (أعلى الغني) is richness in Allah (الغني بالله). Self-sufficiency (*isti'faf*) here means contentment with little (القناعة بالقليل), for the word *al-afw* (عفو) is used in the language to mean "the little," and it is one of the contraries (الأضداد). Charity given from surplus wealth (عن ظهر غنى) is true charity. And supplication made from absolute poverty (عن ظهر فقر) is undoubtedly the answered supplication. But where is the supplicant who supplicates from absolute poverty, and the giver who gives from surplus wealth?

(Section concerning the soul’s need for Knowledge)

### [Legal, Divine, and Eschatological Knowledge]

Know that the soul’s need for Knowledge (العلم) is greater than the temperament’s need for the nourishment that sustains it. Knowledge is of two kinds: Knowledge that is needed just as nourishment is needed, and in this, one should be moderate and restrict oneself to the necessary amount. This is the knowledge of legal rulings (علم الأحكام الشرعية). One should only look into it as much as is needed at the moment, for its ruling is only related to actions occurring in this world. So, take from it only what corresponds to your action. The other kind of Knowledge is that which has no limit to stop at. This is the Knowledge related to Allah and the stations of the Resurrection (مواطن القيامة). Knowledge of the stations of the Resurrection leads the knower to prepare for each station with what is appropriate for it, because The Real (الحق) Himself is the one who demands the lifting of the veils (ارتفاع الحجب) on that Day, which is the Day of Separation (يوم الفصل). Therefore, the intelligent person (الإنسان العاقل) should be fully aware of his affair, prepared to answer for himself and for others in the stations where he knows an answer will be required of him. For this reason, we have attached it to the Knowledge of Allah.

### [The Seeker of Knowledge Should Ask None but Allah Concerning the Subject of Inquiry]

It is incumbent upon the seeker of Knowledge (طالب العلم) to ask none but Allah concerning the subject of inquiry (المسئول), not the person being asked (عين المسئول). This is how the questioner should be, present with Allah (الحضور مع الله). Let this questioner ask frequently, for Allah is the One being asked. If he does not achieve this presence, and only witnesses the teacher (الأستاذ), seeing knowledge only coming from him, and that scholar does not direct him back to Allah by saying, "Allah knows best," nor does he give him knowledge that directs him back to Allah—then that is what the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) referred to, as mentioned by Muslim in the Hadith of Abu Hurayrah: "Whoever asks people for their wealth to increase his own, is only asking for burning coals, so let him ask little or much."

Allah the Exalted only intended for His servants to return to Him in matters of inquiry, not to their peers, except to the extent that they learn from them how to ask Allah. This is the limit of the prescribed piety (حد التقوى المشروع). He said: <<وَاتَّقُوا اللَّهَ>> (And fear Allah) [Q. 2:282] with what He taught you, from His informing you of the path of piety, <<وَيُعَلِّمُكُمُ اللَّهُ>> (And Allah teaches you) [Q. 2:282]. Thus, He, glory be to Him, is the Teacher. This applies whether the inquiry is about Knowledge or about other worldly matters, as His Lord, the Mighty and Majestic, said to Moses (peace be upon him) in what He revealed or spoke to him: "Ask Me, even for the salt you put in your dough."

And He said, in the context of allusion (الإشارة) and not exegesis (التفسير): <<الرَّحْمَنُ * عَلَّمَ الْقُرْآنَ>> (The All-Merciful taught the Qur'an) [Q. 55:1-2]—in which heart it resides and settles, and upon which heart it descends—<<خَلَقَ الْإِنسَانَ * عَلَّمَهُ الْبَيَانَ>> (He created man, He taught him clear expression) [Q. 55:3-4], so that you may clarify to people what has been revealed to them. Thus, He attributed the teaching to Himself, not to others. All of this stems from Divine Jealousy (الغيرة الإلهية): that the created being should ask other than his Creator, so that He may relieve His servants from asking those who possess nothing of the matter. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) drew attention to this, and he did not specify one type of asking over another.

The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "If you knew what is involved in asking, no one would walk to another asking him for anything." The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) disliked asking and criticized it.

He desired that people act upon what Allah taught them through His Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) and ask Allah in their actions to increase them in Knowledge from Him. Thus, He Himself undertakes the teaching of His servants, for Allah is Jealous (غيور) and does not like that others be asked. Even if one asks another with the apparent tongue, the heart should be present with Allah during the asking, knowing that Allah is the One being asked, <<الَّذِي بِيَدِهِ مَلَكُوتُ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ>> (in whose hand is the dominion of all things) [Q. 36:83]—in the essential meaning (بالمعنى). For the apparent name (الاسم الظاهر) of Allah is this person, as he is one of the letters inscribed on the scroll of Existence (رق الوجود) that is unfolded. Thus, this questioner receives his answer from Allah, either by the fulfillment of the need or by the supplication.

### [Asking the Ruler is Preferable to Asking Others]

For this reason, a man asking the ruler (السلطان) is preferable to asking others, because the presence of The Real (وجود الحق) is more manifest in him than in others, such as commoners and the general populace. This is why begging (الكدية) is lifted from those who ask kings, for they are the deputies of Allah (نواب الله) and the locus of the creation's need. They are commanded not to repel the beggar. Allah says to His Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), who is the Greatest Deputy (النائب الأكبر): <<وَأَمَّا السَّائِلَ فَلَا تَنْهَرْ>> (And as for the beggar, do not repel him) [Q. 93:10]. For this reason, Allah the Exalted will question the deputies—the shepherds (الرعاة)—on the Day of Resurrection concerning those entrusted to their care, and He will question the flock (الرعايا) about what they did concerning them. Then we return to the matters of charity (الصدقة) that we are discussing, and we say:

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Asking is scratches (كدوج) with which a man scratches his face. So let him who wishes preserve his face, and let him who wishes abandon it, unless he asks a ruler (ذا سلطان) concerning a matter from which he cannot escape." This is the explicit text of what we mentioned, a Hadith narrated by Abu Dawud on the authority of Samurah ibn Jundub from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him).

### [Asking the Righteous Gnostics is Preferable to Asking Rulers]

Likewise, asking the righteous Gnostics (الصالحين العارفين), the People of Vigilance (أهل المراقبة), is preferable to asking rulers, unless the ruler possesses these attributes. For the possessors of these attributes have a closer relationship (نسبة) to Allah the Exalted. By the grace of Allah, we have seen rulers who attained this rank of religiosity, piety, and upholding the truth by the Truth (القيام للحق بالحق)—may Allah have mercy on them. It has been narrated in a report that a man said to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), "Should I ask, O Messenger of Allah?" He said, "No. But if you must ask, then ask the righteous."

When the Gnostics (العارفون) ask concerning a matter designated for them regarding their worldly interests, they only ask Allah, through Allah, in the world (في العالم).

### [The Best Charity Allah Bestowed Upon His Near Servants]

The scholars of Allah (العلماء بالله), whose witnessing of Allah (شهود الله) has completely absorbed them, are preoccupied by the remembrance of Allah (ذكر الله) from asking Allah. These are the People of States (أصحاب أحوال). He granted them Knowledge of Him (العلم به), which is the best thing granted to those who ask. When they know Him with the knowledge of direct experience (علم ذوق), they remember Him only for Him, through them, and by Him. Through this remembrance, He granted them a matter that caused them to abandon remembrance for Him and by Him. Then He granted them Vision (الرؤية), since Vision is higher than Witnessing (المشاهدة). This is the best charity (صدقة) Allah bestowed upon His near servants (المقربين من عباده).

(Section concerning the scholars of Allah receiving Gifted Knowledge from Allah)

### [Gifted Knowledge is Ladunni Knowledge]

Know that the scholars of Allah (العلماء بالله) only receive Gifted Knowledge (العلم الموهوب), which is Ladunni Knowledge (العلم اللدني)—the knowledge of the Divine Presence (علم الحضر) and its like. This is the knowledge in which they do not exert any thought (خاطر) whatsoever, so that it is not tainted by any impurities of acquisition (كدورات الكسب). For the Divine Theophany (التجلي الإلهي) stripped of contingent substances (المواد الإمكانية)—such as spirit, body, and intellect—is more perfect than the Divine Theophany in contingent substances. And some theophanies in contingent substances are more perfect than others. If a scholar of Allah experiences a Divine Theophany that is nobler than another theophany he had not previously attained, and then he attains it later, and it grants him knowledge of Him that he did not possess, he does not accept it as Gifted Knowledge (العلم الموهوب) but attaches it to Acquired Knowledge (العلم المكتسب).

### [Acquired Knowledge]

Every knowledge he obtains through a specific supplication (دعاء فيه) or a general supplication is acquired (مكتسب). This is only suitable for the Messengers (peace and blessings of Allah be upon them), for they are in the domain of legislating acquisition (تشريع الاكتساب). If they stand with their Prophethood (نبوتهم) and not their Messengership (رسالتهم), their state with Allah is as we mentioned: abandoning the seeking of anything other than Him and the noble things. They stand with Allah, looking toward Him, and speaking by Him (به ناطقون) in every utterance, every object of vision, and every station where they stand.

### [Obligation is Nothing but Command and Prohibition]

Just as they speak by Him, they also hear by Him. They remember His servants out of devotion (تعبدا), and they obey His servants out of devotion. They strive and do not slacken in worship, not seeking exposure or gain, but only fulfilling what is required by the station of the One who obligated them, from the perspective of Him being the Obligator, and not from any other perspective. The station of the One who obligated them bestows upon them knowledge from His Presence (لدنه) that was not sought by them, thus making it acquired. Among His Names (الأسماء) is *Al-Mu’min* (The Giver of Security), which is one of the attributes (نعوت) of the servant, not one of the Names of the servant. For if it were a Name, it would not be conditioned (لم يعلل), but if it is an attribute, it is conditioned. It is a Name for Allah and an attribute for the servant. This is the proper conduct (الأدب) with Allah. A Hadith supporting what we have alluded to was narrated:

Abu Umar ibn Abd al-Barr al-Namari mentioned on the authority of Khalid ibn Adi al-Juhani, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) say: "Whoever receives a kindness (معروف) from his brother without seeking it or asking for it, let him accept it and not reject it, for it is only provision (رزق) that Allah has driven to him."

This Hadith combines the command to accept and the prohibition against rejecting, thus encompassing the entirety of religious obligation (التكليف), for obligation is nothing but command and prohibition.

### [The Great Ones Neither Ask Anyone for Anything Nor Reject Anything]

What supports the authenticity of this Hadith is what Muslim narrated in his *Sahih* on the authority of Ibn Umar: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) used to give Umar ibn al-Khattab a gift, and Umar would say, "Give it, O Messenger of Allah, to someone poorer than me." The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said to him, "Take it, manage it, or give it as charity. Whatever comes to you from this wealth, while you are neither seeking it nor asking for it, take it. But what does not, do not let your soul pursue it."
