The Great Ones (الأكابر) do not ask anyone for anything, unless Allah is their Witnessed Reality (مشهودهم) in all things, and they do not reject anything given to them, for the proper conduct with Allah (الأدب مع الله) is not to reject what He has given you.

### [The Trial of Knowledge is Greater than the Trial of Wealth]

The trial (فتنة) of Knowledge (العلم) is greater than the trial of wealth (المال). For the nobility of wealth is an accidental nobility (شرف عارض) that does not extend beyond the mouths of people; the soul derives no attribute from it. But the nobility of Knowledge is an adornment (حلية) with which the soul is adorned, so its trial is greater. It does not depart from its possessor, whether in poverty, richness, or calamity. Wealth departs from its owner through a thief who takes it, or by fire, drowning, collapse, earthquake, heavenly disaster, trial, or ruler. Knowledge is within you in an impregnable fortress (حصن حصين) that can never be reached. It accompanies the human being alive and dead, in this world and the Hereafter. It is for you in every state. Even if it seems to be against you at one time, it is ultimately for you. If calamities befall you because of it, do not worry, for that is only due to its nobility, since you did not act upon it. You were afflicted only by your abandonment of action upon it, not by the Knowledge itself. When you are saved, it takes your hand to its station (منزلته), and its station is known, and what is known is The Real (الحق). Thus, it settles you with The Real according to that Knowledge. So, do not be among the ignorant.

(Section concerning Allah making Zakat obligatory upon the Generated Things)

### [The Generated Things (Mawalladat) are Generated from the Movement of the Sphere and the Elements]

Know that Allah made Zakat (الزكاة) obligatory upon the Generated Things (المولدات), which are three: minerals (معدن), plants (نبات), and animals (حيوان). Minerals are gold and silver; plants are wheat, barley, and dates; and animals are camels, cattle, and sheep. He encompassed all the Generated Things and applied the name *Mawalladat* to them because they are generated from a mother and a father: from the celestial sphere (فلك) and its movement, which is analogous to intercourse (الجماع) and is the father, and the elements (الأركان) which are the mother.

### [Zakat, While Purification, is Also a Loss of Wealth]

Wealth was beloved to man, like the love of a child. Do you not see that Allah coupled it with children in the context of trial (الفتنة), saying: <<إِنَّمَا أَمْوَالُكُمْ وَأَوْلَادُكُمْ فِتْنَةٌ>> (Indeed, your wealth and your children are a trial) [Q. 64:15]? He mentioned wealth before children. And <<وَاللَّهُ عِندَهُ أَجْرٌ عَظِيمٌ>> (And Allah has a great reward) [Q. 64:15] if He afflicts you with a loss (رزأكم) in either of them. Zakat, although it is the purification (طهارة) of wealth and purifies its owners from the attribute of stinginess (البخل), is undoubtedly a loss (رزء) in wealth. Thus, its giver receives the reward of the afflicted (أجر المصاب), which is one of the greatest rewards.

### [The Child is a Branch (Shujnah) of the Parent, just as the Womb (Rahim) is a Branch of the All-Merciful (Rahman)]

The child (الولد) is a branch (*shujnah*) of the parent, just as the womb (*al-rahim*) is a branch (*shujnah*) of the All-Merciful (*al-Rahman*). Whoever maintains connection with it, Allah connects with him, and whoever severs it, Allah severs him. One of the poets said concerning children, in a poem of valor (*Hamasah*):

> Our children among us are but our livers walking upon the earth.

Thus, he made the child a piece of the liver.

### [The Heart of Every Person is Where His Wealth Is]

Jesus (peace be upon him) said to his companions: "The heart of every person is where his wealth is. So, place your wealth in heaven, and your hearts will be in heaven."

He encouraged charity because he knew that charity falls into the Hand of the All-Merciful (يد الرحمن), and He says: <<أَأَمِنتُم مَّن فِي السَّمَاءِ>> (Do you feel secure that He who is in the heaven) [Q. 67:16]? And charity extinguishes the wrath of the Lord.

Look at how wondrous, subtle, and sweet the speech of Prophethood is! Whoever attaches the child to the parent and connects him to him receives the reward of maintaining kinship (صلة الرحم). Therefore, it is incumbent upon a person to attach his wealth—since it is a generated thing (*mawlid*) born of its father from which it was generated—because it is a piece of him. Thus, the person who gives Zakat charity receives the reward of the afflicted and the reward of maintaining kinship when he purifies his wealth (زكى ماله).

### [Patience in the Loss of the Beloved is Only Possible for a Believer or a Gnostic]

Patience (الصبر) in the loss of the beloved is among the greatest forms of patience, and only a believer (مؤمن) or a Gnostic (عارف) can endure it. The ascetic (الزاهد) owes no Zakat, because he has left nothing upon which Zakat is obligatory, for asceticism requires that. The Gnostic (العارف) is not like that, because the Gnostic knows that within him, as the totality of the world (مجموع العالم), there is one who seeks wealth and fulfills its right, so Zakat becomes obligatory upon him from that perspective. He is an ascetic from one perspective. For this reason, we favored the opinion of those who say that Zakat is obligatory upon the wealth, not upon the obligated person (المكلف), but he is obligated to extract it from the wealth, since the wealth cannot extract itself.

Thus, the Gnostic combines both rewards, unlike the ascetic. The Gnostics are the perfect men (الكمل من الرجال). They possess asceticism and hoarding, reliance (التوكل) and acquisition (الاكتساب). They possess love for the entire world (العالم كله), even if the aspects of love differ. They love everything that occurs in the world through Allah's love for the existence of that occurrence, not from the perspective of the essence of the occurrence. Know this, for in it lies a subtle Divine Cunning (دقيق مكر إلهي) that only the refined Gnostics (الأدباء العارفون) perceive. The Gnostic knows that within him is a recompense (جزاء) that seeks correspondence from the world, so he gives every possessor of a right his due, just as Allah <<أَعْطَى كُلَّ شَيْءٍ خَلْقَهُ>> (gave everything its creation) [Q. 20:50].

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Indeed, your soul has a right over you, and your eye has a right over you."

Likewise, every part of you has a right. For this reason, they will bear witness against you on the Day of Resurrection if The Real (الحق) calls them to witness against you. Consider the wisdom of the Samiri, who knew what Jesus (peace be upon him) said—that the love of wealth is attached to hearts. He fashioned the calf for them from their melted ornaments, in their sight, knowing that their hearts follow their wealth, so they rushed to worship it when he called them to do so.

The Gnostic (العارف), from the perspective of his Divine Secret (سره الرباني), is a vicegerent (مستخلف) over the wealth in his hand. He is like a guardian (الوصي) over the property of a minor, extracting Zakat from it, yet possessing nothing of it himself. That is why we said it is a right upon the wealth. For the minor is not obligated to anything, yet the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) commanded trading with the orphan's wealth so that charity (الصدقة) would not consume it.

The commoner (العامي), although he is a comprehensive being like the Gnostic, does not know this. Thus, the wealth is attributed to him, and it is said to him, "Your wealth" (أموالكم), and he extracts Zakat from it. The Gnostic extracts it as a guardian, while the commoner extracts it based on the ruling of ownership. <<وَمَا يُؤْمِنُ أَكْثَرُهُمْ بِاللَّهِ إِلَّا وَهُمْ مُشْرِكُونَ>> (And most of them do not believe in Allah except while they associate others with Him) [Q. 12:106]. Both groups are truthful in their state and possess Divine evidence (دليل إلهي) in what is attributed to them.

### [From Which Relationship is the Gnostic's Love Derived]

Were it not for love (المحبة), Zakat would not have been mandated, so that they might be rewarded with the reward of one afflicted by the loss of his beloved (رزئ في محبوبه). Were it not for the correspondence (المناسبة) between the lover and the beloved, there would be no love, nor could its existence be conceived. From this, you understand the relationship (نسبة) from which the Gnostic's love for wealth is derived, and the relationship from which his love for Allah is derived. His love for wealth and the world does not invalidate his love for Allah and the Hereafter, for what he loves of it is for a specific purpose that corresponds to that purpose in Divine matters and in the world. "Love Allah for what He nourishes you with of His blessings." Thus, the correspondence is sound.

### [Gnosis is the Wealth of the Gnostic, and its Zakat is Teaching]

Among His blessings is Gnosis (المعرفة) of Him, and the Gnostic seeks it from Him. This is the relationship of a poor person (فقير) to a rich person (غني), asking Him for what is in His hand for him, so that he may obtain it. He only asks Him for a contingent matter (أمرا حادثا), since the knowledge of the contingent being concerning the Eternal is contingent knowledge. Thus, the correspondence between him and Gnosis is contingency (الحدوث), and it is in the hand of the Known One (المعروف). Love is therefore attached to the Known One due to this correspondence. Gnosis of Him is unending and limitless, so the love is unending. The attainment of such Gnosis comes from Theophany (التجلي), and Theophany is unending. Thus, Gnosis (المعرفة) is the wealth of the Gnostic, and the Zakat of this wealth is teaching (التعليم). This is a Divine Degree (درجة إلهية). Allah the Exalted said: <<وَاتَّقُوا اللَّهَ وَيُعَلِّمُكُمُ اللَّهُ>> (And fear Allah; and Allah teaches you) [Q. 2:282]. He is the Teacher. For this reason, we said that teaching is a Divine Degree.

### [The Eight Categories of Zakat and the Eight Bearers of the Throne]

He made the categories of Zakat eight (ثمانية) because of the rectification of the world (صلاح العالم) contained within them. They relate to what sustains bodies through nourishment and the fulfillment of needs absolutely. In these two matters lies the rectification of the world. They are the eight bearers of the Throne (حملة العرش الثمانية), and the Throne, which is the Dominion (الملك), is borne by them. From that Reality (الحقيقة), Zakat was established in eight agreed-upon categories. Anything besides them that is disputed refers back to these eight. Since the Throne is the Dominion, and the bearers of this Throne—which is an expression for us—were these eight categories, this amount of wealth expressed as Zakat is like the wage (الأجرة) for their bearing.

(Section) [Why Wealth is Called Mal]

Wealth (*al-mal*) was only named *mal* because souls incline (*yamīl*) toward it. Souls only incline toward it because Allah placed in it the fulfillment of needs, and man was created with need because he is essentially poor (فقير بالذات). Thus, he inclines toward it by an intrinsic nature (بالطبع) that never leaves him. If asceticism regarding wealth were a reality, it would not be called wealth. And asceticism regarding the Hereafter would be a more perfect station than asceticism regarding the world, but this is not the case. Allah has promised to multiply the reward of a good deed by ten times up to seven hundred times. If a small amount were a veil (حجاب), a large amount of it would be an even greater veil.

### [The Door Where We Find Allah]

Do you not see the station of Theophany and Unveiling (موطن التجلي والكشف), which is the Abode of the Hereafter (الدار الآخرة)? It is the place of Vision (الرؤية) and Witnessing (المشاهدة), along with the absolute attainment of sensual desires (الشهوات النفسية) without restriction, and the word "Be" (*kun*) is ruling for every human therein. If such a thing were a veil, the veil of the Hereafter would be denser and greater by an incomparable degree. Glory be to Him who made for Himself a door in everything; when that door is opened, Allah is found there. And He designated a Divine Face (وجها إلهيا) in everything; when He manifests (تجلى), that Face is known from that thing. Al-Siddiq (Abu Bakr) said: "I did not see a thing except that I saw Allah before it." For he only sees it with His Eye, since The Real (الحق) is his sight in this station. Thus, he sees himself before seeing that thing, and the human is the locus (المحل) for that sight. For this reason, he said, "I did not see a thing except that I saw Allah before it." Allah called it Zakat because of the growth (*al-rubu*) and increase contained within it. For this reason, you give a little and find it to be much. If you gave it to lift the veil because it was a veil, the reward would be many veils, greater than this veil. Therefore, by the grace of Allah, what you gave was not a veil, nor was what you attained from it a veil. Know this.

Look at the Gnostic's disposition (تصرف العارف) in the world and how it is. Do not judge his disposition based on your own disposition, your ignorance, and your poor interpretation, thereby seeing asceticism (الزهد) as superior to it. Far from it! <<هَلْ يَسْتَوِي الَّذِينَ يَعْلَمُونَ وَالَّذِينَ لَا يَعْلَمُونَ إِنَّمَا يَتَذَكَّرُ أُولُو الْأَلْبَابِ>> (Are those who know equal to those who do not know? Only those of understanding will remember) [Q. 39:9]. Rather, for the Gnostic, it is a Solomonic attribute of perfection (صفة كمالية سليمانية): <<هَبْ لِي مُلْكًا لَّا يَنبَغِي لِأَحَدٍ مِّن بَعْدِي إِنَّكَ أَنتَ الْوَهَّابُ>> (Grant me a kingdom which will not belong to anyone after me. Indeed, You are the Bestower) [Q. 38:35]. How fitting is this Name (*Al-Wahhab*) for this request! Do you think he (peace be upon him) asked for something that would veil him from Allah, or something that would distance him from Allah?

### [The Solomonic Attribute of Perfection and the Muhammadan State]

Then look at the proper conduct (أدب) of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) when Allah enabled him to seize the Ifrit that attacked him. He intended to capture it and tie it to one of the pillars of the mosque so that people could look at it, but then he remembered the supplication of his brother Solomon. So, Allah repelled it, disgraced. This was a Solomonic state (حالة سليمانية) that occurred for Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him). What deterred him from it was not asceticism regarding it, but rather proper conduct toward Solomon (peace be upon him), who had asked his Lord for a kingdom that would not belong to anyone after him. We learn from this story that his saying, "which will not belong," means that its manifestation in the visible world (في الشاهد للناس) should not belong to anyone, even if the potential for it is granted to some people, such as the Messenger of Allah’s encounter with the Ifrit. Thus, we know that Solomon intended the manifestation of that kingdom for the eyes of people. Then Allah answered Solomon (peace be upon him) in what he requested by reminding the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) of his brother Solomon’s supplication, so that what had crossed his mind regarding the manifestation would not proceed. Then Allah perfected this blessing for Solomon (peace be upon him) in the Abode of Obligation (دار التكليف), saying to him: <<هَذَا عَطَاؤُنَا فَامْنُنْ أَوْ أَمْسِكْ بِغَيْرِ حِسَابٍ>> (This is Our bestowal, so grant or withhold without reckoning) [Q. 38:39]. Thus, He removed the restriction from him in disposing of things by the Name *Al-Mani'* (The Withholder) and *Al-Mu'ti* (The Giver). He was thus distinguished with a hastened paradise in the life of this world, and this kingdom did not veil him from his Lord, the Mighty and Majestic.

### [The Gnostic Combining the Two Essences and Realizing the Two Realities]

Look at the degree of the Gnostic (العارف) and how he combines the two essences (العينين) and realizes the two realities (الحقيقتين). He extracts Zakat from the wealth in his hand as a guardian extracts it from the property of a minor, based on His saying: <<وَأَنفِقُوا مِمَّا جَعَلَكُم مُّسْتَخْلَفِينَ فِيهِ>> (And spend from that over which He has made you successors) [Q. 57:7]. Thus, He made him the owner of the spending (مالكا للإنفاق) from a Divine Reality (حقيقة إلهية) within him, concerning wealth that is the property of another reality within him, of which he is the guardian (وليها) from the perspective of the Divine Reality. May Allah make us among the Gnostics and scholars, and among those entrusted with the delight of the eyes (قرة أعين) placed within him.

(Section concerning the statement that wealth has types of bestowal)

### [The Types of Bestowal Attributed to The Real and the Servant]

Know that wealth accepts types of bestowal (أنواع العطاء), which are eight types with eight names: one type is called *In'am* (Benefaction), one is called *Hibah* (Gift), one is called *Sadaqah* (Charity), one is called *Karam* (Generosity/Nobility), one is called *Hadiyyah* (Present), one is called *Jud* (Munificence), one is called *Sakha'* (Liberality), and one is called *Ithar* (Altruism/Preferring others). All these types are used by the human giver, but The Real (الحق) the Exalted gives by seven of them, excluding *Ithar*.

### [From Which Reality Did Altruism Manifest in the Cosmos]

If an outsider asks, "From which Divine Reality (حقيقة إلهية) did Altruism (*Ithar*) manifest in the cosmos, since He does not give by way of *Ithar* because He is rich beyond need, and *Ithar* is giving away what you yourself need, either immediately or potentially? It is giving while the thought occurs to the soul that you need it, so you give it despite this thought, making your bestowal *Ithar*. This is impossible concerning The Real. Thus, a matter has appeared in Existence (الوجود) that is not connected to a Divine Reality."

We respond: We have previously established that Absolute Richness (الغني المطلق) belongs to The Real only from the perspective of His Essence (ذاته), stripped of any relationship to the world. If you relate the world to Him, the Essence is not considered, and Richness is not considered. Rather, His being a God (إلها) is considered, and thus the Level (المرتبة) is considered. What is appropriate for the Level is what it is named by—the Divine Form (الصورة الإلهية)—not the Essence in itself, but from the perspective of its being a God. Then He gave you the Form, which is the Vicegerency (الخلافة), and named you with all the Names by way of praise. Thus, He gave you what the Level’s relationship to Him is based upon, which are the Beautiful Names (الأسماء الحسنى).

### [Altruism is Giving Away What You Need]

If you say, "The giver does not retain what he gave," we say: This refers back to the reality of what is given. If it is sensible (محسوسا), the giver loses it upon giving. If it is a meaning (معنى), he does not lose it upon giving. For this reason, we defined Altruism (*Ithar*) as giving away what you need, and we did not address the giver’s loss or retention, for that refers back to the reality of the thing given. Know this. From this Reality, Altruism originated in the world. There is no clearer explanation after this.

### [Explanation of the Eight Types of Bestowal]

Benefaction (*Al-In'am*) is giving what is a blessing (*ni'mah*) for the recipient, something that suits his temperament and agrees with his purpose. Gift (*Al-Hibah*) is giving specifically for the recipient to enjoy. Present (*Al-Hadiyyah*) is giving to attract love, for it stems from love. For this reason, the Lawgiver said, "Exchange presents, and you will love one another." Charity (*Al-Sadaqah*) is giving out of severity, compulsion, and refusal (إباية). As for the human, because he is naturally inclined to stinginess, <<وَمَن يُوقَ شُحَّ نَفْسِهِ>> (And whoever is protected from the stinginess of his own soul) [Q. 59:9] and <<وَإِذَا مَسَّهُ الْخَيْرُ مَنُوعًا>> (And when good touches him, he is stingy) [Q. 70:21]. If he gives in this manner, his giving is only due to his compulsion of what the soul is naturally inclined to.

Concerning The Real (الحق), this relationship is the reality of what has been narrated regarding the Divine Hesitation (التردد الإلهي) in taking the soul of the believer, even though He must meet him—meaning taking his spirit—along with the hesitation, due to what preceded in Knowledge concerning that. Thus, in relation to The Real, it is *as if* (كأنه), but in relation to the servant, it is not *as if*—this is Divine proper conduct (أدبا إلهيا). The evidence of the intellect rejects such a thing due to its deficiency and its lack of knowledge concerning what the Adored God deserves. The Real is known by this Reality upon which His worship rests. Sound intellects (العقول السليمة) accept it, free from the judgment of their own thoughts upon it, with the attribute of acceptance that is upon it, even when the intellects governed by their own thoughts reject it. This is the Gnosis (المعرفة) that the Lawgiver commanded us to know our Lord by and to describe Him with, not the Gnosis by which we established Him, for that is what the intellect can independently grasp, and it is inferior compared to this Gnosis. That was established by the ruling of the intellect, while this is established by Divine reports, and He is in every way more knowledgeable of Himself than we are of Him.

Generosity (*Al-Karam*) is giving after being asked, truly (حقاً) and createdly (خلقاً). Munificence (*Al-Jud*) is giving before being asked, truly, but not createdly. If it is attributed to the created being, it is because The Real did not ask him for this specific thing that the created being designated. Rather, The Real only asked him to volunteer charity (صدقة), without specifying. If the servant designates a garment, a dirham, a dinar, or whatever it may be, without being asked for it, that is Munificence (*Jud*) createdly. We said "not createdly" in that context because he does not give for the purpose of drawing near (القربة) except by Divine instruction. For this reason, we said "truly, but not createdly." If the Law is not considered in this, then giving before asking, not for the purpose of drawing near, certainly exists in the world. However, the Sufi’s aim is only to act in a matter that constitutes drawing near (قربة) necessarily. Thus, he has no escape from observing the ruling of the Law in this.

Liberality (*Al-Sakha'*) is giving according to the need, without excess, due to a benefit seen by the giver. If he were to exceed that, it might lead to the destruction of the recipient. Allah the Exalted said: <<وَلَوْ بَسَطَ اللَّهُ الرِّزْقَ لِعِبَادِهِ لَبَغَوْا فِي الْأَرْضِ وَلَكِن يُنَزِّلُ بِقَدَرٍ مَّا يَشَاءُ>> (And if Allah had extended [excessively] the provision for His servants, they would have committed tyranny on earth; but He sends down in measure what He wills) [Q. 42:27]. Altruism (*Al-Ithar*) is giving away what you need at the moment, or what you imagine you need. Allah the Exalted said: <<وَيُؤْثِرُونَ عَلَى أَنفُسِهِمْ وَلَوْ كَانَ بِهِمْ خَصَاصَةٌ>> (And they give preference [to others] over themselves, even though they are in need) [Q. 59:9].

### [Bestowal (Wahb) is a Divine Origin, and Charity (Sadaqah) is a Cosmic Origin]

All the types of bestowal we have mentioned are Charity (*Sadaqah*) concerning the servant, because he is naturally inclined to stinginess and avarice. Just as the fundamental principle (الأصل) in Divine bestowals among these eight categories is Bestowal (*Al-Wahb*), which is giving for the recipient to enjoy, not for another purpose. Thus, He is *Al-Wahhab* (The Bestower) in reality concerning all types of His giving. Likewise, the servant is a giver of charity (*mutasaddiq*) in all his bestowals, because he is not free from purpose and the seeking of recompense due to his essential poverty (فقره الذاتي). What is attributed to Allah by way of accident (العرض) is attributed to the created being by way of essence (الذات). And what is attributed to The Real by way of essence, such as Richness (الغنى), is attributed to the created being by way of relative, additional accident (بالعرض النسبي الإضافي) only. Allah the Exalted said to His Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him): <<خُذْ مِنْ أَمْوَالِهِمْ صَدَقَةً>> (Take from their wealth a charity) [Q. 9:103], meaning what is difficult for their souls to give. For this reason, Tha’labah ibn Hatib said, "This is the brother of the *jizyah* (tribute)," when it became difficult for him, after he had made a covenant with Allah, as Allah informed us in His saying: <<وَمِنْهُم مَّنْ عَاهَدَ اللَّهَ>> (And among them are those who made a covenant with Allah) [Q. 9:75]. When Allah provided him with wealth and mandated charity upon him, he said what Allah reported about him, and His saying <<بَخِلُوا بِهِ>> (they withheld it stingily) [Q. 9:76] is the attribute of the soul upon which it was created. If this attribute governs the servant, Allah replaces him with others. We ask Allah for well-being. It is narrated: <<وَإِن تَتَوَلَّوْا يَسْتَبْدِلْ قَوْمًا غَيْرَكُمْ ثُمَّ لَا يَكُونُوا أَمْثَالَكُمْ>> (And if you turn away, He will substitute [for you] a people other than you; then they will not be like you) [Q. 47:38], meaning, they will not be upon your attribute, but they will give what is asked, as He said: <<فَإِن يَكْفُرْ بِهَا هَؤُلَاءِ فَقَدْ وَكَّلْنَا بِهَا قَوْمًا لَّيْسُوا بِهَا بِكَافِرِينَ>> (And if these disbelieve in it, then We have entrusted it to a people who are not disbelievers in it) [Q. 6:89]. For the Dominion (الملك) is too vast to be constrained from the existence of anything. Thus, Charity (*Sadaqah*) is a cosmic origin (أصل كوني), and Bestowal (*Wahb*) is a Divine origin (أصل إلهي).

### [The Ruling of Nature in the Highest Levels]

What supports what we have mentioned is that the angels spoke from their intrinsic nature (جبلتها) when they desired good only for themselves, and nature (الطبع) overcame them in this, preventing them from agreeing with The Real (الحق) in what He intended to manifest in the cosmos: the appointment of Adam as a vicegerent on earth. He informed them of this, but they did not agree with Him due to the ruling of nature in coveting the highest levels (أعلى المراتب). Then the ruling of nature concealed itself so that they would not be attributed with deficiency due to their disagreement with The Real. So, they presented the form of jealousy (الغيرة) for the majesty of The Real and altruism for His greatness. They were heedless of glorifying Him, for if they had stood with what is appropriate for His greatness, they would have agreed with Him. Although they intended good, they said: <<أَتَجْعَلُ فِيهَا مَن يُفْسِدُ فِيهَا وَيَسْفِكُ الدِّمَاءَ وَنَحْنُ نُسَبِّحُ بِحَمْدِكَ وَنُقَدِّسُ لَكَ>> (Will You place upon it one who causes corruption therein and sheds blood, while we declare Your praise and sanctify You?) [Q. 2:30]. That is, "We are more worthy than this one." Thus, they preferred their own view over Allah's Knowledge in His creation. For this reason, He said to them: <<إِنِّي أَعْلَمُ مَا لَا تَعْلَمُونَ>> (Indeed, I know that which you do not know) [Q. 2:30]. He described them by negating the Knowledge that The Real knew concerning this vicegerent, which they did not know. They praised themselves, and their question combined this, as they praised themselves, deemed themselves just, and criticized others, without referring the Knowledge in this matter back to Allah. This stems from the stinginess of nature (بخل الطبع) regarding the station (المرتبة).

### [Angels Under the Ruling of Nature]

This supports our view that the angels are under the ruling of nature (حكم الطبيعة) and that it has an effect on them. Allah the Exalted said: <<مَا كَانَ لِيَ مِنْ عِلْمٍ بِالْمَلَإِ الْأَعْلَى إِذْ يَخْتَصِمُونَ>> (I had no knowledge of the exalted assembly [of angels] when they disputed) [Q. 38:69]. And dispute (الخصام) is a ruling of nature. It has been narrated that the angels of mercy and the angels of punishment disputed concerning the person who died between the two towns. He described them with dispute. Were it not that their level is below the soul (النفس) and above the dust motes (الهباء), its ruling would have permeated them. Whoever wishes to understand the origin of this matter should look at the opposition of the Divine Names (تضاد الأسماء الإلهية). From there, this reality manifested in all beings. Thus, they share with us the ruling of nature, and among its rulings is stinginess and avarice in those composed of it. This stems from the Name *Al-Mani'* (The Withholder) among the Names. The reason for it in us is that poverty and need are intrinsic (ذاتي) to us and to every contingent being (ممكن). For this reason, contingent beings are in need of the determinant (المرجح) for their contingency. Thus, the one constituted by nature is essentially avaricious and stingy, but accidentally generous.

Allah only mandated Zakat and made it obligatory, purifying souls from avarice and stinginess, for this verified reason. The obligatory portion (الفرض) is harder on the soul than voluntary charity (صدقة التطوع), due to the compulsion (الجبر) in the obligatory and the choice (الاختيار) in the voluntary. For in the obligatory, he is a servant acting by the command of a master, while in the voluntary, he acts for himself, if he wills or not.

(Section concerning hoarding as a result of the soul’s stinginess and avarice)

### [The Bestowal of Servitude and the Bestowal of Lordship]

Know that hoarding (الادخار) and the doubt (الشبهة) of the soul until the time of need are due to its stinginess. When the needy person is designated, the bestowal occurs. Most of the souls of the righteous (الصالحين) operate on this basis. As for the common people, we have no discussion with them. We only speak with the People of Allah (أهل الله) according to their ranks. Few among the People of Allah seek out the needy so that they may deliver what they possess to them, whether obligatory or voluntary. The obligatory portion has its categories designated by Allah, and it is organized according to a specific threshold and time. The voluntary portion is not restricted by anything, for voluntary giving is the bestowal of Lordship (إعطاء ربوبية), so it is not limited. The obligatory portion is the bestowal of servitude (إعطاء عبودية), so it is according to what his Master prescribes for him. The bestowal of servitude is superior, for the obligatory is better than the supererogatory. But where is the servitude of necessity (عبودية الاضطرار) compared to the servitude of choice (عبودية الاختيار)? This category is rare among the righteous. Their doubt is that they are not obligated to seek out the needy, and the needy person is the one who asks. So, if he is designated to me by state or by asking, I give him.

Those who are above this rank—who give according to the limit of deservingness (الاستحقاق)—are also higher than these. They are those who give what they possess out of Divine nobility (كرما إلهيا) and characterization (تخلقا). They give to the deserving and the undeserving. In our view, from the perspective of Reality, the recipient is deserving, because he only took by the attribute of poverty and need, and not by any other attribute, regardless of the nature of the bestowal, whether it is a present, a gift, or any other type of giving. Consider the rich merchant who owns thousands, traversing deserts, sailing seas, enduring dangers, and separating from family and children, exposing himself and his wealth to ruin in his travels—all to seek one extra dirham beyond what he already possesses. The attribute of poverty (صفة الفقر) ruled him, blinded him from observing these horrors, and made the hardships easy for him, because the authority of this attribute is strong in the servant. Whoever views this matter with the perspective of The Real (الحق) sees that everyone who gives something, and that other person takes it from him, is deserving, due to his knowledge of the attribute by which he took it from him. Unless he takes it to fulfill a need for himself because he would be harmed by rejecting it, or to conceal his station by taking it. In that case, his hand is the Hand of The Real (يد حق), as it has been narrated that charity falls into the Hand of the All-Merciful before it falls into the hand of the beggar, and He nurtures it for him just as one of you nurtures his foal or his young camel.

This person takes without the thought of need at the moment, and he is heedless of the origin that motivated him to take, which is that the reality of the contingent being requires it. This person has had his reality in taking concealed from him by this purposeful matter. We know him when he is ignorant of himself. The giver only gave while being rich beyond what he gave, whether it was for a purpose, a recompense, or whatever it may be, for he is rich beyond what he gave. And the recipient only took as a deserving person or a needy person for what he took, whether for a purpose, a recompense, or whatever it may be, because the need for nurturing what was taken is a need, since nurturing only occurs after taking. Understand this, for it is subtle and obscure due to the Divine relationship in nurturing charity, combined with the Absolute Richness that He deserves.

### [Divine Relationships are Denied Only by One Who is Not a Pure Believer]

Divine relationships (النسب الإلهية) are denied only by one who is not a pure believer (مؤمن خالص). For Allah says: <<وَأَقْرِضُوا اللَّهَ قَرْضًا>> (And lend to Allah a goodly loan) [Q. 73:20], and He says: "I was hungry, and you did not feed Me; I was thirsty, and you did not give Me drink."

He clarified all of this, and He, glory be to Him, did not refrain from attributing these things to Himself, alerting us that He is the Manifest (الظاهر) in the manifestations (المظاهر) according to their preparedness. The upper hand (اليد العليا) is the one that spends, so it is better in every way than the lower hand (اليد السفلى), which is the one that takes. The giver by right (بحق) and the taker by right are not equal in rank, name, or state. There is nothing except that it has a face and a relationship to The Real (الحق) and a face and a relationship to creation (الخلق). For this reason, He made it spending (إنفاقا), saying: <<وَأَنفِقُوا مِمَّا رَزَقْنَاكُم>> (And spend from what We have provided you) [Q. 63:10] and <<وَمِمَّا رَزَقْنَاهُمْ يُنفِقُونَ>> (And from what We have provided them, they spend) [Q. 2:3]. He, the Mighty and Majestic, observed the greatest scholars (أكابر العلماء) in this address, for they are the ones who possess the bestowal from the perspective of it being spending (إنفاق), due to their knowledge of the two relationships. This is because *infāq* (spending) comes from *nafaq*, which is the burrow of the jerboa, called *al-nāfiqā’*, which has two doors. If it is sought from one door to be caught, it exits from the other door. It is like ambiguous speech: if you restrict the speaker to one aspect, he can tell you, "I only intended the other aspect of the possible meanings of the word."

Since the bestowal has a relationship to The Real and Richness, and a relationship to creation and need, Allah called it spending (*infāq*). The scholars of creation spend with both aspects. They see The Real as the Giver and the Taker in what they give, and they witness their hands as the locus where the giving and taking appear. This does not veil them from that. These Gnostics see only the deserving. Every recipient only takes by the ruling of deservingness (الاستحقاق). If he did not deserve it, acceptance from him of what was given would be impossible, just as Absolute Richness is impossible for him, while absolute poverty is not impossible for him.

### [Those Who Await the Times of Need and Hoard]

Then, those who await the appointed times of need and save, as we mentioned, due to the ambiguity that has occurred to them—some save with inner vision (بصيرة) and some save without inner vision. We do not concede the validity of their saving in the latter case, because it is not based on inner vision and such a person is not one of the People of God (أهل الله), for the People of God are the possessors of inner vision.

As for the one who saves based on inner vision, it is either due to a Divine Command (أمر إلهي) which he adheres to and judges by, or it is not due to a Divine Command. If it is due to a Divine Command, he is a pure servant (عبد محض), and we have no discussion with him, for he is commanded, as we suppose was the case with 'Abd al-Qadir al-Jili, for this was his station, and Allah knows best concerning his spiritual authority (التصرف) in the world.

If it is not due to a Divine Command, then either it is based on an unveiling (اطلاع) that this specific saved amount will not reach its intended recipient except through his hand, so he holds onto it based on this spiritual disclosure (الكشف). This is also one of the aspects found in the case of the Capable One (al-Qadir) and those like him. Or, he knows that it belongs to a certain person and must reach him, but he has not been unveiled as to whether it will be through his hand or the hand of another. Holding onto such an amount in this case is natural stinginess (الشح في الطبيعة) and joy in existence (فرح بالوجود), and he is veiled from that by his unveiling of who the owner is.

It was with this argument that we challenged 'Abd al-'Aziz ibn Abi Bakr al-Mahdawi regarding his saving, and he stopped and found no answer, for he had saved without the inner vision that it would be through his hand, nor the inner vision that the specific owner was with him. Thus, he was exposed before us immediately. Such a person ought not to save.

The master of the Sufi community, the wise man of his time, the one who was just in his state, Abu al-Su'ud ibn al-Shibl, was truly fair when he said: "We have left The Real (الحق) to dispose for us." He did not crowd the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية). If he were commanded, he would stop at the command; or if something were designated for him, he would adhere to the designation.

There is a difference of opinion among the People of God concerning this. Among the men of God, there are those for whom it is designated that the saved amount will not reach its owner except through their hand at a specific, determined time. Some of them hold onto it until that time. Others say: "I am not a guard. I will release it from my hand, since The Real, Exalted is He, did not command me to hold onto it. When the time arrives, The Real will cause it to return to my hand so that I may deliver it to its owner. Thus, between the two times, I am not described as saving, because I am the treasury of The Real, but I am not its treasurer, since I have emptied myself for Him and dedicated my soul to Him."

Due to His saying: "My servant's heart contained Me," I do not wish for anything that is not Him to crowd that vastness. Know this, for I have alerted you to a great matter in this issue.

Therefore, Zakat is not validly paid by a Gnostic ('Arif) unless he saved based on a Divine Command or a verified, specific unveiling (كشف محقق معين) that it was predetermined in Knowledge that there would be no treasurer for this thing other than him. In that case, it is conceded to him. Other than this, he pays Zakat in the same manner that the common people pay Zakat.

End of the Fifty-Third Part.

(In the Name of God, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful)

### A Section on the Merit of the Division of People Regarding Charity, Both the Giver and the Taker

### [People are Four Types Regarding What They Take and What They Give]

Know that people are of four types regarding what they give and what they take:

1.  A type that magnifies what he gives and belittles what he takes.
2.  A type that belittles what he gives and magnifies what he takes.
3.  A type that belittles both what he gives and what he takes.
4.  A type that magnifies both what he gives and what he takes.

For this reason, some of them are selective (ينتقي)—these are the ones who do not see the Face of The Real (وجه الحق) in things. And some of them are not selective—these are the ones who see the Face of The Real in things. They may still be selective due to the need of the moment, or they may not be selective due to their awareness of their absolute poverty (فقرهم المطلق). They are diverse, for their spiritual sources (مشاربهم) are different, as are their witnessings (مشاهدهم) and their spiritual tastes (أذواقهم), according to their states (أحوالهم). For the spiritual state (الحال) is to the rational soul what temperament (المزاج) is to the animal soul; temperament governs the body, and the spiritual state governs the soul.

### [Magnifying Charity is Sanctioned]

Know then that magnifying charity (استعظام الصدقة) is sanctioned. The Exalted said: <<فَكُلُوا مِنْها وأَطْعِمُوا الْبائِسَ الْفَقِيرَ>> (So eat from them and feed the distressed, the poor). And He said: <<وأَطْعِمُوا الْقانِعَ والْمُعْتَرَّ>> (And feed the contented and the beggar), meaning from the sacrificial animals (البدن) which He, Glory be to Him, made among the symbols of God (شعائر الله). He said: <<ومن يُعَظِّمْ شَعائِرَ الله فَإِنَّها من تَقْوَى الْقُلُوبِ لَكُمْ فِيها مَنافِعُ إِلى‏ أَجَلٍ مُسَمًّى ثُمَّ مَحِلُّها إِلَى الْبَيْتِ الْعَتِيقِ>> (And whoever magnifies the symbols of God—indeed, it is from the piety of hearts. For you, there are benefits in them until a specified term, then their place of sacrifice is the Ancient House), meaning the sacrificial animals.

In this context, He also said: <<ومِمَّا رَزَقْناهُمْ يُنْفِقُونَ>> (And from what We have provided for them, they spend). We have mentioned in the explanation of the spender that the spending has two aspects. Likewise here: we receive the meat from them, and The Real receives the piety (التقوى) from us regarding them. And part of our piety is magnifying them. Thus, the magnification of charity may stem from this perspective for some Gnostics. Therefore, he magnifies what he gives, if he is the giver, or what he takes, if he is the taker. Or, his witnessing may be a different spiritual taste.

### [The First Witnessing Ibn Arabi Tasted on the Sufi Path]

This was the first witnessing (مشهد) we tasted concerning this matter on this path. It was that one day I carried something in my hand that was usually considered contemptible and repulsive by the common people. People like us would not normally carry such a thing due to the arrogance of the ego (رعونة الطبع) and the desire to distinguish oneself from those who are not regarded with reverence.

I saw the Shaykh approaching with his companions. His companions said to him: "O our Master, so-and-so is approaching. He has not fallen short on the path; he has struggled with his soul (جاهد نفسه). Look, he is carrying such-and-such in the middle of the market where people can see him," and they mentioned what was in my hand.

The Shaykh said: "Perhaps he did not carry it as a struggle against his ego." They replied: "There is no other reason." He said: "Then ask him when he joins us."

When I reached them, I greeted the Shaykh. After returning the greeting, he said to me: "With what thought did you carry this in your hand? It is a contemptible and repulsive thing, and people of your rank among the worldly do not carry such things in their hands due to their lowliness and repulsiveness."

I replied: "O my Master, far be it from you to hold this view; it is not the view of one like you. Indeed, God the Exalted did not consider it repulsive or contemptible when He attached His Power to its creation, just as He attached it to the creation of the Throne and all the creatures you magnify. So how can I, a humble and weak servant, despise and consider repulsive something that is of this status?"

He kissed me and prayed for me, and said to his companions: "Where is this thought compared to the one who carries something merely to struggle against his ego?"

### [The Different Aspects of Magnifying Things for the People of God]

Thus, the magnification of charity may stem from this perspective, both for the giver and the taker. The People of God consider various aspects when magnifying things.

God revealed to Moses (peace be upon him): "If a worm-eaten onion comes to you from anyone, accept it, for I am the one who brought it to you."

The giver magnifies it because he is the deputy of The Real (نائب عن الحق تعالى) in delivering it. The taker magnifies it because God brought it to him through the hand of the giver. The hand of the giver here is the Hand of The Real, whether through witnessing (شهود) or strong faith.

For God says, "God heard the one who praised Him," speaking through the tongue of His servant, thus attributing the saying to Himself, while the servant is the one speaking it. And the Exalted said in the sacred tradition (الخبر): "I was his hearing, his sight, his hand, and his supporter."

The magnification may also occur for the People of Unveiling (أهل الكشف) because they see, witness, and hear the glorification (تسبيح) of that charity, gift, or donation to God the Exalted, and its magnification of its Creator with the tongue appropriate to it. And His saying: <<وإِنْ من شَيْ‏ءٍ إِلَّا يُسَبِّحُ بِحَمْدِهِ>> (And there is not a thing except that it glorifies Him with praise). So, it becomes magnified in his eyes due to its glorification of The Real and its constant lack of heedlessness or weakness. This is similar to how righteous kings are magnified, even if they are poor, despised, slaves, or servants, afflicted or healthy. People seek blessings from them due to their affiliation with obedience to God, as is said. How much more so for the possessor of this witnessing, who actually observes this?

Whoever has this witnessing, whether giver or taker, magnifies the creation of God, since all of it is of this status.

Magnification may also occur from the perspective of being poor toward that thing and needing it, because The Real, Exalted is He, made it the means by which his need is met, whether he is the giver or the taker, if this is his witnessing.

### [God is Named by Everything Needed, and is the Intended in Every Worship]

This may also be magnified based on the saying of God the Exalted: <<يا أَيُّهَا النَّاسُ أَنْتُمُ الْفُقَراءُ إِلَى الله>> (O mankind, you are the poor in need of God). In this verse, God is named by everything that is needed, and this charity is one of those things. The Names of The Real are magnified, and this is one of His Names. This is a subtle point that not everyone grasps, except those who witness this station. It stems from the aspect of Divine Jealousy (الغيرة الإلهية) and the general Divine Descent (النزول الإلهي العام), such as His saying: <<وقَضى‏ رَبُّكَ أَلَّا تَعْبُدُوا إِلَّا إِيَّاهُ>> (And your Lord has decreed that you worship none but Him), despite what is worshipped on earth—stones, plants, animals—and in the heavens—stars and angels. This is because they believe that every object of worship is a god, not because it is a stone or a tree or anything else. Even if they err in the attribution, they err in the object of worship. Therefore, He said: <<وقَضى‏ رَبُّكَ أَلَّا تَعْبُدُوا إِلَّا إِيَّاهُ>>. It was part of His decree that they believed in the Divine, and thus they worshipped what they worshipped. This is from the Divine Jealousy, so that none is worshipped except the one who possesses this attribute, and in reality, that is none but God, Glory be to Him. Thus, charity may be magnified based on this unveiling.

### [The Different Aspects of Contempt for Things for the People of God]

As for the contempt (استحقار) felt by some of them, it is due to another witnessing, not this one. For the witnessings, states, spiritual tastes, and sources of the people govern them with their power and authority. Is not everything we mentioned regarding magnification merely due to the governance of the states, tastes, and witnessings over their possessors?

### [Contingency is a State of Need for the Contingent]

One such witnessing is the contingency (إمكان) of what you give as charity, if you are the giver, or what you take, if you are the taker. Contingency (الإمكان) is a state of need (صفة افتقارية), lowliness (ذلة), want (حاجة), and contemptibility (حقارة) for the contingent thing (الممكن). The possessor of this witnessing therefore belittles everything, whether it is usually considered the most precious of things or not precious at all.

### [Ibn Arabi as a Witness to His Time]

Contempt may also be mixed with the act of giving for the sake of God and taking by the Hand of God. I saw one of the People of God—as I reckon, for I do not purify anyone before God, as the Messenger of God (may God bless him and grant him peace) commanded us and practiced, and as God forbade us from doing. A poor man asked a person to give him charity for the sake of God. The man being asked took out a purse containing pieces of silver, some large and some small, and began searching through them with his hand. The righteous man was looking at him, then turned to me and said: "Do you know what this giver is searching for?" I said: "No." He said: "For the measure of his own rank with God. Since he is giving for the sake of God, when he sees a large piece, he turns away from it, saying, 'I am not worth this much in the sight of God.'" He continued until he took the smallest piece he found and gave it to the beggar. The righteous man then said: "That is your value in the sight of God."

### [Everything is Contemptible next to God]

Indeed, everything is contemptible next to God. However, there is a Divine Generosity (كرم إلهي) supported by a Divine Jealousy (غيرة إلهية). This is because on the Day of Resurrection, a caller will announce among the people on behalf of God: "Where is what was given for other than God?" Then huge amounts of wealth, property, and estates will be brought. Then it will be said: "Where is what was given for My Face?" Then dry crusts, small coins, worn pieces of silver, and tattered clothes will be brought. The Real felt jealous that such things from His bounty were given for His Face. So, He took the charity with His Hand and nurtured it until it became like Mount Uhud, the largest possible size. He will display it to him before all witnesses, and He will belittle what was given for other than God, making it <<هَباءً مَنْثُوراً>> (scattered dust).

The one who possesses this witnessing must be mindful of this, and similar matters, the mention of which would be lengthy. We have alerted you to what is sufficient concerning this, which encompasses the four divisions into which we divided the world at the beginning of this chapter.

(A Section on the States of People Regarding Public and Secret Charity)

### [Considering Secrecy in Charity]

Some people observe secret charity (صدقة السر) because of The Real's praise for it, as in the sound tradition which includes the saying: "His left hand does not know what his right hand spends." And what came regarding secret charity and God's attention to it. So, he gives secretly because God knows what he spent, not for the sake of sincerity (إخلاص) or similar reasons, because the People [of God] are protected by God from manifest and hidden polytheism (الشرك الجلي والخفي). They are among the sincere ones.

There is nothing but God; there is no Lord other than Him.

This is due to their witnessing of The Real acting in all deeds. They know that The Real, Exalted is He, only mentioned the aspect of secrecy in such matters and preferred it over publicity for those who hold this view, because of a knowledge He possesses regarding it, even if they are not unveiled to it. This is not for the sake of sincerity and publicity, since publicity and secrecy are equal for these people, both the giver and the taker. Related to this is His saying: "Whoever remembers Me in himself, I remember him in Myself; and whoever remembers Me in a gathering, I remember him in a gathering better than theirs."

### [Considering Publicity in Charity]

As for the one who favors publicity (الإعلان) in charity, this is not his witnessing, nor is it like those mentioned. Rather, what dominates his heart and inner vision is the witnessing of The Real in everything. Every state, in his view, is undoubtedly an act (عمل). He witnesses nothing else. So, he announces the charity just as he mentions Him in a gathering. For whoever mentions Him in a gathering has certainly mentioned Him in himself, since the remembrance of the self precedes it without doubt. But not everyone who remembers Him in himself mentions Him in a gathering. This is a state added to the internal remembrance, not a rank that the possessor of internal remembrance misses, for internal remembrance is unseen in both cases; it is a secret in every respect.

Public charity announces the Divine Power (الاقتدار الإلهي). From whom should one hide it or keep it secret, when He is the Manifest (الظاهر) in the contingent manifestations (المظاهر الإمكانية)? This was the way of our Shaykh, Abu Madyan, who used to say: <<قُلِ الله ثُمَّ ذَرْهُمْ>> (Say, "God," then leave them). <<أَ غَيْرَ الله تَدْعُونَ>> (Is it other than God you call upon?). He may also announce it for the sake of emulation (التأسي), as a prophetic inheritance.

### [Showing Off and Sincerity for the Common People and the Elite of the People of God]

As for what the common people of this path, such as Abu Hamid [al-Ghazali] and al-Muhasibi and their likes, mention regarding showing off (الرياء) and seeking sincerity (الإخلاص), that is merely the address of The Real through the tongue of generality, so that it encompasses those who do not see [the action] as being for God. We, however, are speaking with the People of God concerning this.

Our Shaykh used to tell his companions: "Announce your obedience to God so that the Word of God may be the highest (كلمة الله هي العليا), just as these people announce their disobedience, violations, and display of abominations, without being ashamed before God."

One of the masters asked the companions of a respected Shaykh: "What did your Shaykh command you to do?" They said: "He commanded us to strive hard in deeds and to see our shortcomings in them." He said: "By God, he commanded you to pure Magianism! Why did he not command you to perform deeds while seeing the One who executes them and originates them?" This is related to the same matter.

### [The Perfect One is He Who Gives in Both States to Combine the Two Realities]

I have alerted you to the subtleties of secret and public charity in the souls of the People, along with the disagreement among the scholars of external law (علماء الرسوم) regarding obligatory charity (الصدقة المكتوبة) and voluntary charity (صدقة التطوع). This is well-known and does not need mention due to its fame, in order to maintain brevity and economy. Regarding public charity, the tradition "Whoever initiates a good practice (سن سنة حسنة)..." was reported.

As for the Perfect One (الكامل) among the People of God, he is the one who gives in both states, so that he may combine the two stations (المقامين), achieve the two results, look with both eyes, traverse the two paths (النجدين), and give with both hands. He announces it at a time and in a place where he sees that The Real has favored publicity, and he keeps it secret at a time and in a place where he sees that The Real has favored secrecy. This is the most fitting approach for the perfect ones among the People of God on the path of God the Exalted.

(A Section on Voluntary Charity)

### [Voluntary Charity and Self-Imposition of Obligation]

Voluntary charity (صدقة التطوع) is chosen servitude (عبودية اختيار) mixed with lordship (سيادة). If it were not so, it would not be voluntary charity. For the servant imposes it upon himself, just as The Real imposed Mercy upon Himself for those who repent and reform from those who commit evil out of ignorance. This is similar to a mixed Lordship (ربوبية مشوبة) by which the servant is governed.

For God the Exalted is not obligated to anything by the imposition of another; He is the One who imposes upon Himself what He imposes, from the perspective of being the Imposer. So, whoever gives from this obligation (الوجوب) from this station—if we assume that this Divine Level (المرتبة الإلهية) performs such an act and we assume a suitable reward for this act—we give that exact reward to the one who gives with this obligation from this station. These are individuals among the Gnostics who practice voluntary charity. Indeed, The Real, from that station, rewards him if this is his spiritual source.

This is a matter of spiritual taste (مسألة ذوقية) witnessed by the People, but I have not seen anyone alert to it before me, unless it was done and did not reach me. For the People of God who are realized in this station must grasp this, but God may not cause it to flow from their tongues, or some of them may find difficulty in expressing it. We have mentioned it in this book in another place with simpler language and clearer expression than this.

### [Voluntary Charity is Higher than Obligatory Charity]

By this consideration, voluntary charity is initially higher than obligatory charity (صدقة الفرض). For this voluntary act may also become obligatory by God's imposition, since the servant imposed it upon himself, like a vow (النذر). God made it obligatory by the servant's imposition. Other than the vow may also be attached to this category.

The Bedouin said in the sound Hadith: "O Messenger of God, is there anything besides Zakat?" He said: "No, unless you volunteer (تطوع)."

It is possible that God makes that obligatory upon him when he volunteers it, thus attaching it to the degree of the obligatory (الفرض), so that the reward is equal, with the added merit of the voluntary act. Thus, it rises above the original obligatory act by this measure.

God says: <<لا تُبْطِلُوا أَعْمالَكُمْ>> (Do not invalidate your deeds). This is a prohibition, and prohibition applies generally to the deed, unlike a command. Thus, commencing a religious act is binding, which is the clearer view. He equated the prohibited in the obligatory and the non-obligatory. The Messenger of God (may God bless him and grant him peace) made up (قضى) supererogatory prayers and fasts.

However, making up obligatory acts is not permissible according to us, and this is a matter of dispute regarding making up time-bound obligatory acts.

### [The Servant is Compelled in His Choice, in Resemblance to the Origin that Created Him]

The meaning of voluntariness (التطوع) in all this is only that the servant is a servant by origin (بالأصالة) and a locus for what his Master imposes upon him. He is essentially receptive to obligation and imposition upon him. Voluntariness is merely a return to his origin. Deviation from the origin is only by way of accident ('arad).

Whoever adheres to the origin constantly sees nothing but obligation constantly, because he is a compelled agent in his choice (مجبور في اختياره), in resemblance to the Origin (الأصل) that brought him into existence. For He said: <<ما يُبَدَّلُ الْقَوْلُ لَدَيَّ>> (The word will not be changed with Me). Thus, nothing proceeds from Him except what was preceded by Knowledge. Possibility (الإمكان) is negated with respect to God. There is nothing but "to be" or "not to be." Nothing else exists in the Divine Presence. From this comes His saying in the Hadith of Hesitation: "And he must meet Me," meaning he must die. And His saying: <<أَ فَمَنْ حَقَّ عَلَيْهِ كَلِمَةُ الْعَذابِ>> (Then is one upon whom the word of punishment has come true?). And His saying: <<حَقَّ الْقَوْلُ مِنِّي لَأَمْلَأَنَ>> (The word has come true from Me: I will surely fill...).

### [The Rule Belongs to Necessity, and Possibility Has No Essence]

In the Origin, there is only one command with God. There is only one command realized in the cosmos, known by those who know it and ignored by those who ignore it. This is what the realities (الحقائق) yield. The rule belongs to Necessity (الوجوب), and Possibility (الإمكان) has no essence (عين) in any respect.

The One (الواحد), if it contains only the Reality of Unity (حقيقة الوحدة) from all aspects, then Multiplicity (الكثرة) has no aspect in it from which it can emerge. Thus, only one thing emerges from it. If the One contains aspects of meanings or different relations, then the Multiplicity that appears from it is not impossible due to these many aspects.

### [Glory to the One, the Unifier by the One, and the Oneness of Multiplicity]

Pay attention to this issue, for from here you will know where you came from, who you are, and whether you are one or many. From what aspect does the One accept Multiplicity, and the Many accept Unity? Why is the wisdom in Multiplicity broader than in the One, when the One is the Origin? By what means did the branch (الفرع) depart from the rule of the Origin, and is there anything that supports it? Do the relations that gave rise to Multiplicity in the Origin return to the Origin, or do they give the rulings of the branch, and are not existential essences (أعيان وجودية) in the Origin? All this relates to this issue.

So, Glory be to the One (الواحد), the Unifier by the One, and the oneness of Multiplicity (أحدية الكثرة). For Multiplicity has a specific oneness (أحدية تخصها) that is necessary, by which that specific Multiplicity is named and distinguished from others. Distinction between things, whether singular or plural, only occurs through Unity. If two things shared in it, distinction would not occur, yet distinction is achieved. Thus, Unity is necessary in the single thing and the aggregate. There is nothing but the One, fundamentally and derivatively.

Look, my brother, into what I have alerted you to, for it is the core of Divine Gnosis (لباب المعرفة الإلهية). And look at what voluntary charity yields, and how noble this attribution is.

(A Section on the Rectification of Zakat Purification)

(A Section on Zakat from a Species Other Than the Taxable Wealth)

The Messenger of God (may God bless him and grant him peace) mandated one sheep for every five camels, and the species of sheep is different from the species of camels.

The fundamental question in this issue is: Does a thing purify itself, or is it purified by something else? The sound principle is that a thing is only purified by itself. This is the truth to which one returns, even if there is a difference in the form (الصورة). The consideration is only in the origin (الأصل).

### [Water and Dust Differ in Form, Not in Origin]

When God mandated purification for worship using water and dust, they are different in form but not different in origin. The origin is that <<من الماء خلق كل شي‏ء حي>> (from water We created every living thing), and He said concerning Adam: <<خَلَقَهُ من تُرابٍ>> (He created him from dust). Thus, purification in the manifest world only occurs by the very thing from which the object was created, such as the animality (الحيوانية) that encompasses both sheep and camels, and the financial nature (المالية) that encompasses both sheep and camels, and so on. Were it not for this encompassing commonality, purification would not be valid. For this reason, Zakat is valid in some types of wealth using a species other than the one in which the Zakat is due.

### [The Sanctification of the Servant is His Knowledge of Himself]

The Messenger of God (may God bless him and grant him peace) said regarding the purification of man from ignorance: "He who knows himself knows his Lord."

By his knowledge, his purification is valid, due to his knowledge of his Lord. The Real is the Absolute Holy One (القدوس المطلق), and the sanctification (تقديس) of the servant is his knowledge of himself. Thus, he is purified only by himself. Realize this.

(A Section on the Nisab)

The *Nisab* (النصاب) is the measure (المقدار), which is what can be quantified (كم), whether by volume or weight. The Lawgiver has clarified the *Nisab* for what is measured by volume and what is measured by weight.

(The Consideration in This)

The measured by volume (المكيل) is the intelligible (المعقول), based on the prophetic tradition that mentions the division of intellect ('Aql) among people by one *qafiz* (scoop), two *qafiz*, more, or less.

The Lawgiver attached it to the measured by volume, even though it is a meaning (معنى). The possessor of the most complete, manifest, and clear unveiling (الكشف) is the one who understands this. We have informed you before that the Presences (الحضرات) are three: intellectual, sensory, and imaginal (عقلية وحسية وخيالية). The imaginal presence is what brings meanings down into sensible forms—meaning, their self-disclosure (تجليها) occurs in them, since we do not comprehend them otherwise. It is from this Presence that the Lawgiver divided the intellect by volume, so that the intellect—which The Real manifested to him in the form of the measured by volume—would be understood, according to God's intention.

### [The Weighed are Deeds in the Presence of the Archetypes]

As for the weighed (الموزون), these are deeds (الأعمال), which are also accidental meanings ('aradiyya) that occur to the doer. God attached them to the weighed, saying: <<ونَضَعُ الْمَوازِينَ الْقِسْطَ لِيَوْمِ الْقِيامَةِ>> (And We place the scales of justice for the Day of Resurrection). And He said: <<فَمَنْ يَعْمَلْ مِثْقالَ ذَرَّةٍ>> (So whoever does an atom's weight of good), thus including the deed in the scale, making it weighed. However, this occurs in the Imaginal Presence (الحضرة المثالية), where meanings are only perceived in the form of sensible things, even the Divine Self-Disclosure (التجلي الإلهي) in sleep, where you only see The Real as a form. Many traditions have been reported concerning this, making further investigation unnecessary. This is something every person knows, as every person has imagination (تحيل) in wakefulness and sleep. This is why the Lawgiver (peace be upon him) interpreted what the imagination perceived, such as the image of milk as knowledge, and the image of a shackle as steadfastness in religion.

### [Quantities of the Weighed and Quantities of Number]

This is the knowledge of the *Nisab* as a *Nisab*, not as the *Nisab* for a specific thing, for that relates to the *Nisab* from which Zakat is extracted.

Included in this chapter is the knowledge of what has a single quantity and what has multiple quantities. We have a doctrine concerning this, because a piece of silver or gold may be unminted, making it a single body. If it is weighed, its weight may reach the *Nisab* or more. Since it is a single body, does that body have a single quantity or multiple quantities—meaning, more than one?

Know that numbers give a thing multiplicity or paucity of quantities, and number itself is a quantity. If the number is simple (بسيط) and uncompounded, it has only one quantity. This applies from one to ten, and to the tens contracted (عقد العشرات) one by one, such as twenty, thirty, up to one hundred, two hundred, one thousand, and two thousand, and so on. If the weighed or measured object, being a single body, is described by one of these numerical titles, it has a single ruling.

If it is described by other numerical titles, such as eleven, or one hundred and twenty, or three hundred, or three thousand, or any number that is compounded, then its quantities, based on the number, are multiple.

Or, if the weighed object is not a single body, such as dirhams and dinars, it also has multiple quantities. If the number is compounded and the weighed object is an aggregate of units, then both the number and the weighed object have multiple quantities. If one of them is compounded or aggregated, and the other is not aggregated or not compounded, then the one that is neither compounded nor aggregated has a single quantity, while the compounded or aggregated one has multiple quantities. Know this.

Quantities arise in bodies with the occurrence of division, for bodies undoubtedly accept division. But does separation by division apply to connection (الاتصال) or not? If it applies to connection, as some believe, then the single body has multiple quantities. If it does not apply to connection, as others believe, then it has only one quantity.

This detailed explanation we have given regarding the quantities of the weighed and the quantities of the number—we have not seen anyone address it, yet it is necessary. Whoever understands this issue will know whether it is valid to affirm the existence of the indivisible substance (الجوهر الفرد), which is the part that does not accept division, or not.

### [Categories of Number in the Zakat Nisab]

Furthermore, know that it is part of the wisdom of the Law that it gathered categories of number in what Zakat is due upon, namely the odd numbers (الفردية). It placed this in livestock, which are three categories: camels, cattle, and sheep—three being the first of the odd numbers. It placed the even numbers (الشفعية) in two categories: minerals (gold and silver) and grains (wheat and barley). It placed unity (الأحدية) in one category of produce, specifically dates. This is by consensus, without dispute. Anything else upon which Zakat is due is subject to dispute, some of which is marginal and some not.

(A Section on Zakat on Silver)

They agreed that the *Nisab* is five *awaq* (ounces), based on the sound tradition. An *uqiyya* is forty dirhams. This is the *Nisab* for silver (الورق), and its Zakat is five dirhams, which is a quarter of a tenth (ربع العشر).

(The Consideration in This)

Every species reaches a perfection (كمال) to which it culminates. The perfection in the mineral species is attained by gold, and its Zakat will be mentioned later. Silver is at half the degree of perfection. The time period for achieving mineral perfection is thirty-six thousand years, and for silver, it is eighteen thousand years, which is half the time of perfection.

All minerals seek the degree of perfection to attain it, but along the way, defects occur that prevent them from reaching the goal. The one that reaches the goal is called gold. What falls short of this degree due to a dominant ailment acquires another name, such as silver, copper, lead, tin, iron, and mercury.

### [The Formation of Gold and the Hardship of the Path to Perfection]

Gold is formed through the union of its two parents (sulfur and mercury) by marriage (نكاح) and the equalization of proportion, with the heat of the mineral dominating equally throughout. The parents are not affected by coldness or dryness that would influence this seeker of perfection before the dominance of the mineral heat takes hold. If the spiritual traveler (السالك) is of this status, he reaches the goal and finds the essence of gold.

If coldness enters his path more than is needed, it sickens him and prevents him from his goal, and he acquires the name silver. Silver is only one degree below gold in perfection. Perfection is in the four [elements], and silver is deficient by one degree out of four. Four is the first perfect number, and this is why it encompasses ten. Therefore, the Zakat on silver is a quarter of a tenth (ربع العشر), due to the lack of one degree compared to gold, caused by the dominance of coldness. Coldness is a primary origin, and heat is a primary origin, while moisture and dryness are secondary, passive branches (فرعان منفعلان). Moisture follows coldness because it is passive to it. For this reason, silver is formed in half the time of gold's formation.

### [The Scientific Miracle in the Quran]

Since the passive (المنفعل) indicates the active (الفاعل) and seeks it by its very essence, the mention of the passive suffices for the mention of what caused it, because it implies it. Thus, the Exalted said: <<ولا رَطْبٍ ولا يابِسٍ>> (Nor anything moist nor dry), and did not mention "nor hot nor cold." This is part of the eloquence and miraculous nature of the Quran, as He knew that the one who brought it, Muhammad (may God bless him and grant him peace), was not engaged in natural sciences and would not know this much. Thus, it is known with certainty that this did not originate from him, and that it is <<تَنْزِيلٌ من حَكِيمٍ حَمِيدٍ>> (a revelation from a Wise, Praiseworthy One), and that the Speaker is All-Knowing, which is God the Exalted. The Prophet (may God bless him and grant him peace) knew everything through God's teaching and informing him, not through his own thought, contemplation, or research. Only one whom God informs of such matters can truly appreciate the measure of prophethood.

Look at how wise the Law of Zakat is in mandating Zakat on these species according to this known limit for each species, for those who contemplate and gain insight.

(A Section on the Nisab of Gold)

The agreed-upon *Nisab* for gold is what we shall mention, God willing. One group said that Zakat is due on twenty dinars, just as it is due on two hundred dirhams. Another said there is nothing due on gold until it reaches forty dinars, in which case one dinar is due, which is a quarter of a tenth (ربع العشر), since a tenth of forty is four, and a quarter of four is one. Another said there is no Zakat on gold until its exchange value reaches two hundred dirhams or their equivalent. If it reaches that, a quarter of a tenth is due, whether it is twenty dinars, less, or more. This applies to amounts less than forty.

When it reaches forty, the consideration is the gold itself, not the dirhams, neither by exchange value nor by monetary value.

(The Consideration in This)

In every forty dinars, one dinar is due, which is a quarter of a tenth of that amount. We mentioned that silver, when judged, is seeking the perfection attained by gold, but one nature—coldness—from the four natures dominated it, thus taking one nature from gold and removing it from the state of equilibrium. For this reason, one dinar was taken from the forty dinars, which is the *Nisab* of gold, and it is a quarter of a tenth. If you multiply four by ten, the result is forty. Four is a tenth of forty, and one is a quarter of four, so it is a quarter of a tenth. This is the one [degree] that silver took, becoming silver in its quest for perfection. This amount was reduced from gold, so its Zakat was one dinar.

### [The Consideration of Those Who Say the Nisab of Gold is 20 Dinars]

This one dinar agrees with the five dirhams in being a quarter of a tenth of what was taken from it. For twenty is a tenth of two hundred, and a quarter of twenty is five. Thus, in two hundred dirhams, there are five dirhams, which is a quarter of a tenth.

Whoever equates gold with silver and says that Zakat is due on twenty dinars, just as it is due on two hundred dirhams, or whoever uses the exchange value or monetary value of two hundred dirhams, mandates Zakat on gold that reaches this value or exchange rate. This applies to amounts less than forty, for no prohibition was reported regarding amounts less than forty dinars of gold, as was reported for silver. He said: "There is no charity due on less than five *awaq*," but he did not say, "There is nothing due on less than forty [dinars]." For this reason, disagreement was permissible regarding gold but not regarding silver. They both agree on the quarter of a tenth in every respect.

The tenth and the quarter of it were considered because the number four encompasses ten, so it was multiplied by it and not by others. This is because four encompasses itself and the numbers below it, making the total ten. This is why four is said to be the first perfect number: four itself, plus three (seven), plus two (nine), plus one (ten).

Whoever multiplies four by ten is like one who multiplies four by itself, including what it contains. Zakat became obligatory because of its self-regard (نظرها لنفسها) in that matter, and it did not regard its Creator and Originator. So, The Real took from it its self-regard and called it Zakat (purification) for it, meaning purification from the claim [of self-sufficiency]. Thus, it remained for its Lord, by its Lord, and no distinct right was determined for Him in it, because all of it belongs to Him, not to its essence.

(A Section on Al-Awqas, the Amounts Exceeding the Nisab)

Scholars agreed on Zakat for the *Awqas* (intermediate amounts) in livestock, and that there are no *Awqas* in grains. They differed regarding the *Awqas* of gold and silver. I hold the view that Zakat is not due on the *Awqas* of gold and silver, for attaching them to grains is more appropriate than attaching them to livestock. For the animal is adjacent to the plant, and the plant is adjacent to the mineral. Thus, attaching it in ruling to what is adjacent is more rightful, for the neighbor has more right to his proximity.

(The Consideration in This)

Perfection (الكمال) does not accept deficiency, and Zakat is a deficiency (نقص) in wealth. For this reason, when the animal was perfected by humanity, there was no Zakat on it. Things were only created to seek perfection, and the only perfect one is the Human. The most perfect of minerals is gold, and this is why it does not accept deficiency by fire in the way other minerals do.

If you say: "Silver has fallen short of the degree of perfection, so it is deficient. Therefore, Zakat should be due on its *Awqas*," we reply: The Real included it in the Zakat when it reached the *Nisab* of gold, but He did not do that for the rest of the minerals. Were it not for a strong affinity between them, they would not share the ruling. Let it be the same for the *Awqas*.

### [Change and Transformation in Forms and the Difference of Relations to the Divine Presence]

If you say that Zakat is a deficiency in wealth, and one who reaches perfection is not deficient, yet Zakat is due on gold when it reaches the *Nisab*—and it is gold in the *Nisab* and gold in the *Awqas*, and the ruling of perfection has not left it—we reply: That is what I say. This is how it should be if we followed this principle. However, another Divine Principle (أصل إلهي) opposes us, which is the change and transformation in forms during the Divine Self-Disclosure (التجلي الإلهي) and the difference in relations and considerations (الاعتبارات) applied to the Divine Presence, while the Essence (العين) is one. The relations are different: He is the Knower from this perspective, and the Powerful and the Creator from that perspective.

The Real, Glory be to Him, did not mandate Zakat on the essences of the taxable items merely because they are essences, but specifically because they are *wealth* (أموال) in these particular essences, not in everything that is called wealth.

When the ruling of Zakat came upon them when they reached the *Nisab*, we considered their financial nature (المالية), and we did not consider their essences. But in the *Awqas*, we considered their essences, not their financial nature, so we lifted the Zakat from them. This is similar to how, in the transformation of theophanies, we considered the beliefs (الاعتقادات) and the rank (المرتبة), and did not consider the Essence (الذات). And in transcendence (التنزيه), we considered the Essence and did not consider the rank or the beliefs.
